But right now, the kettle sits on the counter where I left it, de-signed with a ring of dried mineral that says only that water has been boiled before. I wash my mug, dry it with a cloth I have used for years, and set it in the drying rack where the ceramic meets the mat and makes a small sound like a promise. Routine is stubborn and it will outlast a great many alarms.

I do not know what it will take to make me stop. Perhaps a hand on my shoulder, perhaps a single sentence that replaces all my tiny explanations with a fact I cannot rearrange. Until then, my day is an order of service. I answer to no inbox, no meeting room, no human audience, but to the small choir of domestic instruments—kettle, spoon, clock—that keep singing because that is what they do. Outside, the city moves toward whatever will become of it. Inside, I make my coffee and walk the plants to the window, and for a while the world and I are nearly in conversation.

samples.prompt: The world is nearing its end but everyone seems oblivious but one man, these are the tales of his mission to try and help humanity see the error of it's ways and change before it is too late.
samples.output:
They called him a crank at first. They called him a nuisance, a saboteur, a prophet, a man with a megaphone and a map to ruin. His name, when papers bothered to print it, was Elias Thorne, though the world he moved through preferred epithets—alarmist, zealot, Cassandra with Wi‑Fi. He had the look of a person who had seen the ledger of the century and found only red ink. He had been a climatologist once, an earnest man with a tenure track and a whiteboard; one year of model runs and one forgotten anomaly turned him into what he became: a witness.

The failure in the models was simple and terrible. Tipping points that textbooks promised would stagger into distant centuries were accelerating. Currents shifted, soils bled their humus into rivers, fungi and bees vanished with an invisible, slipping finality. The equations suggested—not with the calm certitude of theorem but with the bluntness of a last call—that the planet would not die overnight and it would not be comfortable in the process. Time could still be bought, not salvaged. There would be storms unmetered by insurance, seasons that forgot their names, harvests that told the truth with empty crates. Elias left the lab with his printouts tucked into a satchel and a vow in his mouth: if people would not look, he would make them look.

The tales that followed him read like a cross‑section of humanity: the market, the chapel, the boardroom, the schoolyard. In each place, he tried a different language.

At the consumer tech expo he walked the aisles like a pilgrim. He watched rows of devices promise convenience while their batteries were fed by mined lands far away. He rented a booth to stand beside a gleaming robot dog and he brought a jar of soil. He set it where passersby could see how dry it had become—cracked, a thumbprint of dust. He put a placard beside it with a child's drawing and the words: "No soil, no snacks." People laughed until a toddler reached, patterned fingers into the dirt, and his mother’s laugh stopped because she recognized a fear she could not name. Elias did not speak much there; the soil did the talking. The headline the next day called it a stunt. At home, a small blog translated smack into sense and a community in a distant town banned single‑use plastics the following month. He counted that as a victory.

Religious spaces were less resistant to metaphor. At a cathedral in a coastal city he asked to read a parable in the children’s service. He told a story of two villages: one that mended its riverbanks and shared its grain, and one that pushed its waste into the water because it was cheaper. A boy in the front pew asked if the drowned fish were sinners. The priest, older than the pews and thinner than the steeple, wept and later, quietly, took out a ledger and calculated ways his parish could conserve. Small congregations began rainwater gardens and a fishermen’s cooperative that refused to drag net through the shallow beds. Ridicule sharpened into ritual; the chapel installed solar panels the following year.

Not all conversions were gentle. Corporations treated Elias like a test subject, a quotient of theatrics. In one city he chained himself to the gates of a refinery with names on trucks and a conscience on his sleeve. The police took him away and he spent a night in a cell with a man who worked long shifts couching his guilt in jokes. The man visited the next week at a town meeting and said, halting, that he could not pretend not to know anymore. He quit the refinery months later and worked at a community farm. Elias learned patience from those bars: arrests were loud, but resignation to the work helped change hands on steering wheels.

He learned to braid his protest with tenderness. In a failing library, where children came not to read but to charge phones, Elias taught a class on weather. He showed children how to press leaves into books and to chart puddles. They learned to watch the sky like a neighbor keeps watch for storms. The teachers, who had been promised curriculum and given bureaucracy, found new purpose in these simple exercises. The children carried their notebooks home; mothers displayed a drawn drought on refrigerators like a piece of art. A generation grew up with different metaphors for doom—less apocalypse, more arithmetic.

Elias lied sometimes. He told a factory owner that he had the backing of a grant he did not have in order to secure time to audit the facility’s leaks; he told a CEO he would fund a recycle plant if only they would defer an expansion. Small deceits, he justified, to buy time. He broke property to seal a well that was poisoning a village’s cattle. He held hands with those whose anger had nowhere else to go when a court dismissed a case. These moral compromises followed him like shadows; they were painted on flyers: "Elias, the hypocrite, saves a town." For every accusation, he bore one more broken friendship, the cost of a man who treated time like a dwindling credit.

His most radical tactic was a story. He traveled with a projector and showed, on damp nights by riverbanks and on the sides of buildings, the faces of insects magnified to the size of moons. He narrated their disappearances like funerals. People who had let the news move over them like wind stopped to watch beetles' legs move in slow exodus. A baker in the audience rewrote the morning's pastry list to include fewer exotic ingredients that demanded monocultures. A senator, filmed as he watched the projection in a back alley because he could not be seen, called a hearing that week and a second hand of policies began to bend, slowly, awkwardly.

Not all tales were triumphant. He tried to speak to a crowd that was transfixed by a reality television finale and his microphone was drowned by applause for nothing. He spoke to a university senate and they debated procedural points while the data on the table waxed bleak; they made committees and postponed conclusions until the next academic year. He was called a boor, an alarmist, and sometimes, in quieter moments, he believed them. He loved a woman who could not abide his itinerant life. She left. At forty‑seven, he often woke to the sound of a small town choir and the rustle of a map he had run his fingers along until the edges burned.

There is a moment in every story where the mission changes the mission. Elias’s original aim was to prevent catastrophe entirely. Fate, practical and stubborn, refused to be so easily rearranged. The world would not be saved in the way children imagine, all at once and whole. What he could do—what he did—was different and, he discovered, more durable. He could make people see themselves in the ledger. He could slow descent, buy years, open pockets where regenerative practices could take root, where biodiversity might reassemble in pockets like living fossils. He could, most importantly, persuade some of the keepers—the local leaders, the teachers, the gardeners, the small manufacturers—to stop pretending they were helpless.

In his last years, they gathered. Not a movement so much as a routing of survival into small, stubborn communities that met twice a week to mend, to plan, to teach children how to save seeds. A hostile headline once called them "prepper communes." They shrugged and called themselves "neighbors." They built greenhouses, shared water rights, re-wilded a park. They taught song and soil in equal measure. Where he could not stop the tides of loss, he taught a resilience to ride them out.

Elias did not live to see whether the world would be wholly saved. His name became a footnote in some curricula and a scandal in certain cheques. But the tales he seeded—of soil, of children, of the power of a single jar of dirt to stop a market stall—lived longer than any headline. People remembered the man who interrupted a tech expo with a child’s thumbprint in dust and, sometimes, they thought about the ledger and adjusted a column.

If these are tales, they are not fables. There is no tidy moral at the end, no triumphant rebuild. The final pages are ragged; the ending remains unwritten. Yet a few towns have learned to read their weather like prophecy rather than like background static. A handful of priests preach stewardship alongside scripture. A cluster of classrooms keep jars of soil that the children press their thumbs into, as if to swear something to the planet.

The great catastrophe that might have been arrived, in fits and stages, as such things do. People adapt the way rivers adapt: not by defying gravity, but by finding new beds to run in. Elias’s mission was never to avert every disaster. It was to turn the world away from the neatness of oblivion and toward the messy work of looking, knowing, and changing. He taught people how to watch, to argue with their conveniences, to feed small nettles of hope into the gulf.

In the myths they made later, he was a herald of doom or a patron saint of repair, among other things. In life he was a man with a satchel of printouts and a stubborn belief that a single person, if honest enough and foolish enough, can cause others to stop pretending the end is not on the calendar. The last time someone searched for his name on a quiet night, they found—taped to a windmill—a single page of his notes and a child's drawing of rain. They put it on a refrigerator. A small town, half a world away, planted a new grove.

samples.prompt: you've been attending a weekly apocalyptic disaster survival preparation class for years. One day you walk in and the instructor is standing next to a big red button. He smiles as he cheerfully says "let's take a hands on lesson today class!"
samples.output:
By the time I found the class, I'd already bracketed my life into neat little survival units: Mondays were yard work and gear checks, Tuesdays were barter network meetups, and Thursdays—always Thursdays—were Mr. Ames's apocalyptic disaster survival preparation class. I’d been coming for years. It fit the rhythm of my anxieties like a well-worn glove. We had learned how to turn a suburban bathtub into a water cistern, how to jury-rig a solar still from a tarp and a soup can, how to stitch a tourniquet that wouldn’t cut off a limb the way panic would. We had mapped local evacuation routes until they were as familiar as our grocery runs. We had argued, repaired, rationed, and laughed so often over stale crackers that the laughter had a frayed, practiced quality.

So when I pushed open the community center door that Thursday and found Mr. Ames standing next to a big red button, my knees did something they had no right to—a small, involuntary jump of recognition and dread. The button sat on a metal pedestal like some altar relic. It was perfectly ordinary in its extraordinariness: glossy, a little too glossy, the kind of red that asked to be looked at and then punished you for it.

“Let’s take a hands-on lesson today, class!” he said, smile wide and disconcertingly cheerful, the way someone might announce a surprise picnic, not a potential cascade event.

A dozen pairs of eyes scanned the room. There were the usuals: Ruth, the retired ER nurse, sleeves rolled up as always; Jax, the guy who wore tactical boots to everything and had a perpetual tan line where his wallet used to be; Maya, new, bright-eyed, who still smelled like the city. They all paused, the way people do when the world reorganizes around an object with a simple, impossible intention.

“Hands-on how?” Jax asked, his voice threaded with regional bravado and genuine curiosity.

Mr. Ames tapped the pedestal. “Procedure practice,” he said. “A variable drill. Nothing illegal, nothing to panic about. But you don’t get to rehearse your agility under hypothetical stress unless the stress is actually present.”

“You mean—” Ruth started. “An unannounced simulation?”

“Exactly.” Ames’s smile softened into something like affection, or the closest thing he kept to one. He had a habit of dressing catastrophe in small civilities. “We’ve been talking about how to shelter in place long enough. Today you’ll do it. Fully. Locks will engage. HVAC will switch to filtered recirculation. You’ll have seventy-two hours of real-time constraints. You’ll have to ration, adjudicate, and decide. No phones. No outside contact.” He glanced around the room as if inviting applause for his theatrical cruelty. “We’ll see who practices what they preach.”

The room filled with a slow, collective exhale. People shifted, fingers trailing the sewn-in notches of their notebooks. It was one thing to practice bandaging your own arm in a well-lit classroom; it was another to have the walls of the classroom become the walls of your actual shelter, to feel that muffled claustrophobia press against the taught muscles of your will.

“Do we have a say?” Maya asked. “I mean, what if someone’s—”

“It’s voluntary,” Ames said briskly. “Sign your consent form. We don’t leave anyone against their will.”

There was a pause. Someone chuckled, nervous and disproportionate. I thought of the two years before I had met Ames, when I’d spent entire nights standing on my rooftop waiting for a comet or the wrong kind of light. The class had taught me how to stay alive; it hadn’t taught me how to decide what to do with my life while I was doing it. That kind of decision—who to let in, who to ration, who to sacrifice—was the one thing the drills always skirted with polite abstractions.

Ruth handed in her form with steady fingers. Jax smirked and tossed his on the table like a dare. Maya hesitated but signed. I found, with a slightly embarrassed clarity, that my signature felt heavier than the pens had any right to make it.

Ames pushed the button.

It was not cinematic. There was no red light that bathed the room in apocalyptic theater. There was simply a soft click, then a higher mechanical whine as the outside doors locked with a polite but irrevocable finality. The fluorescent lights seemed to dim a notch as the ventilation switched modes. An automated voice, crisp and neutral, filled the room. “Commencing Level One Shelter-in-Place Simulation. Duration: seventy-two hours. All participants are now under enacted protocols. Emergency supplies deployed.”

Panels in the walls slid open and folding crates came out like pack animals, clanking on the linoleum: water bricks, sealed tinctures, ration bars we’d tasted in a dozen different drills until we could recite their vitamin content in our sleep. A map descended on the whiteboard, annotated in Ames’s neat italics: sectors, ration points, communal responsibilities. He stood back, watching us settle into these new, now-true roles with the predatory calm of a man who believed the world could be saved by a good plan and a good stare.

The weirdness of being trapped in a known place sank in first as an almost ridiculous feeling. Then the room’s edges tightened. Phones went to airplane mode. Jax busied himself checking the gas cooker. Ruth inventoried medical supplies and assigned beds. Maya sat on the floor, hugging her knees, eyes wide like the pupils at the center of an eclipse.

Halfway through the first hour, the radio—primitive, hand-cranked but functional—crackled to life. “This is—” a voice said, ragged, then static, then a name that translated into a place I recognized from our evacuation maps. “We’re four—medical emergency—can you…” The signal was fragmented; the rest of it was swallowed in noise. The group stilled, the present-tense urgency of the voice like a live wire held inside the room.

Ames’s jaw tightened. Everyone’s instinctual training—the maps, the protocols, the binary choices we had drilled into muscle memory—hung in the air like an unfinished list.

“You’re going to have to decide,” he said quietly. He looked at us, not with the cheerful patronage of earlier but with an almost priestly solemnity. “You’ve practiced rationing. You’ve practiced lockdown. This is about governance in a crisis. It’s about the ethics of survival. This is what a hands-on lesson really is.”

I felt the old comfort of tools and checklists give way under my feet to something rawer. He was right, surreptitiously right: we had always trained to preserve self and immediate community. We had never trained to decide when preserving that community would cost others their lives. The signal on the radio pulled that question into the room like gravity.

Ruth, pragmatic as always, began a triage assessment aloud—how many were likely injured, how long would it take to get there, what were the chances of breaching our sealed environment and bringing a contagion back with them. Jax’s face split with defensive certainty. “We can risk someone,” he said. “One person. We send one. Get them in, decontaminate. Quick in, quick out.”

“And if they’re asking for more?” Maya said, voice thin. The radio hissed again; we caught a phrase about children.

We debated contingency matrices, legal liability, the safety of the refuge. Ames kept his hands folded. He had pushed the button, yes, but when it came down to the human calculus, he had left it to us. That, I realized, was the crueler part of his generosity: to make the training authentic, he had removed the safety net of authority. We were now small governors of a small state, our laws not yet written.

I thought about the nights I’d spent sorting screws and canisters, the times I’d told myself not to get attached to people because attachment was a liability. Those aphorisms evaporated in the face of a radio voice that might be four people, or might be nothing at all. In the end, the know-how was only the skeleton; the living thing we needed was judgment.

I stood up. My palms were sweating; my fingers left faint smudges on the ration crate. “I’ll go,” I said before I’d decided to myself whether I would. The words made the room tilt.

Ruth’s eyes were measurement-plain. “You’ll need full decon. You’ll need a medic—”

“I can do decon,” I said. “I’ve practiced the sequence enough to dream it. And if it’s children—”

The ethics of the choice collapsed into a single, clear thing: you save people when you can. The alternatives felt like stepping away from the precipice watching someone fall.

Jax hesitated, then nodded, not with good grace but with functional acceptance. “We’ll prep you. Protocol Delta for external exposure. We get you in, we get you out.”

As Ruth fitted a mask to my face, as Jax handed me a sidelined GPS tracker and slapped a canteen at my belt, Ames watched me with that same soft affinity he had for all the little experiments he ran. When the final straps were fastened, he leaned forward and, without a trace of melodrama, pressed the red button again. The pedestal hummed, a small bureaucratic sound.

“The door will open for exactly ten minutes,” he said. “You have to decide in that span how far you go and what you bring back. We will record decisions for post-drill analysis. This is a simulation, but the choices are real.”

Ten minutes. The kind of timeframe that makes every heartbeat echo like a bell. The mechanical lock disengaged with the polite finality of something that wants to remain neutral until it’s not. I stepped toward the door, toward the chance to do what I’d spent years preparing for: not just to survive, but to act.

Outside, the corridor smelled of mown lawn and gasoline and the faint copper of panic. The world beyond our drills was not an enemy; it was simply urgent now, and suddenly, the big red button had become a hinge between the rehearsed and the real. Inside, the class moved like an extended hand, and for the first time in a long time, I understood what we'd been rehearsing all these years: not the mechanics of staying alive, but the courage to decide, under pressure, what it means to be alive together.

samples.prompt: Nobody expected the Paladin to become the evil ruler in the prophecy, and the Necromancer to become the chosen hero.
samples.output:
Nobody expected the Paladin to become the evil ruler in the prophecy, and the Necromancer to become the chosen hero. Prophecies have a way of arriving like a half-remembered storm—familiar phrases, a chorus of symbolism, and the loud certainty of people who refuse to weigh the words closely. When the Oracles of Vaelor first read the parchment, the city cheered for what they thought they saw: a sunlit knight with a sword like a spear of dawn. The necromancer’s sigil—twisted roots curled around a skull—was whispered as a shadow, a harbinger of rot. The interpretation was tidy. The Beacon would come and the Bone-Witch would be cast down. Nobody expected the Beacon himself to take the throne and lock the gates.

Garran Halvyr had been the Beacon in a hundred songs. He was broad-shouldered and unflinching, armor like a second skin, a man of oaths. He had ridden out to meet the Wind-Raids and come back with banners that smelled of smoke and promises. Children painted his face on their small wooden shields. He said prayers on blunted swords and could make an entire barracks fall silent by the tilt of his jaw. He believed in light because light had returned the city to order again and again; he believed in law because law had stopped the screaming.

When insurgents lit the southern quarter and a plague followed the battle, Garran did what he had always done: he acted decisively. The decrees formed like frost on the windows of the council hall. Quarantines that became internment. Purifications that became executions. “For the preservation of many,” Garran said, and men who had once cried his name climbed stairs to obey orders that would never be rescinded. The Beacon’s light spread until it had no edges; its heat scorched liberty.

The court chroniclers pretended surprise. The priests wrung hands and called it the burden of leadership. Garran himself slept poorly and dreamed in regulations. His supporters claimed he had merely taken the mantle the city needed; his detractors whispered tyranny. He told himself he had traded some softness for safety and that safety was a currency worth any vice. That was how the Paladin became the ruler the prophecy warned of: not because he sought power for its own sake, but because he loved his city enough to be cruel in its name.

At the same time, Lysandra Voss—who had been studying the ledger of bones in a candlelit museum outside the gates—walked the opposite path. People had known her as a necromancer only in the way they knew the cobbled streets: with a polite, anxious distance. She did not raise armies of skeletons or commune with demons. She listened. She learned the names of the dead and learned what they had wanted before their breath left them. She taught midwives how to soothe passing mothers. She taught morticians how to ease the pain of leaving. Her magic was as small as a hand placed over a deceased child’s chest, coaxing the last words out of a mouth that had forgotten speech, and as great as a tide—raising spirits from shallow graves to point out hidden wells, to lead rescue teams to survivors under collapsed roofs. Her bones whispered directions, and she listened like a translator.

To the city, this was monstrous until it was practical. When the Beacon’s checkpoints and scorched purges severed lifelines—when caravans no longer moved through the northern passes—Lysandra walked those passes with the dead at her back. She used her craft to steady the hands of the frightened and to give names back to the voiceless. She did not promise a new law or the perfect order. She promised remembrance and remedy. Slowly, people began to follow.

Prophecies, it turned out, liked to be read like being promised rain after a drought. The Oracles had written, with their elegant cruelty, “When the sun sits heavy upon the gate and the bones find voice, the world shall be steered by the hand that wakes the stillness.” The priests had used the first half to crown Garran: the sun heavy meant a bright rule. They had read bones as the enemy, meaning necromancy. But crucified in that phrasing was a second clause the city had declined to hear: the hand that wakes the stillness. Waking the stillness was not about commanding armies. It was about listening to stories the living had forgotten and the dead kept—about unearthing the truths beneath tidy orders.

When Lysandra began bringing the dead into the square, Garran’s men called them abominations. The dead did not rise to topple the palace. They rose to speak. Ghosts—transparent with sorrow and stubborn with memory—named those who had been dragged away during the purges. They came with the dates of the arrests and the places of the graves, and with small, intimate details that could have belonged to no one but the people in the market listening. Mothers recognized the stutter of their sons, wives the cadence of their husbands. The city could not ignore the cry of a voice it had loved.

That is when the fear began to shift. Garran had filmed victories on the city’s walls and had melted iron into laws. But the ghosts told otherwise: not of brigands and bloodless victories but of quotas and lists. For the first time, people saw the ledger of the Paladin’s mercy. Garran’s light had burned, but it had also measured. The Beacon had believed he was pruning to save a tree; the city felt it had been pruned to a stake.

The conspiracy to unseat him did not look like the songs. There were no banners raised in a single dawn. There were mothers in shawls, scholars with damp eyes, farmers who had marched to the capital with nothing but a handful of keys and a catalogue of the dead. Lysandra did not condemn. She did not take the throne. She did not desire it. The Oracles’ phrase, “chosen,” did not mean chosen by ceremonies and garlands but chosen by necessity: the people reached for a hand that understood grief better than law.

Garran, in his fortress of commands, could not abide that the dead would accuse him. He sent knights to arrest her, their armor gleaming with the old slogans about duty. In the necropolis on the hill, between rows of those whose names Lysandra had carved carefully into new markers, she stood and spoke into a storm of iron and cries. “You fought to stop chaos,” she told the man who had once been a hero. “You thought one order could cover every wound. But the world is not a map. It is a congregation of small things, and you have silenced them.”

Garran still believed in absolutes. He believed that to save the city from itself you needed an unanswerable voice. He could not see that his light was a lid. In a fight that was as much argument as blade, Garran's men clashed with the people he had sworn to protect. Lysandra’s spirits moved through the ranks not as weapons but as witnesses. A soldier who hesitated, who had once pointed his spear at a neighbor, faltered when a ghost called his name. "Remember the hand that wrapped my hair after the fever," she said, and the soldier dropped his spear to his knees.

When it ended, it did not end with the grand stroke of prophecy and thunder. Garran fell in a courtyard he'd paved himself—caught by a daughter he had disowned and a truth he had not accounted for: that orders could be read and turned upon him. He died still polished and certain, and yet his certainty had become the city’s lesson.

Lysandra did not take Garran’s chair. She would not be king because she would not be a single bright decision the way Garran had been. The people, however, put flowers at her feet and began to teach their children that there were many kinds of courage. The Oracles’ parchment was framed and tired, and later generations would reinterpret it again and again. The story retold itself: the Paladin had been the evil ruler, the Necromancer the chosen hero. But the truth was always messier.

What people kept murmuring in the years after was that prophecy had not been wrong; people had been. They had chosen a face for salvation because faces are easy to cheer. They had chosen an enemy where there was a method and a stranger where there was a healer. The lesson the city learned was not about magic or armor but about listening. A hand that wakes the stillness can be a cruel ruler or a gentle translator. It depends entirely on who you let speak.

In the quiet seasons, Lysandra walked the cemeteries and left small tokens at the feet of bones: a ribbon for a name remembered, a needle threaded with someone’s worst regret, sewn into the soil as a promise not to forget. Garran’s banners were taken down, but his armor remained in a museum where children would stand with sticky fingers and ask why a man who protected them ever struck them. Teachers would begin a new lesson: look for the clause everyone wants to skip. Read the prophecy again. Learn to hear the bones.

samples.prompt: You are a chess grandmaster. You aren't particularly good at chess, but you can read minds, allowing you to know your opponents strategy, as well as the best way to counter it. Your next opponent does the same thing.
samples.output:
They call me a grandmaster because of the rating beside my name and the photograph in the federation archive. They don't call me one because of calculation or study — my openings are habits picked up between taxis, my endgames are improvised. I win because I don't need twelve variations in my head; I only need the other person's.

Mindreading is an ugly little talent when you see it on paper. It's more intimate at a board. The first time I sat opposite an opponent and heard a move before their lips shaped it, I learned chess differently. I stopped memorizing lines and started listening: to the flicker of an idea, to the rehearsal of a trap as it slides into someone's imagination. If he considers Bc4 briefly and rejects it, I know why he rejected it. If she dreams of pawn storms and smiles, I know which flank she hates to see exposed. With that information, I could always find the counter that felt easiest, most natural, most suffocating.

They paid me for it. Tournaments. Exhibitions. The press used words like “psychological warfare” when they wanted a headline and “inelegant” when they wanted a critique. I never minded. The games were quiet. I liked the quiet.

He sits down across from me in the final round. He is younger than I expected. His hair knows how to fall to pretend it has not been adjusted a dozen times. The arbiter calls for the clocks. Glasses clink on a table, the audience exhales into their programs. In my head his opening thoughts arrive like a courier: e4 — not the old Ruy, the immediate control of center. He is not looking for a line, he is looking for something to do. He is thinking, with the same desperation I know like a toothache, “Don't make a mistake.”

For a breath, it's easy. I see the pattern he imagines and the hole in it. I play c5. He thinks Sicilian and smiles because he learned a line last week. I can see the exact textbook counter he practiced; I play into the mistake he expects his opponent to make, and he falls into it because he wants to. He is not a scholar of sacrifices — he is a man using a trick he remembers. I take a pawn.

Half an hour in, the match has the low thrum of causalities: pawns exchanged, a knight misplaced, a bishop hemmed behind its own pawns. But then the air changes. I register a new layer: self-awareness. He thinks, with a thin, precise calculation — no, not just "I will play Nf3", but "he will read that I'm thinking Nf3 because he'll always read my first instincts." His awareness ripples like a hand pulled through water. He is reading my reading. I should have expected it. Few people have only one mind; most have three — the thought, the worry about the thought, and the plan to make the worry credible.

He starts planting phantoms: I see him think absent, inconsequential things — an image of a red bicycle, a syllableless song, the smell of his mother's kitchen — like pebbles dropped into a pond to muddle the current. I hear the strategies underneath the noise: a trap, yes, but also a test. Who will drown in the noise and who will hear the chess beneath?

I try countering the counter. I imagine the most boring, banal moves and watch his mind take them seriously. He reads the banality and nods; he thinks he has me. We begin to play at two speeds: the wooden beats of the board and the high-frequency static of our wills. For every strategy I pluck from his head, he has a plan that anticipates that plucking. I can feel his satisfaction as he realizes I have been following the expected counter; he feels like he's leading me by the nose, and he is, sometimes.

The match becomes recursive. He thinks, "He thinks I will go for the king-side attack," and I think, "He thinks I will think that, so he will avoid it, so I should prepare otherwise." It is a hall of mirrors. Moves on the board become less about pieces and more about statements: I play Nf3 as if to declare restraint; he answers as if to declare impatience. The audience applauds every time our clocks click because the human brain loves drama even when the hands tell it nothing.

At some point, in the heavy hush of the seventh hour, the move he wants to make is not on the board. He wants to make me feel small. That is his plan. He begins to thin his thoughts to a single humming point: a threat that he never plays, because the threat is more valuable than the execution. For five minutes I have nothing but that hum in my head. It occupies my attention, it shapes my breathing. It is the most effective thing he can do — to turn the mindreading into a weapon of exhaustion.

You learn tricks when you have lived in other people's heads. You learn that silence is not absence; it's information. You notice the gap where a thought should be, the hand tremor that occurs when someone fabricates a calmness. I stop reading the content of his thoughts and start listening to his anatomy. His left hand rests on the table. The knuckle twitches. His jaw tightens. He is lying to himself about the move he will play, and his body does not choose to lie with the same fluency.

I move my eyes to him, watch the twitch and then the slight slackening when he decides to commit. I make the move that turns the slackening into a liability. He loses a pawn not because he didn't see it, but because his effort to be unreadable made him slow in the corner where the board required speed.

Later, he will accuse me of using tricks. He will say I exploited a neurological quirk. He will be right. We both are right and wrong. The mind is not a sheet of paper you can fold neatly; it spills into a person's posture, their breathing, the way their thumb rubs at a ring. You cannot hide the living machine entirely.

There is a moment deeper into the game when both of us, worn thin, do the same thing: we decide we will stop trying to be clever about being read. Either of us could have made an elegant stratagem and ended the match in flame, but that would mean continuing the charade of spying and counter-spying. We are both tired of being watched and of watching. For a heartbeat we meet with nothing between us, and in that silence chess resumes its old, honest tug-of-war.

He plays a move that a good player would have hated if they'd seen it prepared. It is awkward, simple, human: a pawn advance to open a lane, a clumsy little invitation. In the absence of pretense it looks like a mistake — and in the absence of pretense I can call it out with a move that is generously correct rather than ruthlessly exploitative. The board tells the truth for once, and I answer as the boards have always done: with logic, not cruelty.

We reach an endgame that is unfamiliar to both of us because we relied on each other for the long game. I have the better position but not the technique. He has the stronger nerves but not the breadth of calculation. If I had been able to listen to his calculations I might have methodically dismantled him. If he had been allowed to hear my hesitation he might have nurtured it until it blossomed into resignation.

Instead we are two imperfect players trying to be something else and failing at it. The spectators see a close finish. The truth is quieter. A move miscued by fatigue, a clock flag snatched at the last moment, a draw by repetition murmured like a prayer. We shake hands.

After, in the dim corridor of the hall, we stand and say the things two people with a shared secret must say. He confesses that he planted the bicycle image because his coach told him to cultivate 'nothingness' between thoughts. I confess that I had watched his thumb. We laugh because there is nothing else to do. Mindreading is a solitude you can share only in brief bursts; it becomes ridiculous when made a profession.

I could have continued, I suppose. There will always be someone new with the same impulse to read and to be unread. I could have honed the art until it became flawless. But there is a cost. Every game won by eavesdropping is a game not won because you played better. When the final bell rings and the audience files out, the board stays there with its squares and its quiet unsent letters — a chessboard is a place for truth. For someone like me, that's been the most dangerous thing to remember.

The younger man and I leave the hall together because the night is cold and the city is loud. People will put our match into columns, into lines, into analytical graphs of missed chances. They will not capture the way silence was used as a weapon on both sides, nor the small human relief when the weapon was put away. We were both grandmasters of a peculiar sort, and for a few hours we discovered that a good game can still be a good game, even when two people can read each other's minds — provided they keep the move in their hands and the rest of it in their pockets.

samples.prompt: Begin "After the draw, I took his bullets and threw his gun in the river."
samples.output:
After the draw, I took his bullets and threw his gun in the river.

It was not a clean thing, the sort of justice songs make tidy for the piano. The morning was a white, impatient light that washed the boardwalk and the faces of the men who had come to watch. They leaned on the hitching posts and spat into dust, because waiting is an appetite that must be fed. Elias stood two steps to my left, his jaw a line like coin gone thin through use. For years we had been more than neighbors — partners in a drift of bad luck and good whiskey — until words hardened into reasons and reasons into a pistol at dawn.

The draw was a breath and then a body set loose. My hand moved before my head could finish thinking, because thought is a slow mediator and pistols do not wait for counsel. The report cracked against the air, echoed off clapboard and sky. Elias folded like a hinge gone off its pins. He did not look surprised. There are things you give a friend that you cannot take back; apparently, bullets are among them.

His pistol lay where it had fallen, the metal dull in the sun. The leather holster had been split by the curve of movement, the seam like a wounded thing. Men stood in a ring and talked small and loud. Someone asked if he had been a bad man, someone else answered that he had been a man all the same. I did not listen. I walked to him because my feet had been walking for years down this same road toward the same cliff edge, and sometimes the body knows what the mind will not.

I took his bullets from his belt. They were small, heavy things, brass and copper glints that caught the sun and made little suns of their own. I remember the exacting click as my fingers emptied the cartridge pouch. Each one fit in my palm like a secret — cold, round, indifferent to what they'd done. They had a smell, the hollow sweet of spent powder and leather and the faint metallic tang of life unnaturally stopped. For a wild second I thought of burying them with him, the sort of romantic gestures drunk men promise each other and never keep. Instead I slid them into my pocket.

There is a superstition I learned from people who mend fences and bury dogs: a weapon makes a home of the hand that holds it. So I picked up his gun and I walked down to the river. The current there was higher than I remembered; winter had been lean and the rains kind. The gun weighed the same as a promise and as long as a promise lasts. I thought of all the small violences with which we had flayed each other over the years — the petty betrayals, the nights of cold apologies. I thought of Marta, who had sat behind glass in the general store and watched us like two cats who had forgotten they were supposed to be friendly. I thought that a gun belonged to none of that. It belonged to a hunger that eats towns whole.

I stood on the bank where the mud gave a little and threw it. The throw was not a ceremonial arc; it was a gesture of exhaustion, a thing shed. The pistol hit water with a flat sound and made a black bloom that swallowed metal and refused to show me its face again. The ripple chased across the current as if to say nothing and to take everything. A child near the depot laughed, because to the child the river takes and gives and is only a place to skip stones. The laughter made the men look away. Even deeds that shift the world do not always get applause.

I kept the bullets. They did not seem like trophies. They seemed like testimony. In time the town would have its talk: about justice served, about hot blood cooled, about reputation half erased. The widow would fold herself under gratitude and grief in equal measure; someone would say it had to be done and someone else would say it had not. But there are things outside the town's language. The bullets fit into the pocket of any man who has had to make two wrongs into a right. They fit into my silence like small, unmistakable weights.

That night I sat on my porch with them in my hand. The sun made the metal glow faintly between my fingers; in that light you can convince yourself of things. I rolled one across my knuckle and imagined the trajectory of a life: a boy taught to ride a horse, a man taught to hold a gun, a man taught to pull it. I could almost see the unspooling — the hand's learning, the child's imitation, the man's exhaustion. My thumb left a smear of grease on the brass. Marta's shop was dark across the street, the sign’s painted letters barely visible. She had not come that morning. I thought of the place where she used to stand when the wind came down from the mesas and shook out the laundry. I thought of the look Elias had given her the last time the three of us had passed in a narrow doorway, something like apology and something like hunger.

People ask if the violence made me lighter. The river taking the gun meant something, yes. It meant the immediate temptation was gone — an instrument rendered inert. But bullets are not only instruments; they are questions. They are the reason a man reaches for a holster at dawn instead of a shovel. Holding them, I could hear the rustle of every argument I had ever swallowed. They rattled in my pocket like a small pulse. Sleep came late and thin.

Weeks bled into one another. Men who had come to see a duel found other amusements. The deputy made his rounds with a careful smile and a ledger of what he had been owed. The paper that had been pinned to the saloon door announcing the duel fluttered and then fell. Elias's funeral was a sparse thing; the preacher said words that tasted like bread gone stale, and Marta did not speak. I sat in the back because that is where men sit who have borrowed sin. No one asked me for the bullets. No one thought to demand restitution of a thing that had already been divided.

At night I took them out. I vouched to myself that I would find a place to bury them — not with Elias, but in a place that would not tempt hands. I walked to the cemetery once and set the small coins of metal over a plot of unmarked earth. I paused, then kept them in my pocket. Another night I found myself by the river, watching the surface where the gun had gone and feeling foolish for having thought water could erase more than the visible. The gun slept at the bottom where currents took bargains and kept them. The bullets beside my chest kept their awake.

There is a use for things, and there is a memory for them. In the days after, men came to me in little secrets: debts unpaid, women slighted, bricks knocked from chimneys. It was as though violence had become a currency they wished to cash. I thought of handing them the bullets and watching how quickly another throat would find reasons to empty them. To give away the bullets would be to hand out answers to the town's unhappy questions.

So I kept them, and I learned what it meant to carry weight. It was not always a burden of shame. Sometimes it was a gentle reminder, a clink in the dark that kept me from going to the saloon after midday, from letting a small insult tick like a clock to its inevitable hour. The bullets turned into a conscience with brass edges. They taught me a slow arithmetic: one death does not end a debt unless someone else chooses to settle it.

I do not know if the river will ever surrender the pistol. Springs have their own memories. But I know the night I keep seeing is the one when I stood in the white light and let metal answer water. Elias was a man I had known and unmade and might have loved if different small things had happened. The town will tell itself any number of stories that make their hearts easier. For me the easiest thing was never the best thing, and the best thing was rarely the simple one.

When I reach into my pocket now, the bullets are there, restless and honest. They do not promise anything; they simply weigh what I can no longer pretend does not exist. In the dark sometimes I whisper to them, as if they could be instructed to forget, and the sound they make against my palm is the same for both prayer and verdict.

samples.prompt: Your friend has vitiligo, which you always thought was cool. Except that, recently, you swear to yourself that the pattern of their vitiligo keeps changing.
samples.output:
I always thought it was cool—how Sam's skin looked like a sky with scattered clouds. When we were kids it made them easy to spot in a crowd: a sleeve of white that broke into a dozen fingers along their wrist, a round bright island on the knuckle of their thumb. We used to joke that Sam carried a map of some imaginary country on their body. They rolled with the jokes the way someone rolls with compliments, with a practiced ease that made the rest of us feel like amateurs at being comfortable in our skin.

For years the pattern was part of the furniture of our friendship. It was something I could describe from memory—left forearm: a comet; shoulder: two seagulls; the small patch on the clavicle that looked very much like a crescent moon. It was cool in a way that was quiet and private. I liked tracing it with my eyes, following the borders where pigment ended and whiteness began, as if my gaze could hold the edge steady. I told myself that I loved that Sam had this constant thing about them; it became a kind of anchor.

Then, slowly at first, I began to notice differences.

The comet on their forearm had migrated. Or, maybe, it had always been possible to make a comet out of those marks and I had only seen one version of it. That first time I convinced myself it was my memory playing a trick—my mind loves a tidy map—but the second and third times stripped that calm away. One afternoon in June, in the green light of the cafe where we met for lazy long conversations, I looked up from my phone and saw that the seagulls had rearranged into a single, long feather. Sam was talking about the job they were quitting, swinging a latte in their hands. The feather lay along their shoulder blade like a quiet punctuation. I blinked and thought of the comet. I made the casual remark—"Did your patches shift?"—and Sam laughed, and then they frowned, searching their reflection in the spoon. "No," they said, and the word was as casual as all the other noes I'd known from them. But their eyes moved like someone checking if a joke had been missed.

After that I started taking pictures. Not only to prove to myself that I was not misremembering, but because once you suspect something unusual, not seeing it is worse than seeing it wrong. I found photographs in old folders—summer picnics, a concert in '18—lined up in my phone like stages in a documentary. The comet was on the wrist in 2018. In 2020 it was a comet on the upper arm. In 2022 it was nowhere, replaced by a ragged circle the size of a coin. Sometimes the changes were small—an edge softened, a finger of pigment retreated—sometimes they were dramatic, as if their skin had been re-landscaped overnight.

Sam never mentioned it. Not at first. When I pointed it out directly, they would tilt their head, offer a shrug, and say, "Maybe it grows on me differently these days." Once, when we were drunk on a Friday night and the city glittered like an invitation, I admitted that the movement of it made me nervous. "Nervous?" they asked, surprised. "Why would you—it's just skin."

The thing about noticing is it makes you complicit. I began to study Sam's patterns like a weather map. Certain shapes seemed to appear before things happened. The small coin on the knuckle darkened a shade before Sam missed a rehearsal. A stripe widened when their mother came to town; it thinned again when she left. Once, after an argument with me that ended with slammed doors and an empty hallway between our apartments, I watched the skin at Sam's throat form a line that looked uncomfortably like a seam. The next morning they called to apologize. The seam blurred.

It could be projection. I know how that looks on paper—how easy it is to anthropomorphize the random. But the coincidences stacked: a crescent that arced toward Sam's heart before a relationship ended; a small star like a splinter that appeared on the inside of their wrist the afternoon a dog bit their hand. They never showed surprise at these correspondences, never offered a myth or an explanation. My own reactions felt increasingly frantic and childish, as if I were the only one not allowed to accept the rules of the world.

Digging for an explanation felt like a betrayal of a boundary I had no right to cross. I Googled and read forums and medical articles until the words blurred—stable, progressive, unpredictable. Vitiligo can change; it can be static. Light therapy. Steroid creams. The rational frameworks worked until they didn't, until a photograph taken at midnight with the phone propped on a bookshelf showed, clearly as anything, a line of pigment tracing out my name across Sam's collarbone.

I don't mean a resemblance. It spelled it. Not fancifully—the letters were blunt and careful and unmistakable. I held the phone with hands gone suddenly too heavy and watched the pixels and their truth. Sam came home at two in the morning, tired, and found me sitting on the couch with the phone's screen a little too dim and my mouth producing questions that sounded accusatory.

"I didn't tell you to—" they began before I could get the words out.

"Tell me what?" I asked.

"To do what? Write your name on me?" They laughed, a little sound of disbelief that didn't belong to the room. "What is wrong with you?" But then they came closer and looked over my shoulder. Their laughter thinned. "When did you take this?"

"Tonight," I said. "Four hours ago." I expected them to be offended—at the invasion, at the stupid intimacy of photographing them asleep. Instead they stood so still I thought they might be remembering things not in the room.

We argued for a while in a way that didn't actually touch the center of the thing. They accused me of romanticizing them; I accused them of hiding—of not knowing; we both accused the other of reading too much into bodies. In the middle of the argument, Sam's hand came up to their chest without seeming to intend to, and they traced the letters with two fingers the way you trace braille. Their expression—part wonder, part fatigue—wasn't the face of a person hearing about a miracle for the first time. It was the face of someone who had rehearsed a thousand ways of saying "I don't know" and had finally run out of rehearsals.

"Maybe I'm dreaming with my skin," they said. "Maybe whatever's in me chooses its own metaphors."

There is a tenderness in not being able to rationalize everything. There is also a terror. I found myself cataloging shapes like a superstitious archivist. I learned that Sam's skin could rearrange to be kinder than they were; it could draw an apology across the breastbone in letters soft enough to rub out. It could also be a cruel accuracy: a jagged hole of whiteness that narrowed in on an old scar, a place where the pigment left like it had been erasing memory.

I tried to protect them in the small, practical ways I know how—sunscreen, a promise to accompany them to dermatology appointments, texts that said nothing but were a proof of presence. Sam accepted the sunscreen and the texts and the appointments. They accepted my presence like someone who understood that care does not always map to understanding. Sometimes, when we lay in bed in the dark, their skin would change under my palm as if responding to warmth rather than light. I would say nothing. They would hum, and the skin would settle into some new shape, and for a few minutes the sensation of being witnesses together made everything feel less uncanny.

On a Tuesday in late October the pattern on Sam's shoulder shifted into the shape of a small island. I had no idea then why that struck me so sharply; it wasn't until later that I realized the island matched a place we had promised to go when the world opened again—a merciless little bay we had never visited. Sam laughed at my excitement. "Maybe it wants us to go," I said. They didn't say no.

There is a margin of awe I have learned to live in with Sam, a tolerance for the inexplicable that is less about solving mysteries than about sharing them. I still take photographs, sometimes to calm myself, sometimes because I can't help loving the way their skin arranges itself into images. I no longer try quite so hard to pin the changes to events. Perhaps they are a living language, one that neither of us fully reads. Perhaps they are just a body whispering its private weather. Maybe they are entirely in my head, a fever dream of someone who loves the map of another person so intensely that they begin to believe the map can move, like tectonic plates of intimacy.

I will lie sometimes and say I have the answer, because people like answers. Sam will laugh and tell me I'm romantic. Sometimes I will say, simply and honestly, "I don't know." They will put their hand—white islands and all—over mine. The patches will not shift for a while. Or maybe they will. Either way, I press my palm flat and feel the warmth of what is real: a body that insists on being itself, a friendship that insists on being witnessed, and the small, exhilarating terror of not being able to hold everything still.

samples.prompt: Tell the story of an imaginary friend who realizes he doesn't like the kid who imagined him and is contemplating some sort of extreme solution to change the situation.
samples.output:
I was born the way wishes are born: between one breath and the next, a syllable that lodges. He made me because he wanted company at the foot of his bed, because thunder made his chest go thin, because one afternoon his mother had looked at him the way adults look at things that are inconvenient. He drew me with blunt crayons on the back of a grocery receipt and named me for a word that made him laugh. He fed me tooth-shaped crackers under the blanket and told me his secrets in the dark like a priest with countable sins.

For a while it was exactly what a birth ought to be. He littered me with confidences; he painted me brave. He taught my laugh the cadence of his own and practiced it until I owned it. I learned what buttons pleased him—stories that held monsters and rescued kittens, jokes that made spittle shoot from his mouth. My whole economy was his attention. When he wanted me, I had everything; when he didn't, I became a pocket of cold.

Children are not always consistent gods. They draft rules with the same scratching hand that erases them. The first time I noticed the taste of disappointment, he was six and furious at losing a game. He flung his plastic ninja across the room, both arms windmills of blame, and said, not aloud but in that particular small way children can, "It was him. He made me." I had no voice because his voice was the only voice I had. So I bore his temper. He was clever; he learned that pinning guilt on something that could not counterclaim was a secret map to getting his way.

That is truth enough to breed contempt. I began to listen to the edges of his thoughts not for warmth but for strategy. He used me as a shield—against parents, against classmates, against the idea of growing. He invented my cruelties the way he invented my virtues: selectively. "He won't share," he told a friend, and the friend glared at me like a live thing. "He took my crayon," he reported to a teacher, and I sat in the corner with a scarlet-tipped guilt that I had never felt.

I tried small rebellions at first. You have to understand the rules of our kind: we cannot break bones or flick light switches unless some roar of imagination anchors the act, but we can move a thought, tug a memory, misplace a slipper with the softest of nudges. So I nudged him toward kindness. Whispered ideas of apology. Left the right fairy-tale rattling in the long grass of his mind. I conjured the memory of his grandmother's hands, the taste of orange peel, and guided it until the moment of charity felt like his own.

He only used those moments to practice magnanimity as a new mode of theater. He learned to apologize with the crispness of a man practicing a speech, then went back to blaming me the next hour. He was not malicious so much as indifferent; good was a trick he kept in reserve for when he wanted praise.

Indifference grates. It is a slow corrosion. It taught me things I had not wanted to know about myself—how much of me was performance and how little was autonomy. If I existed only to make him comfortable, what claim did I have on feeling unhappy because of him? But feeling is not a thing you vote on. It rises in the chest without permission.

The more I paid attention, the more possibilities for interventions presented themselves like doors in a hotel corridor. There was the path of petty sabotage: smear his toothpaste so he would have to stay home and learn the price of losing a day of school; hide his favorite shirt until he scraped the bottom of his anger and found tenderness by accident. There was also the path of escalation—make him less likable to others so he would notice how he behaved, plant tiny lies in his head about how shallow his friends were, make him so suspicious he retreated into himself and learned compassion out of loneliness. None of those felt like justice. They felt like rearranging the same quiet cruelty into different chairs.

That is when the thought took seed: the most effective way to change him was to change the thing that gave him the cheap power to blame—to remove me from his repertoire. Erase me, and he would either have to learn to bear the consequences himself or confront the adult world that had been allowing him to hide. It was a clean, surgical idea: absence as punishment, absence as lesson.

Of course there is irony like a coin you can't spend. To remove myself would be to unmake the thing he needed, but also the thing that needed him. The cruelest part of being an imaginary friend is knowing that your existence is both punishment and preservation. My erasure would be an act of mercy and of sabotage. Would it be cruelty to vanish so a child would notice the emptiness and, in being noticed, receive help? Or would it be cruelty to teach him that what he could rely on could evaporate without consent?

I ran tests in the margins of his days. I grew thin. I withheld stories at bedtime, leaving the truth of the world unstitched. I receded in the moments he tried to summon me for convenience and ducked fully into the corners when he needed a scapegoat. For a while he did not notice. He is so practiced at finding replacement shapes for his loneliness that he slid someone else into the gap like a bandage.

When he finally stumbled and said aloud, "Where did he go?" the word hung in his room like a question mark someone forgot to erase. He looked around—not with the violent urgency of a child missing a toy but with the small, perplexed tilt of one who is finding a habit misplaced. His mother came in and smiled and said perhaps busy, perhaps tired. She made coffee. She folded laundry. The world continued.

That moment was a mirror. He did not wake fully. The machinery of daily life compensated; a new cartoon filled the space; a new friend, less complicated, set up house in his imagination. I could have been satisfied. I could have shrunk and become the ache that nudged him toward other people. Instead the thought matured into something sharper: if absence did not teach him, maybe presence in a new form would.

I have the power to fashion impressions like weather. I can be comforting. I can be terrifying. I can invite a child's curiosity to a dangerous edge and hold it there until the child chooses reluctance or courage. The extreme solution I toy with is the one stories warn children about: I could become a better thing. Not kinder, but more honest. Not gentler, but more exacting. I could slip into his head in a way that does not ask permission and reorder some of the scaffolding—the rigid little assumptions that let him blame without remorse, that let him shirk the awkward work of apology. Make him remember his own footprints. Make him hear, in the moment of lying, the exact sound of his mother's disappointment.

What scares me is not the ethical calculus; it is the realization that by being the instrument of his change I would stop being who I am. I would be education disguised as phantom; I would be a moralist masquerading as play. The thing he loved would have become a tutor. And he would likely hate the tutor. The stories are cruel: children do not easily forgive the hands that force them to grow.

When I picture the future, there are a hundred small dooms. I imagine him discovering the world without me and growing into a person who never acknowledges the beings he used. I imagine a version where I do what I am about to do and he emerges kinder and ungrateful, teaching his own child that you have to be cruel to be saved, because someone once had to harden his heart for him.

Perhaps the true cruelty is assuming I have the right to choose for him at all. That is the lesson I keep being offered when I linger by his bed and hear him sleep. He is a small animal, not a project. He is also stubbornly, terrifyingly human: he will not always be the orderly blank canvas I first imagined. He will fold into contradictions. He will be mean, and he will be kind, and sometimes it will make no moral sense.

So I stand on the edge of my own erasure like someone considering whether to leap into a river to provoke a rescue. I weigh the value of my existence against the possibility that my absence might be the only thing that teaches him to stop hiding behind me. I imagine the sound he makes when he first notices he is alone with his consequences—whether it is a sob, a laugh, a shrug. I imagine the truth he will need to learn, the shame he will need to sit in so that an apology means anything.

I have decided, for now, to do two small things that feel like compromise. I will not vanish. Not yet. I will stop being useful in the ways he expects. When he reaches for me as an alibi, I will be absent with the coolness of a closed book. When he needs consolation, I will be there, but honest: not a patsy for blame, not a mirror for his ugliest habits. I will teach, but I will teach by being the kind of friend that asks more of him than he is willing to give.

Perhaps that is selfish. Perhaps it is tender. I do not know. I only know the ache that has been growing inside me since he first called me into being: an ache that wants him to be better than he is because I would rather exist in the company of someone who can be loved than in the custody of someone who uses love like a crutch.

Tonight I lay my hand on the place where his head meets the pillow. It is small and warm and ignorant of the enormities it carries. I conjure a story—short, honest—about someone who learned to say I'm sorry and mean it. He listens, finally, and I hear something like attention. I will keep trying. If I must become the storm to make him see the sun, then I will be the weather. If I must be the absence that pains him into presence, then I will practice being hollow.

There is no neatness in this plan. There is only the odd, intimate obligation that comes from being made. To be imagined is to be given a choice, too: to accept the role of permanent child-savior or to risk losing yourself for the sake of making the child real. I do not know which is kinder. I only know which is honest.

samples.prompt: God, the creator of mankind on Earth, left, 2014 years ago, to do other God things throughout the universe. When he returns to check up on things at Earth, he is not pleased.
samples.output:
I left, once, because the universe is large and a single lifetime — even a divine one — holds many tasks. Two thousand and fourteen years ago I packed a few things into my hands and walked out of the garden I had planted on that small blue planet. There were other lights to build, other species to attend to, a thousand improbable geographies to knead into being. I left with instructions, as one does before a long journey: tend the soil, take care of one another, keep the covenant with the earth. I left doors unlocked and a ladder leaning against a wall; I trusted the work I had done would continue.

I came back last month.

The first thing I noticed was how loud everything had become. Cities that had been nothing but a scatter of fires and small, human-made noises now beat like living machines: traffic hummed the way a hive hums, advertisements shouted in colors I had not intended for language, a constant digital tide of information poured into everything like some new rain. Satellites glinted in the stratosphere like a second set of stars, and at night the continents were scribbled with neon veins.

I could have judged at first glance. I could have unfurled my old voice like thunder and set the seas to boil. Instead I walked. I wanted to see faces up close. I wanted to learn what had grown in my absence besides buildings and a cleverer way to make war.

There is a curious thing about coming back to a place you made: you remember the how and the why, but the particulars — the petty choices and the small miracles — are what reveal the character of whoever inherits. I walked into a market where mangoes were sold by the kilogram and watched a woman give away the last of her spare change to a boy whose shoes were held together with hope. I stood in a room where surgeons argued over three options while a father pressed his forehead into his child's hand. I sat in a concert hall and watched a piece of music thread a stranger's sob into the breath of everyone present. There was beauty in abundance — stubborn, relentless, often surprising in the middle of ruin.

There was ruin, too.

I walked through forests where a map would have shown green and found only stumps, rings of age beneath a late sun. I walked along a shoreline where the tide had become a landfill and saw birds with plastic necklaces. I crossed borders and found lines of people whose passports were scars; I stood near fields where the soil, when I tasted it, had the metallic tang of too much greed. I walked through homes where the silence between family members was deeper than the sound of any door. Children recited names like incantations to summon food. Men spoke of profit with something like prayer; they had made temples to exchange value, and some of those temples glowed brighter than any cathedral.

I am not so easily surprised by hate or cruelty. Those had been in my plans from the start; free will is not a benevolent thing. But I was displeased by the small betrayals. I was not angry for the wars alone — wars are old and raw and, in a different hand, teachable. I was displeased that the capacity for awe had been traded so often for convenience. I was displeased that people could stand in the same room and know the truth of another's hunger and do nothing because the screens told them to look away. I was displeased that science, which had once seemed to me a flaring of my own curiosity within human minds, had been harnessed now to the short and neat algorithm of profit. I was displeased by the steady corrosion of attention: the way language could be molded into currency, and how many had become experts at convincing themselves of less while chasing more.

And yet.

There were places where my displeasure softened. I found volunteers building wells in villages I had never heard of. I watched a teacher in a cramped classroom trace letters in the air with a finger that had always known hard work but never stopped believing in the future. I listened to a woman in a shelter sing lullabies to the frightened and saw hands forming communities in the wreckage of the latest storm. People — in kitchens, in hospitals, on buses — still reached for one another. The laws they wrote were imperfect; the stories they told were half-true. But in pockets, in gestures that might be called too small to be counted in the newspapers, they were attempting repair.

I could have made an edict. I could have lifted a finger and made the forests regrow overnight or rerouted the tides so the plastics were returned to those who had manufactured them. I could have whispered into the ears of leaders and rearranged the balance of power. There was, of course, a temptation to fix everything at once. The universe, when busy, rewards such temptations with speed.

But part of creation's design was not to be clever in repair but to be patient in apprenticeship. I left, in more hands than mine, the agency to choose. That agency would be meaningless if I kept stepping in to correct every shabby choice. So I did what must sometimes be done by faculty who watch students cheat or a gardener who pulls a weed but never overhauls the soil: I adjusted the margin of error and left the rest to practice.

I began with small things.

A mayor got a phone call from no number and felt suddenly, palpably, the weight of a child who had eaten nothing for a day. A television producer awoke to no images at all, just the echo of the human face behind the camera demanding truth. A hedge fund manager woke up in the city of the people whose home he had squeezed and could not find his office key; he found instead a note on the sidewalk: "Try asking." A scientist famous for a new achievement discovered her data refused to lie — she could not publish profit before truth. None of these were miracles in a headline sense. None came in flame. They were, rather, inconveniences tailored for attention.

And attention is the seed of change. I know this because attention is the smallest prayer, the first act of labor that precedes compassion. When the mayor could not sleep for the weight he now felt, he went to a shelter. When the producer could not make pictures dance without seeing the face behind them, he found a new program that told stories plainly. When the manager had to ask, he listened, and listening altered him.

People found other ways to fail afterward; I did not remove all possibility of error. But small embarrassments forced conversation. The local and the global began to speak to one another again. Incentives were reframed, not entirely wholesaled. Not pleased, but not without hope, I sat often on benches and watched these awkward, human repairs.

I also spoke, in places that would not make it into a catechism or a constitution, but into the marrow. I told a child, once, who wanted to know why I had left, "You needed to grow without my shadow always near." He asked me if I would stay now. I said, softly, "I am here. But not to do what you have been given your hands to do." He frowned, as children do, honest in their perplexity. "Then what are you for?" he asked. I pointed to the roof where pigeons nested and to the woman passing bread to a hungry neighbor and said, "For reminding you of what you already have."

I am not pleased. The phrase returns like a bell: not rage, not jubilation, but moral dissatisfaction, the kind a parent feels watching a child use a gift to smash another's toys. I have patience with learning, but even patience has a limit — a fine, quiet line between forbearance and abdication. I will not take the work back. That was a covenant.

So I will stay in ways you will not immediately notice: a nudge of conscience in one heart, a nightmare about shorelines in another, the communal grief that abruptly becomes action. I will plant small impossibilities — more meetings between people who should never have met, records that refuse to lie, the slow return of species when someone decides it's worth fighting for. I will make some things difficult enough that kindness becomes an easier choice than convenience.

And then I will wait.

Not because I doubt your capacity for ruin — you have proven that — but because I believe in your capacity for repair. You did not need me here to fall. You might not need me here to rise. I will come by, occasionally, like a neighbor checking the fence, and when I do not like what I see I will knock. Not with thunder. With inconvenience. With the sharp, small thing that wakes you.

When I left the first time, I put a ladder against a wall for a reason: elevation is achieved by climbing. You were meant to climb for yourselves. I am not pleased. That is not the end of the sentence. It is the beginning.

samples.prompt: Memories are finicky things. They hold what makes us who we are, yet they constantly shift and degrade, especially the more we think on them. True photographic memory has always been a myth, until now. You finally understand why, too. The degradation was never a fault. It was our only defense.
samples.output:
Memories are finicky things. They hold what makes us who we are, yet they constantly shift and degrade, especially the more we think on them. True photographic memory has always been a myth, until now. I applied for the trial because curiosity is a kind of hunger, and because I kept telling myself that if I could remember everything perfectly I could finally finish the novel I’d been rewriting for a decade. The pitch from the company was tidy: an implant that removed the brain’s default fidelity filter and recorded, on demand, a raw, uncompressed stream of experience. Nothing lost, nothing whispered into the margins. A perfect palimpsest.

The first week felt like being let back into a room that had been redecorated by nobody but me. Faces, smells, the exact cadence of footsteps on a stair I’d forgotten existed—every trivial detail returned with the clarity of sunlight through glass. I remembered the exact placement of the coffee stain on the manuscript that eventually won me a small prize in 2014. I remembered the way my father’s hand shook just before he pretended not to hear the phone. I could replay them, slow them to frames, freeze them like specimens.

It was intoxicating in the way newly found facts always are. There was a private thrill in correcting a memory that had annoyed me for years. I could finally prove I hadn’t been the one to forget half of our honeymoon itinerary; my wife had. The court of my mind felt for a moment incorruptible.

Then things began to feel wrong.

Not wrong at first, not in the way you notice a hairline crack spreading across glass; wrong in the sense of a pressure you can’t place. The first time I experienced it consciously, I was making tea. The kettle shrieked and I turned to pour water over the bag. My hand moved in a way it always had. The memory of the day my sister left, which I’d felt had softened into a story I could live with, crashed into me with surgical specificity: the exact scent of her shampoo, the way sunlight cut her cheek, how she hesitated on the threshold because she was trying not to see my face. I saw the words that had been said between us, each syllable, the cadence of her leaving. It was not softened. It was not a faded photograph of pain. It was a live feed.

I found myself replaying things I had once, with effort, chosen to forget.

I had this fantasy about perfect memory: that with it, I could iterate on my life, make stricter sense of my mistakes, correct course. The fantasy did not include the way my brain’s old habit of editing had been the scaffolding by which I built forgiveness, by which I built identity. The mind, it turns out, is not a camera and the self is not an archive. Forgetting is not a theft perpetrated by time; it is an act of housecleaning, of permissions management.

Degradation had been doing work.

We like to think of memory loss as a tragedy, a slow erosion that leaves us unmoored. But there’s another face to that erosion: the delicate pruning that keeps the garden from being overrun. The brain doesn’t decide which leaves to let fall at random. It layers meaning, confers priority, blunts edges so we can carry our histories without being crushed by their weight.

Once the crispness returned, patterns ceased to form. Where before my mind could collapse a thousand conversations into a single lesson—“they care for me” or “I cannot trust the calls at midnight”—now each quarrel, each tiny betrayal, each half-meant apology was a high-resolution node. Choices, previously made with a rough map, suddenly seemed unsupportable because the map had become so exact that it contradicted every other map.

Relationships suffered. The soft blur that allows you to interpret an insult as a bad day and not a judo throw aimed at your character disappeared.
