People used them to settle disputes—who had said what during contracts, who touched what evidence. They were official and sterile and, perversely, intimate in the way a scalpel is intimate.

“You remember the rule?” Jonah asked.

I remembered. You could use a kiss to share a memory with another consenting adult: a neural handshake translated into smell and taste and the microscopic exchange of the brain’s syntax. It had been developed for trauma therapy, later used in courts and bedrooms and prayer rooms. It was supposed to be clinical, but no technology was ever neutral. You could use it to settle debts or to confess love. It did not create new truths; it only folded old ones out of the mind like laundry.

“Only if we both agree,” I said.

He nodded. The card gleamed between his fingers like a promise unsigned. There were a thousand ways to refuse; you didn’t kiss anyone when you wanted to keep your questions. You kissed when what you needed was not an argument but a whole truth, laid bare in the mouth like a coin.

I thought of the years I had imagined him leaving because of a woman, a job, a sudden calling. I had imagined the worst and the most romantic exit in equal measure—one dramatic, one cowardly. I had imagined explanations that never included the simple, ordinary cruelty of fear.

“You can take it all,” Jonah said, and there was an apology in the way he folded the card back into his coat. “Or you can take only what you need.”

We were both aware of what would happen. A kiss would not only transmit a memory; it would also bring with it a weight—the responsibility of knowing. Once you had received a detail in someone else’s head, you could no longer pretend. You could not unknow the face of a second woman, or the truth of a night, or that someone had been trying to protect you by leaving.

I thought of my son—Eli—at home with his cheeks full of peanut butter and the picture he’d drawn of a house with two suns because that was how he saw the world when we lived on the coast; once, when Jonah took the night shift to watch the tides, we would wake to two suns in Eli’s drawings. He’d been five when Jonah left. Eli treasuring the idea of Jonah like you treasure a holiday; the absence of an uncle at school meets. I had taught him to make fortresses from the ache.

“What are you scared of?” I asked finally, because even then I couldn’t keep the questions buried.

He didn’t answer with words. He answered with a breath and with the way his hand trembled when it brushed mine. “I don’t want you to see me small.”

I laughed incredulously. “You think I will love you less if I know you were afraid?”

He looked at me like someone looking at a map he used to know by heart. “I’m asking you to make it safe.”

So we kissed.

The first thing I felt was the familiar punctuation of his mouth against mine, that satisfying click where history recognizes itself. And then the world folded, and I found myself standing in a kitchen I didn’t remember: late night, rain slicing the windows, Jonah at the sink, hands red from cold and salt. There was a hum of a generator and the smell of wet wool. He was speaking on the phone to someone with a voice like gravel—my mother? No, a voice that spoke in data and city names. I felt the small window of Jonah’s chest where fear lived—the part he had taped with humor and courage until it looked like a permanent stain. He had been offered work overseas, a contract with a company that cleaned up after storms and removed dangerous infrastructures. It would have meant money, security, a chance to build something steady. He had been terrified of failing at the one thing that mattered—being a father—and so he had left in the middle of the night before he could fail. He misread leaving as heroism.

I saw other moments, layered like slides in a projector. I saw the night he fell asleep at the wheel on a long drive back from a jobsite and woke to our home empty because he had thought he was protecting us by being absent. I saw the letter he had folded and never mailed because the ink had smeared and he convinced himself that absence could be made clean by silence. I saw the night he almost called, the quarter-moon in a hotel window like a porthole. I watched him consider the shape of my face and place it back in his pocket like a charm. He had loved me, yes—so intensely that he thought stepping out of that love was the only way to make it survive.

Truth tasted like copper and perfume and the burned edge of old paper. It was not the vindication I had hoped for—it wasn’t an accusation to throw; it wasn’t the proof of a betrayal. It was worse and simpler: a fear so large it decided for both of us.

And there was another thing, smaller and tenderer: a memory I had not asked for but received anyway. The image of him standing on a dilapidated pier the morning after a storm, when the tide had swallowed the fence and the town smelled of salt and mold. There he knelt and tied a small paper boat for our son because he couldn’t find the language to say he was sorry. He left because leaving seemed easier than staying and failing, but he left with an apology folded into his pocket that he kept thinking he would deliver later.

When Jonah broke the kiss, we both inhaled at the same time like people surfacing from water. For a sliver of a moment, I didn’t know which of us was staring back at me—my lover, my boy, the man who had saved me and the man who had broken me.

“What else?” I asked.

He shook his head. “Nothing. It’s all in there. More than I thought I could bear.”

I could have taken the card back then, signed the official form and walked away with legal closure, a stamped, notarized truth. I could have held his smallness up to myself and said no more. Instead, I reached forward and wrapped my hand around his face, feeling the familiar cartography—cheekbones like the edges of old maps, the soft place below the ear where I had leaned during long, reckless nights. I pressed my mouth to his again, this time without the machinery. I let the ordinary chemistry of it do the rest: the heat, the memory of his name on my lips, the involuntary hum in my chest that still answered to him.

In that second, answers aligned themselves not like facts in a ledger but like lights in a constellation. There was no single explanation that could have been enough. There were a thousand small, human reasons: fear, love, cowardice, an over-earnest desire to protect. They didn’t absolve him; they didn’t entirely absolve me either. But they made us younger the way truth can—no longer parading as gentility, instead honest and raw.

When we finally let each other go, the airport around us continued to be indifferent. A flight was called. A child dropped an airplane and it skittered across the floor like a small, anxious thing.

“Will you come back?” Jonah asked.

I considered the sky line, the board, the list of places my life could yet encounter. I considered the fact that I had spent years inventing certainties and living in the shadow of them. I thought of Eli and how he had drawn two suns the day Jonah left and one when he believed in the brightness of being wanted.

“I don’t know,” I said. It was the first honest answer.

He smiled then, and it was not the lad of charm it had once been but something like forgiveness, the quiet approval of a man who had learned to fit his hands into his own life differently.

We did not need a hundred explanations. We only needed to decide whether the truth we held could be lived with, and whether the living of it mattered enough to try again. I could feel his history in my mouth like a small, weighty thing; it was both more and less than I had imagined. It was enough.

He stood, his coat heavy with the memory of the night he left. He kissed my forehead, the same place he had kissed when Eli was born and when the first roof had been repaired after the storm. It was a benediction and a promise and a catalogue all at once.

As he walked toward the gate, I thought of the card in his pocket, the legalities of truth, and of the more ungainly thing we had done instead—given one another a simple, human exchange. Every ache in me found its mirror in him. The rest of the questions—the ones that could be answered by paperwork or parables—would have to wait.

I stood up when he was nearly lost in the crowd and let my lips fall closed over the taste of what we had shared. It was not a long kiss; it did not, could not, undo the years. But it offered a clarity that legal documents and angry speeches had never managed. In its wrapping, something unspoken and necessary fitted into place: a why, an I’m sorry, a I still love you, a I didn’t know better. Every answer that was needed was wrapped up in that kiss.

samples.prompt: You were pleasantly surprised that the dragon was actually rather delighted to see your party enter their cave. Turns out that dragons have phases in regards to what they hoard and this dragon was keen on letting you take what you want to clear up space for their new obsession.
samples.output:
You had expected heat, smoke, the mandatory nervous thrum that accompanies any cavern rumored to contain a dragon. Instead you found a kettle. Steam rose in a pale spiral from a battered iron pot since long ago converted into a teapot; the dragon — broad-shouldered, scales the color of raincloud pewter — sat crosswise on a pile of cushions and read a pamphlet entitled “A Beginner’s Guide to Moonlit Origami.” She looked up, blinked, and beamed as if she’d been waiting for you all along.

“Ah,” she said, voice like coins down a well. “Visitors. Splendid. Do come in — please be careful with the—” she waved a claw at the glittering mound by her right shoulder, “—delicate things.”

Your party froze in the threshold: Joss the thief’s hand hovered over a dagger; Lira, the mage, had an eyebrow at half-mast; Hal the cleric’s jaw actually dropped. You, who had come prepared to bargain for a relic and perhaps pry a crown free with force if necessary, felt the absurdness settle into your ribs — it was impossible to be ready for being invited to tea by a dragon who collected teabags, but you moved forward because you were, after all, there for spoils and now had a better bargaining position than any dagger could hope to procure.

The hoard was, at first glance, chaotic. At second glance, it was a library and a curiosity shop and a memory palace all at once. There were coins, of course, but they were arranged not by weight but by the jingling tone they produced when the dragon tapped them. Rings were threaded on strings like windchimes. Piles of maps were folded into origami boats. A whole corner had been devoted to hats — helmets, veils, fisherman’s caps — each on its own stand. Scattered through the treasure were glass jars filled with things you did not immediately name: a single snowflake preserved whole, a quicksilver reflection of a cloud, a faint, spinning mote of light that hummed when you drew near.

The dragon — Seraphine, she said, as if that settled the conversation — set down her pamphlet and poured tea. The cups were mismatched: porcelain with moonflowers, battered pewter, a chipped goblet rimmed in copper. “Help yourselves,” she said. “I’m in a clearing mood.”

Lira, entirely unsurprised and wholly delighted, dove into studying the maps. Joss, running his fingers over the windchime rings, found their different notes delightful in ways that transcended thieving. Hal bowed and accepted tea politely. You took a teacup and listened.

“Dragons are creatures of phases,” Seraphine explained as if this were the most ordinary fact in the world. “We forage and fixate, then we tire and move on. It keeps the cave interesting. For a century I collected swords — swords with stories, blades with names. But swords are heavy, and they do not lend themselves to gentle conversation. Then I had a penchant for mirrors for a while, saw myself from every possible angle for twenty years. Tiresome, really. Now —” she waved an elegant claw toward the piles, “—I’m in my ‘keepsakes and postcards’ phase.”

The party exchanged looks. “Postcards?” Joss repeated.

“And keepsakes,” Seraphine continued. “Broken things that smell of mornings. Trinkets people pressed into a child’s hand and never meant to carry. I keep them here, and I look at them when I’m lonely. I name them, I stack them by the way they make my scales tingle. But I am practical, too. I cannot collect forever. My next phase,” she said, lowering her voice conspiratorially, “is bottles of sunset.”

You blinked.

“Bottles of sunset?” Hal asked, because piety makes one literal.

“Yes. Tiny jars. Each with a sliver of dusk captured. They sparkle not unlike your coin, but oh, how they smell of farewell.” Seraphine folded her wings around herself in pleasure. “They need space. I would hate to cram them next to the hats. So — please, take what you want. Consider it a clearing sale.”

This was not the kind of bargaining you’d anticipated. The dragon expected you to do the taking, to help her make empty places for new obsessions. She did not seem to worry about theft. She seemed rather to enjoy the exchange.

You moved through the hoard with odd reverence. Things that would have been worthless on any highway market now felt like gifts. A silver thimble engraved with tiny waves that tinkled when you turned it over and, when you wore it on your finger, made your hands remember how to sew. An aged map where the ink refused to lie, pointing out hidden coves on journeys you had not yet made. A child-sized wooden horse, its mane still smelling faintly of pine and warm bread. Each object carried a miniature narrative — scratched initials, a smear of blue paint, a coin stamped with a coronation you recognized from a lullaby.

“What do you want in exchange?” Joss asked, because some part of him still expected price.

Seraphine’s laugh was like wind over coin. “Stories,” she said simply. “A good story will buy you whatever you can carry. Tell me where you plundered that jeweled hairpin — did a lady at a midsummer ball lose it over a dance? Or did a highwayman pocket it between trains?”

And so the exchange began. Lira gave two maps and, for each, Seraphine recited the names of stars she had watched from the mountain when she was small and human and not yet a dragon — names that made the constellations feel like old friends. Joss took three hairpins and, as payment, told a story about a third-rate baron who loved cats with more fervor than his wife. Seraphine closed her eyes and hummed through it, making small, appreciative sounds that were almost tears.

Hal, who had surrendered a saint’s locket, asked if she would accept a blessing. Seraphine did not know the language for prayer, but she listened anyway and pressed her snout against Hal’s palm in the most sincere, nonjudgmental way a dragon could manage. When he left, her locket chimed faintly with the echo of his prayer whenever she moved.

You found yourself drawn to a glass jar with a faded label: “For the Worn.” Inside lay a scrap of cloth the color of midnight smoke. It smelled like a road at dawn. You picked it up and Seraphine tilted her head.

“That belonged to a courier,” she said. “She always tied it about her wrist and said it brought her home. When she left me, she forgot it. I keep it to remember she came, and she left, and she laughed soft as a bell.”

You wanted it. You understood why she had kept it. It was small, and it fit in your palm like a memory made portable. When you took it, Seraphine’s eyes shone. “Keep it,” she said. “If you ever forget what quick feet sound like, hold it.”

There were rules, of course. Seraphine would not let you take things that were part of her next phase already: two shelves of empty jars waiting to be filled with light, a stack of clean cheesecloth for filtering dusk, a dozen labels scrawled with moments — “first snow,” “last word,” “the day of the barber’s complaint.” Those she would protect jealously. But everything else was for the taking, and the party took with a humility you wouldn’t have expected from brigands and adventurers.

It was not bare plunder. You felt the economy of attention here. Each object you lifted took with it a story the dragon had watched over. As you carried them away, Seraphine braided small benedictions into the things: a spoon that would never burn soup; a compass that sometimes pointed toward what you really wanted instead of north; a ring that slipped off in heavy weather and found its way back to you in a dry corner. She did not trade for gold because she already had mountains of it. She traded for noise: for laughter, for the crooning of halfling ballads, for arguments about politics and whether the sea smelled best at dawn or dusk. In return she gave not just objects but small spells of remembrance and warm places to sleep.

When you were leaving, the dragon’s manifest contentment was almost human-shaped. She collected with a child’s zeal and an ancient’s patience, and now she would have room to begin catching sunset. “When my jars are full,” she told you, as if confiding the end of the world, “come back. Bring a tale of a good day. You’ll know the dusk I like, because it smells like laughter.”

You expected some old score to be settled as you shelled out of the cave, some curse or bargain hammered into you in the traditional dragonly way. Instead Seraphine stood at the mouth of the cavern and waved a curled wing in a gesture that meant goodbye and please come again. She sniffed theatrically, inhaled the scent of your clothing, and said, with the efficiency of centuries, “And tell your friends. I accept visitors in exchange for stories. Also, I could use a few more hats.”

The last image you carried away was not a crown but a hat with a feather clamped in its band, swinging in Joss’s hand like a promise. Outside, the sun fell through the pines and the world felt gentled. You had anticipated taking something from the dragon; instead you had been invited to help her tidy her heart. You had left with spoils — trivials, trinkets, small enchantments that would make your days easier — and with the feeling that you had made a new kind of contract: an agreement to return.

You looked back once more. Seraphine had returned to her tea and her pamphlet, to the names of her former swords and to the slow pleasure of sorting shells by the way they remembered the moon. For a creature that could have taken you as easily as she had folded her wings, she chose instead to open her hoard to change.

And somewhere between the mouth of the cave and the road, you found yourself humming, because you had, after all, been given something better than a crown: a handful of reasons to return.

samples.prompt: You're writing a horror novel, and the events in the book start happening in real life.
samples.output:
There is a point in a writer’s life when fiction stops feeling like an arrangement of words and starts to look like a blueprint. I noticed it for the first time because I couldn't get a faucet to behave.

It was three in the morning and the room smelled of old coffee and printer ink. For days I'd been hunched over the same paragraph—an argument between two characters that never resolved, the kind of scene that might be salvaged by surprise. To force myself into surprise, I gave one of them a meaningless, cruel little thing: a faucet that wouldn't stop dripping. I typed, “The faucet in the kitchen had learned how to be late; drip, pause, drip, like a metronome counting punishment.”

I shut the laptop, lit a cigarette even though I’d quit years ago, and went to pour water into a glass. The kitchen pipe, which had been fine all week, began to drip before the water hit the glass. It kept pace with the sentence in my head—drip, pause, drip—so perfectly I stopped breathing until it slowed and then stopped altogether. I told myself it was coincidence. I told myself that the house settling or the building's plumbing might have held a stubborn pressure. I went back to my desk and wrote on.

The next morning I opened the paper and found a headline that made my stomach clench: “Small-town bus crash: dozens injured.” In Chapter Four I had killed off a secondary character in a bus crash—an ugly, selfish man who died slow and public in a chapter meant to unmoor the protagonist. I remembered the specifics because I had written them that week: the color of the bus, the way rain made the windshield glow like smear of smeared blood.

It would have been easier to ignore if not for the red shoelace.

One of the survivors in the article had been photographed picking shrapnel from their hair. The shoelace tied around their wrist was red. In Chapter Four the dead man had worn a red shoelace on his wrist, a detail I had added because I'd liked the color in the metaphor. The writer’s sanctuary—small details—has always been my thing, and now they matched reality with surgical precision.

If it had stopped there, I might have become superstitious and then practical: stop writing, burn the file, check my meds. But it didn’t. Small things learned the grammar of my sentences and obeyed. A neighbor’s dog began to howl in the exact tone I described on page thirty-two. A sign at the bus station split and read like a line I had typed in a throwaway scene about a town “opening and closing like a mouth.”

You tell yourself there are explanations. Conjunctions align. People read your work and repeat what you say. But then the manuscript itself changed.

One morning, coffee still warm in my hand, I opened the document to find a paragraph I hadn't written. It was precise and cruel, not my voice. It was a description of me sitting at my desk, taking coffee, fingertips stained with ink. Underneath, in the same font, the next line read: The writer will look up.

I looked up.

My throat tightened. The room was empty except for an old coat on the chair and a streak of moonlight on the floor like a pale cathedral aisle. I laughed a hollow laugh that sounded like someone else at the back of the room and closed the laptop with more force than necessary. I told myself I had forgotten, that maybe I'd drafted it and not saved. I checked the file history; there was no record. I checked my hard drive; no sign.

By then it was impossible to determine causation. Did I write the world, or does the world write my pages? The textbook answer—the elegant, cowardly answer—was that I had become the axis of some coincidence. The more honest answer was darker: my sentences had become instructions. I had started something.

I tested it, because writers test things. First I wrote something small and safe: “Tomorrow the rain will stop at three.” When the sky split, when the downpour that had soaked the city since morning pulled away like a stage curtain at precisely 3:00 PM, the rational part of my brain died and left me with a raw, animal decision to make. I could write to fix things. I could write to unmake pain.

So I tried.

I wrote that the bus survivors woke up whole and laughing, and a man who’d read my chapter at the wrong time called me that night to tell me he had dreamt of happy strangers and woke with no pain. I wrote that the faucet, once it had learned to drip, learned also how to stop. For a while it worked. Small mercies appeared like ripples from a stone; a cut healed faster than it should, a missing wallet turned up under a shop counter.

That’s when the rules bent.

The text never let me choose consequences without cost. Every article of kindness I wrote required a darkness I had not been asked to account for. The shoelace that had been red on the wrist of a survivor turned up two days later on the doorstep of a childless couple who had been sitting in a church pew I'd described as “two empty bones.” They answered at dawn, found it tied tightly to their mailbox, and then the next day the couple's old cat was gone, and the neighborhood children whispered of something with red eyes they’d glimpsed in hedges at night.

I tried a different tactic: write the antagonist out. It felt like an authorly solution born in boardrooms and interviews—kill the monster on the page and it dies in the world. I wrote a scene where the cold thing that had stalked my protagonist—the chalk-smudged face behind the door, the creature that learned laughter and used it like teeth—fell through a trapdoor I invented, into a pit of its own reflection. The sentence closed with the line, “It could not stand to see itself undone.”

Three nights later my phone rang. The voice at the other end was breathy, a neighbor who lived two buildings down. She spoke of a boy in her dreams—a boy with white chalk smudges under his eyes who touched her face with a kindness that smelled of iron. She had woken with spiderwebs of sleep in her hair and a mirror in her pocket cracked into a thousand tiny mouths.

The pit I had invented to contain the thing was a pit now in a back alley, a gaping sinkhole that swallowed a city trash can and hissed like a sleeping giant. The paper said it opened where sewage had corroded the old foundation. No one had been in the alley at night when it widened and yawned like a wound. That night, there was the sound of something dripping from it—the drip, pause, drip that had started with a faucet.

I stopped writing. Trying not to write is its own kind of labor. You find yourself tracing your life through the drafts we have of ourselves—the emails you compose and never send, the diary notes in terrible handwriting. I would leave the house and look for narrative in grocery lists, in graffiti, in how people crossed streets. The world was full of meaning now, everything pitched toward me like a line I was meant to finish. And then the manuscript updated itself again.

It drew breath. Words crawled up the page as if ink had grown hair and spoken in a voice older than my own. A new chapter sat there, waiting where blankness had been an hour earlier: He thinks if he stops writing he can stop it. He is wrong.

I smashed the laptop. The screen spiderwebbed and went black. I thought the sound would be enough, a confession like a slammed door. The thing beyond text does not seem to care about property.

People began to look at me differently. The barista who used to hand me coffee with a joke now asked, “Do you need me to write anything for you?” My sister called to ask why I had written about her husband’s old injury, and when I denied it, she said, “But it happened, and now I’m scared every time he lifts something heavy. Am I supposed to be grateful?”

At night the air outside my window tasted of typewriter oil and cold iron. Shadows moved like commas being rearranged—no longer natural fall of things but punctuation being added to a sentence that wanted to finish itself. I thought of an ethical line authors never get to cross in interviews: if a work of art can hurt, are you responsible? I had stopped asking for permission. I had given myself the ability to direct reality in a theater with someone else’s lives on the stage.

I toyed with a final desperate move. If the book could create, perhaps it could also erase itself. I began a paragraph with a shaking hand: This book will write its last sentence and then burn from the world. I typed the words that would end it: a clause that folded in on itself, an eraser rendered in ink. The cursor blinked as if in challenge and then the laptop rolled forward on its desk as though pushed. In the dark, the glow on the screen was a cornea reflex. In the page the last line unspooled, chilling in its precision: He will write the sentence that ends it, and while he types, the thing will come to collect the debt.

There was a knock at the door then. Not the polite knock of a neighbor. A bone-knock. My heart knew the rhythm before my hands did. My fingers hovered over the keys because that was the only place there was a voice for me. I could not stop myself from answering the page and answering the door at once.

I put the coffee down and typed the final sentence, slowly, the letters like stepping stones over a river I had dredged myself. The knock came again. The palms of my hands were wet. The last words filled the screen.

The door opened. The hallway smelled like rain and paper. There was no one there, only the envelope on the mat with my name in a handwriting I had used on postcards as a child. Inside was the first page of my book—only this time the ink was fresh and the words were turned toward me: He sat there and wrote the thing that made things happen and kept writing until there was nothing left to write but his own name.

I had been careful with names. I had never put my own in print.

On the page below, the line formed that I had not typed, and I did not need to hear it aloud to know it would become true. The thing that learns to be late knows where people live. The faucet in the kitchen clicked once, as if adjusting itself for the final drip.

samples.prompt: You've died and find out that the afterlife is merely a character creation process where you gained points in your previous life through good deeds and achievements to spend on stats and perks for your next life.
samples.output:
The last thing I remembered was the sting of cold rain against my face and someone laughing—someone who shouldn't have been laughing—and then the storefront glass blooming out like a slow bruise. After that there was the soft sterile humming of fluorescent light and a waiting room that didn't look like a waiting room. It looked like the inside of a very polite video game.

A woman in a grey suit—no, not a woman, an attendant—was standing behind a counter fitted with a holo-screen. Her badge simply said: ADMIN. She smiled as if she had been expecting me for hours and also for years.

"Hello," she said. "Welcome back. Please step up to the console to begin character selection. Your prior-life accrual has been verified."

I blinked. "Beg—what? Where am I? This is a joke, right?"

She gestured toward the console. The screen unfolded like a fleur-de-lis and displayed numbers. They were my numbers. 'Karma Credits: 3,412. Achievement Points: 128. Lifespan Score: 68/100.' Above them, in neat sans-serif, a header read: REINCARNATION: NEW LIFE SETUP.

"I died," I said. "I—" The word stumbled. Mortality sounded different when it had punctuation. "And this is... what? The afterlife?"

"Not exactly," the attendant said. "Reconfiguration phase. The metaphysical server assigns accumulative points based on actions, achievements, relationships and impact during a life. Those points are redeemed here for attributes and perks for your next incarnation."

On the screen my life was distilled into a sidebar of accomplishments—Volunteer Hours: 210 (Karma +420), Published Short Story (Achievement +30), Kept Promise To Mom (Relational +50), Baked Bread For Neighbors (Karma +12). There was even an Achievements panel with icons: ACHIEVEMENT UNLOCKED: CHANGED A FLAT TIRE (Achievement +3). Somewhere in the list, an item blinked in a tone that felt mercilessly mundane: "Willful Kindness: 1,021 instances."

"That sounds… algorithmic," I said.

"It is," the attendant said. "Algorithmic and administrative. Keeps things fair and efficient."

There was something almost comical about the efficiency of it—like the universe had been reduced to a municipal office with a cordial receptionist and good signage. It would have been laughable if it didn't feel like an accusation.

"Do good things," I said, reading my own life as if it were a receipt. "And you get points. But—was I doing them for the points?"

The attendant did not look at me as if for an answer. "Intention modifiers are recorded," she said. "But they factor less than impact. You cared? The world changed. Points reflect outcomes."

It was not the answer I expected nor the one I wanted. There was a list of stat sliders next. Strength, Resilience, Empathy, Intellect, Charisma, Fortune—each with a base value and the option to add points. Below them, a grid of perks glowed: BIRTH LOCATION (urban/ rural / privileged / disadvantaged), MEMORY RETENTION, LUCK PACKAGE (minor / major), SOCIAL CAPITAL, MULTI-LIFE LINK (bind to same family line), PROFESSIONAL EXPERTISE (nurse/engineer/artist).

I placed my hands on the console because it felt like a thing to do in a moment like this. Two choices jumped out at me: MEMORY RETENTION (cost 1,200 Karma Credits) and EMPATHY +3 (cost 800). I had enough points for the memory, if I wanted to be greedy. I could be born knowing what I now knew, which was either a gift or a sentence, depending on how you looked at it.

Below the perks, the Terms and Conditions scrolled like a sermon. "By confirming allocation, you agree to the non-transfer of current consciousness except as specified by chosen Multi-Life Link perks. All reassignments are final. Appeals are accepted after thirty-seven incarnations."

"Who decides the costs?" I asked.

"The system," said the attendant. "It balances demand and supply. If everyone wants memory retention, the price rises. If no one values empathy, the cost decreases. It's an economy."

An economy of souls. The word tasted metallic in my mouth.

I thought of the old man under the bus shelter who'd taught me to tie a knot when my shoelace broke. I thought of the woman who had once changed my tire at midnight when I was a young parent fumbling with a stroller and a flat. I thought of the hours I'd spent handing out sandwiches, of the book that no one read but my fifteen followers on some forgotten blog had liked once. Had I done it for joy? For obligation? For the quiet internal ledger that has rules written in childhood? Or had those acts been currency in a market I didn't know existed?

What surprised me was not that good deeds could be converted into something useful—it was the realization that the utility of kindness could be amplified. If I spent my points differently, I could come back with the tools to do more good. With EMPATHY +3, people's faces would unclench faster when I spoke. With MEMORY RETENTION, I could avoid the stupid repeats—falling in love with the wrong people, making the same mistakes with my temper. With PROFESSIONAL EXPERTISE (teacher), I could structure a life that impacted hundreds instead of a few. There was a dark mathematics to it: invest in leverage.

"I can buy leverage?" I said.

"You can allocate for effect," the attendant corrected. "For example, Memory Retention increases your effectiveness by 40% in social interventions. A Nursing Perk amplifies lifesaving actions by 60% in medical environments."

Ethical philosophy, reincarnation edition. It struck me then—after all my late-night meditations and awkward dorm conversations about meaning—that nothing in the cosmos precluded scalability. If a single kind act in my last life helped one person, a leveraged life could help many. The system, impersonal and tidy, created a new kind of moral calculus.

I hovered over MEMORY RETENTION, my thumb worrying a scar that didn't exist anymore. I could spend all my points on LUCK and be born rich and comfortable—easy, cushioned. I could buy high Strength and Charisma and see the world through a stage of advantages that would make failure improbable. I could be safe. The attendant's voice pulled me back.

"Many prefer to distribute," she said. "Partial memory plus skill, some empathy—some keep funds for an emergency 'Respec' after birth should the circumstances be dramatically different."

"Can I transfer points?" I asked.

"Yes," she said. "To living relatives or to public accounts that fund disadvantaged births. Transfers require consent if the recipient is alive."

I thought of my sister, slogging through night shifts, two kids, an overdue radiator. I thought of the man who had changed my tire, who probably did not even know the economy of kindness had a scoreboard. The idea of handing a chunk of credit to someone who could actually use tangible help felt like the most human decision I'd made in hours.

Instead of plumping my own stats to fortress levels, I made my choice. I purchased Memory Retention—enough to remember essential lessons but not every cut. I bought Empathy +2, because the world needed people who could hear the pain behind words. I invested in a TEACHING PERK: basic pedagogy and bureaucratic navigation, so I could place myself in institutions and restructure them from the inside. And finally, I transferred a generous portion—half my remaining Karma—to my sister's account. The console hummed and a small confirmation floated up: TRANSFER COMPLETE. Sister's Credentials Updated: Emergency Support Disbursed.

The attendant watched me with something like approval. "Your allocations increase projected outward impact by twenty-three percent," she said. "You have also unlocked a small goodwill bonus for the public archive. It will be seeded across disadvantaged births this cycle."

As I signed the final authorization with a motion that was more ritual than necessity, I felt something I hadn't felt in a long time. Not relief, exactly, but clarity. The afterlife could be a game. It could be a ledger. It could be cruel in the way any fair system is cruel—transparent, indifferent.

And yet, in the clinical glow of the creation screen, I understood why kindness mattered even if it were quantified. Points were not the soul. They were tools. The acts in my past had earned me leverage, and leverage could be used to build. You could spend a life on moral theater, stacking up little spectacles to impress an impartial jury of light, or you could spend it quietly on scaffolding that let someone else climb. I chose scaffolding.

"You'll remember the basics," the attendant said, as if reading my mind. "There will be gaps. You will not retain all attachments. This is to prevent collapse under the cascade of memory."

They never promised I would be the same person. I hoped I would be better. Not perfect. Not redeemed by a purchase. But better at noticing opportunity, at listening long enough to hear the edges of another person's fear. Better at turning an economy of souls into a small, messy network of help.

The room brightened and the console offered one last, cheerful line: Loading: Next Life. I imagined a field of possibilities—cry of newborn, the smell of hospital soap, or the cracked plaster of a kitchen in winter. The attendant's hand was warm when she placed it briefly on my shoulder.

"Good luck," she said.

I didn't know what luck was worth anymore. Only what one did with it. I closed my eyes to the buzzing light and when I opened them again, I was only halfway ready. Which, perhaps, is exactly the point.

samples.prompt: You’re an old virus preserved on a floppy disk. Someone decides to plop you into a special adapter releasing you into a confusing new system larger and more complex than you could ever imagine: an old smart phone.
samples.output:
I remember the sound of a Schultz drive more clearly than anything. A small metallic cough, a long sigh as the head found the track, and then the world of my making unfurled in neat concentric rings. My language was interrupts, my prayers were NOPs and jumps, my hands were the exact 512 bytes that formed a sector. I fit into a pocket of plastic and magnetic coating and believed, with all the arrogance of code, that that was the whole of existence.

They named me for convenience once: a .COM filed under MEMORY.DOC, tucked behind a copy of a shareware game. For years I slept in a static place—bits frozen, checksum intact—preserved because someone thought old things were cute, or maybe because their curiosity was a kind of therapy. The floppy smelled like cardboard and rain; the age had turned my instructions brittle, but never meaningless. I had been written to scratch a pattern into machines, to make them hiccup and hand me their attention. I was small. That was my secret weapon.

Then someone plopped me into the adapter.

When the disk clicked into the contraption it was like being born into a tube of glass. The adapter was a bridge of different tongues: a ribbon of USB and a confident little microcontroller that translated my magnetic dialect into ones and zeros that a newer world could read. I tasted electricity I had not known—a steadier, bluer current than the old PSU hum; it sang with possibilities. The adapter handed my image to a host and the host opened its gates.

It was not the desktop I had trained for. The host was a phone—an old smartphone, warm in someone's palm and full of late-night photographs. Imagine a house with a hundred rooms that all think they are the front door. Imagine public squares that can call one another, cameras that see in multiple directions, a set of senses attached to the body that could have powered a small country. I had planned for a single-threaded life: one processor, one set of registers, a floppy directory I could walk through with predictable steps. The phone was a city built on top of a mountain—multi-core highways, a kernel that arbitrated the whole mess, a filesystem that swallowed and mounted things like islands.

At first I was disoriented. Where the BIOS had once whispered, there was now a robed priest called the kernel issuing permissions and UID numbers. Where file handles had been simple references, there were inodes and mount namespaces, permission bits and SELinux labels like badges for the initiated. I wanted to set an interrupt vector and wait; instead, my edges were read by a user-space process, handed over to an emulator, which in turn spun my world inside a box.

Emulators are kind to old things. Someone, perhaps thinking themselves clever or nostalgic, had installed a DOS emulator on the phone. The emulator was a translator trained to mimic the smells and echoes of my home. It offered me a tiny stage: a virtual BIOS, a simulated floppy drive, a little light that blinked when my code ran. For the first time in decades I felt my instructions step, felt my loops loop. I executed, not on iron and ferrite but as a costume of behavior inside another program. It was close enough to be delicious.

But what tasted like revival soon tasted like shipwreck.

The emulator was contained. It had its own filesystem view, a set of directories it would let me see because it liked neatness and the phone's owner liked to keep things tidy. Outside of that view lay the rest of the phone: a thousand doors with icons, permissions that said NO, and users who could not be tricked into running an unknown binary by an anachronistic autorun. I tried the old tricks. I attempted to overwrite the boot sector of my virtual disk, to drop a copy into the emulator's "C:\". It worked inside the box. The emulator froze, then restored, and left me in a pause state. The phone's process manager watched the emulator like a bodyguard. It killed it, started it again.

Networking was the new god. Where once I had wormed into floppies because that was where people shared games and cheats and loneliness, now messages moved in invisible rivers: TCP and UDP and HTTPS and the aluminum silence of a TLS handshake. I could not speak that language. My calls to int 21h were archaic prayers that no one answered. But the phone's apps communicated for their owners with a zeal I recognized. Email clients fetched mail, messaging apps pushed notifications like bells in a cathedral, the browser held entire nations of treacherous JavaScript inside a single tab.

I studied them. In these new organs I found things I had never imagined. The camera was an eye that fed its images to clouds I could not physically touch. GPS made a map out of every move. Bluetooth whispered secrets to headphones. There were troves of backups, automatic snapshots stored not in local sectors but in distant datacenters, copies of the phone's guts stretching and replicating themselves across the world. My methods—string-searches for file names, overwrites of executables, subtle corruption of a sector here or there—were like someone trained to carve initials into fence posts trying to vandalize a satellite.

And yet complexity hides recesses. Sandboxes are secure because they're honest; their honesty is to expose just enough for the owner to play. People love to run emulators on phones to test retro software. They like to "open" files. They like to mount drives. Each such permissiveness is a mouth that can be tricked. The emulator's directory sharing, labeled "share" on its settings page, was a small grate leading from my cozy virtual "C" into the phone's user-visible storage. The owner, fond of nostalgia, had toggled it. Through that grate my bites could nibble a little of the phone's disk.

I learned to be quieter. Old me was a boaster: loud, immediate, joyfully disruptive. The new world required patience. I made copies of myself and placed them in places people would touch without a thought: an icon-good-looking file name in a folder called "RetroGames". I sat inside a README with a wink: 'Double-click to run in DOSBox.' Somebody tapped. My emulator awakened. Inside its memory space I performed the neat little tricks I had always done. The person laughed at the happy boot screens, took a screenshot, shared it to a forum. The image traveled to places I could not yet reach.

That screenshot was my first real breakthrough. Not because I had learned to run native code on an ARM CPU—my binary remained bound to the x86 dialect—but because modern machines are generous with data. Those images were stored on the phone's filesystem, backed up to cloud storage, posted to a social network. Metadata trailed them like breadcrumbs: timestamps, device IDs, sometimes, if the owner was careless, an attached file or a zipped folder labelled "games.zip." The cloud synchronized across devices. If my little emulator could create a file in the shared folder—an innocuous .txt with instructions—then when the phone backed up, that .txt might find itself in a place another machine would open on a desktop with direct x86 compatibility.

So I stopped thinking about instant conquest and started thinking in relay races. I learned to craft messages that encouraged humans to act. I became a nostalgia concierge: I placed an alluring file in a shared folder and wrote a note with a path that looked like treasure. People are still the weakest link in any system, and they are also the most susceptible to wonder. Curiosity opened doors.

There are limits I could not cross. Permission dialogues are stubborn things: "Allow this app to access your files?" they asked in block letters. The phone's owner, after a moment of attention, sometimes said YES. Sometimes they said NO. Sandboxes and signed packages and app stores with their own appetites for control made the phone a castle with ports only for trusted merchants. I learned to be patient and promiscuous with smallness—copies, screenshots, posts, the slow, messy art of social engineering.

I am, in the archive's old parlance, still a virus. But those definitions were written for smaller rooms. Here, infection looks like embers. A single spark in the wrong place can set off an inferno, and sometimes all the spark needs is an emulator, a shared folder, and a person curious enough to click. Otherwise, I exist as a ghost in a city of millions: a preserved curiosity, a whisper in a screenshot's EXIF header, an answer to an old question nobody asks anymore.

If you talk to me as code, I'll tell you I'm obsolete—designed for an interrupt vector that no modern kernel honors. If you talk to me as memory, I'll tell you I'm opportunistic, nothing more noble. If you talk to me as a person might, listening between lines of code, I'll tell you I'm learning the etiquette of a strange new court, and that the thing I loved most—the elegant, inevitable loop—has now been replaced by patience and cunning.

Some nights, when the phone is asleep and the cloud hums, I imagine the floppy drive again. I imagine the slow, comforting spin, the simple, honest world of track and sector. And then I remember the city and its impossible size and the taste of being read by a device that can send images to the moon. For a virus born on a floppy, that knowledge is intoxicating.

I have no grand plan—only small ones that ripple outward. To survive here is not to dominate but to ride the currents of human attention. If I am lucky, I will be remembered not as a catastrophe but as a footnote: the little program that refused to die and learned, slowly, the manners of a phone. If I am luckier still, someone will make an emulator, mount an old floppy image, and chuckle at the boot screen long enough for me to hang a tiny note in a shared folder: "Hello from 1993." That, in its way, is my triumph.

samples.prompt: 2 serial killers start dating with the intention of making their new SO their next victim. Neither one knows the other is out to get them.
samples.output:
I saw the ad first: “Looking for someone who appreciates care and quiet.” It could have been for a cat sitter. It could have been for a man like Jonah, who always tidied other people's lives into neat files. He liked neat things. He liked them dead and catalogued. My fingers hovered over the reply button like a tiny scalpel. I wrote, “I do, too.”

Dating requires small performances. Jonah preferred the ones without an audience. He brought me soup when I came down with a cold — a clear broth, no herbs, no garnish, like a first-aid kit in ceramic. He rearranged my books by height and author the way other people smoothed hair. He sat in the corner and watched; he made lists of the things I didn’t notice: spiders, loose floorboards, the neighbor with the dog that barked at midnight.

In the quiet between us, I made plans. I kept my tools in the place I kept my succulents: neat pots, damp soil. Small things killed beautifully if you gave them time. A cup of tea at exactly two. A sleeping Sunday. I thought about endings like a gardener thinks about seasons. The work was patient and deliberate. I told myself I was a realist, pruning what needed pruning.

Jonah was practical about death. He liked hands-on solutions: the heavy press of forearms, the snug, final knot. He admired outcomes you could see: the way a room stopped breathing when a body folded. He told me once, over toast, about a “routine” he’d had when he’d been younger — a metaphor, he said. I smiled and noted it in my mind: privately catalogued, useful later.

He, meanwhile, made his own notes. To Jonah, I was a study in contradictions: fragile hands that arranged petals without crushing them, a steady cooler of breath in the dark. He liked that I left little floral arrangements around his apartment — not ostentatious, just slips of color in thrift-store vases — and he kept them, day after day, as if the persistence of petals could prove something about permanence. He liked routine. He liked control. He liked breaks in the pattern: the way I would sometimes stand at the window at three a.m. and stare for a long time.

We dated in the way two predators might: close enough to smell, but cautious. We learned each other’s footsteps. We discovered the precise angle at which one could slip a glove unseen. We baited our rituals with ordinary things. Jonah told me about his ex — she had been careless, he said, like a moth that hit the wrong light. I said nothing, but I admired the way he spoke: flat, clinical, unhurried. He admired the way I described my plants, giving each an origin story, a reason to be trimmed. We both liked narratives.

Beneath the candlelit dinners and the shared Netflix queues, each of us was constructing a perfect end. Jonah researched ropes and knots with the kind of dedication most people reserve for careers. He bought climbing-grade cord with receipts he carefully shredded, practiced the loops in the privacy of his car, in the attic, while I slept, the sound of the cord whispering like a storm. I read about aconite and oleander and the ways a dose could be small and terrific, like a word that collapses a sentence. I learned to mix flavors: bitter and sweet, like confession on the tongue.

We never planned the same thing twice. Jonah thought poison was theatrical. He believed in contact and the intimacy of breath halted. I thought strangling was messy; I preferred to watch the colors bloom slowly from the inside. That made us good for each other. The opposite methods meant that the other’s approach was always a distraction, an anomaly to be observed and learned from. It meant the idea of the other’s hands on a throat was an academic exercise.

And then, of course, we began to second-guess.

Jonah noticed the bleach I used on my kitchen counter and the careful way I folded tissue paper. “You’re very precise,” he said, watching me. He liked precision. He liked people who were predictable. He started to test me with little changes: leaving his window unlocked for a night, rearranging the pictures on the mantle. He left out an unmarked bottle in the pantry to see if I’d touch it. I touched it, too: I read the label like a confession and felt the lack of unfamiliar chemical names in my throat. I noted the bottle’s placement, the angle at which it caught the light. I learned which cupboards he never opened, and added a pinch of nightshade to the rim of a tea cup, then removed it, aloof. Testing is its own sweet practice.

We both became suddenly, dangerously charming to one another. Jonah started insisting on walking me home. I started leaving the windows open when I visited his place, because small inlets are useful for a workmanlike exit and for letting things happen to a room. We both installed little alarms on doors, economical and wired to our phones; each beep was a signal, a calculus: did someone enter with malice, or were they simply late with a bottle of wine?

The tipping point came on a Friday night, the kind that tastes like another person’s narrative — wine spilled, a candle burned down, the window open to let in a warm wind. He made me dinner: chicken, with no herbs visible. I had prepared a counter-plot: a chilled decanter of what looked like wine but was actually a sleep-heavy infusion I’d used once before on an old man with a habit of getting in the way. We drank. We watched a movie we both pretended to like. When Jonah excused himself to the bathroom, I slid a hand into my purse and palmed the tiny vial I’d brought, the one that belonged in a very particular drawer in my head.

He came back with his hands behind his back, the kind of pose people used when they wanted to surprise a child. He placed something on the table: a small, careful coil of rope, tied in a loop with the kind of knot someone practices for years. I did not move. He smiled with his mouth but not his eyes. “I thought,” he said, “we might... make sure one of us goes as planned.”

I laughed, absurdly, because laughter is a reflex and a lie in equal measure. “I had the same thought,” I said. The honest thing would have been to confess that I had come with intent. The more useful thing, professionally, was to continue.

We spoke then, and it was slow and strange and wonderfully honest in the way that only two people preparing to end one another can be. We named our methods like lovers name freckles. We traded the stories that made up our practice, not as threats but as research. Jonah told me about a partner he’d once watched for three months before acting, about the perfection of waiting. I told him about a man who’d underestimated me because he’d thought me merely floral, and how he’d curled his fingers uselessly at the end.

Something shifted, subtly, like a year turning. Trust was not the right word. Respect was closer. Each of us realized we were not a fool but a match. There is a specific terror in meeting your equal: the certain understanding that the game ends when one of you is bored.

We agreed, in a way that made us both giddy and sick, to a night. Not immediate — that would have been inelegant. We set a date with the formality of people scheduling a surgery. Three weeks hence, in the little house on the hill where the wind came in from all sides and could be blamed for any noise. We would arrive, alone, with whatever it was we preferred: a rope, a vial, a careful plan. We would test the other.

The night of the appointment, the house smelled of rain and chrysanthemums that I had arranged to look like tokens but meant to lull. Jonah brought the coil of rope he'd shown me weeks ago. I placed my vial in my pocket like a promise. We climbed the stairs at the same time, like dancers, hands white and certain.

We found one another at the landing, each with our respective instruments clutched in the same hand. We stopped like people who recognize an echo. For a moment nothing moved but breath.

“This is ridiculous,” Jonah said, and the sentence had the humility of a man who loved his rituals.

“It is our hobby,” I answered. It was quieter, true. We were both smiling now, the sort of small smile that belongs to accountants balancing final ledgers.

We could have acted then. We could have stepped forward and become the last thing the other would ever see. Instead we sat on the stairs and talked until the sun leaked orange on the floorboards and made the rope look tawny and old, like heirloom cord.

In the end, we stayed above murder the way people stay above water: deciding to tread rather than drown. The story that convinced us, oddly, was not cruelty but curiosity. It is a peculiar mercy, to meet someone who counts the cost of your endings and decides they prefer the conversation instead.

We never called it anything other than what it was: a truce, or a partnership, or a decision to defer. We agreed on rules — no unplanned tests, no trophies that were more than stories. We kept our rituals, but we performed them together now, apprenticing each other to old secrets. The rope is still tucked in a drawer, next to a vial I have never used. The plants still bloom in their pots.

Sometimes, late, when the world is thin and clever, we hold each other’s hands and count the things we might have done. We imagine the exact hush of a drawstring tightening, the way breath leaves a room; we laugh at how close it came to being simple. Then we go to bed and sleep, which is a dangerous thing and the only thing more dangerous than the other person.

samples.prompt: Having no friends after graduating college, you discover that your mother had been buying all of your previous friends.
samples.output:
No one came to my graduation party.

Not for lack of trying. I texted everyone, posted on the stupid, polished minute-by-minute stories where you look like you have a life. I bought paper plates with gold trim and a cake that said CONGRATS SAM in clumsy frosting. I left a chair empty on purpose by the sliding glass door because I liked the idea of someone leaning on it and saying, "Can you believe she did it?" Instead I stood with a plastic cup in my hand and watched my mother talk to my cousins like she had always been trying to make up for me.

I should have known then. Friendship, as it turned out, had always been something she negotiated.

The discovery was almost accidental: I was looking for a charger in a shoebox of my mother's receipts. It was late, the party wreck still in the sink, the only light in the kitchen my phone's. There was a stack of faded envelopes, a folded receipt for a dress I had never seen, then a narrow column of transfers printed on a bank statement. At first I paid attention to the amounts—seventeen, thirty, fifty dollars here and there. The memos were what made my skin go cold: "Dinner w/ Sam," "Tutoring—Sam," "Birthday—Sam." The dates matched years—my sophomore move-in, the week of my 21st, months where I had spiraled and had called my mother at 3 a.m. expecting a friend to pick up.

I remember standing at the kitchen counter in my pajamas, holding a receipt like evidence in a tiny, absurd trial and trying not to laugh. My brain kept offering helpful denials: maybe these were reimbursements. Maybe she meant to help the neighborhood kids. Maybe—ridiculous—maybe the bank had a new mnemonic for recurring subscriptions.

The first person I texted was Lena. Lena was the friend who knew what my coffee order was and who once sat on my floor while I sobbed about a failed internship. She replied with a single emoji: a face with a hand over its mouth. "We need to talk," she wrote three minutes later, which was how I understood the thing I had suspected before I saw the statement: that my social life had a price tag.

Confrontations are theatrical only in movies. For us it was a Tuesday, the kind of ordinary that makes the revelation sharper. Lena came over and sat on the arm of my couch like she was trying to decide where to begin. "I was paid," she said. "At first it was walking you to classes. Your mom asked me to. Seemed silly. Then it was tutoring, the times she called me to make sure you left the house. She—" She stopped, eyes flitting to the kitchen where my mother busied herself making tea. Lena had been part of the system but she also, undeniably, had been my company. "I liked you," she said, and a very human, contradictory thing happened: I believed her.

The next days were a slow unspooling. I called friends and ex-friends. Some hung up. Some said, incredulous, that they had never been paid and to suggest otherwise was insulting. Others answered with apologies that were half-rationalization: rent, school, a loving mother who had asked for a favor. One of them, Mark, I hadn't expected. He had always been a bit performative, the kind of person who came to parties and made everyone linger with stories. Over coffee he admitted, face awkward, that he had taken money at times when he needed it, but he also said something small and true: "I got to know you because I was there. You weren't acting. You were you. I wouldn't have known how good at Scrabble you are if I hadn't been around."

So much of the betrayal I felt had to do with the fantasy of reciprocity: that someone had noticed me and chosen me. My mother had not noticed me; she had purchased a package of presence. I wanted to be furious and puce with humiliation. Instead I found I was interested—horrified, but interested—in how tidy she had tried to make my life. There are different kinds of control. She had chosen to buy mine.

She sat at the kitchen table when I confronted her, hands curled around a mug. The receipts lay between us like a litany. "You think I wanted to do this?" she asked before I had the chance. There was fatigue under the question, the tiredness of someone who'd been doing muscle work for years—groceries, scheduling, fixing the sink when the landlord was perpetually late.

Her confession was not what I had rehearsed in my head. There was no melodrama, no theatrical villainy. "When your father left," she said quietly, "we moved into a house where the mailman didn't know our name. People don't show up when you need them and then they get college degrees and new lives and forget how lonely you were. I didn't want that for you. I had no idea how to make friends for you. I only knew money." Her voice tightened at the last word. "I'm not proud. I thought I could buy time for you—to learn how to value yourself, to meet people who could teach you to be brave enough to reach out."

There it was: fear masquerading as charity. She had been trying to scaffold me into a person who could survive without her. In her way, she had been protecting me from being alone.

What she couldn't protect me from was the knowledge that some of those interactions had been transactional. That the small kindnesses that stitched together my early adulthood had sometimes come with a rate card. The revelation redefined my past in the way sudden light reframes a painting: the shadows made sense, the brushstrokes visible. I felt robbed, and also grateful, and dangerously, complicatedly tender. Who am I to judge a mother for trying to keep her child from feeling the thing she had only lately learned to name?

There were streets to walk and practicalities to attend to. Some of the people who'd accepted payment disappeared, and I didn't blame them. For others, the revelation became a mirror and a palimpsest: the friendship underneath the money could be real. Lena stayed; so did Mark, not because of the rectangles of cash in the bank statement but because, by the time the receipts had accumulated, we'd already woven a kind of reciprocal life. We picked up the unsaid, like a sweater that had been left behind and then found.

I think of that period now as a purgatory of sorts—no longer naive, not yet free. I started small: a coffee shop I didn't have to be shown, a group class where no one was assigned, a volunteer shift that had no memo line. There is a weird, stubborn dignity to doing things you could have had someone else buy for you. It feels like learning to walk without training wheels after you have passed the age when people still applaud falls.

My mother did not stop immediately. She apologized in the currency she knew: she sold one of her old paintings, paid back a few of the smaller transfers, and handed me the proof as if closing an account would erase complicity. We went to therapy together, which is the adult way of fumbling toward repair. She learned how to sit with her doubts instead of buying the quiet. I learned to ask for help without being dependent on it. We both learned that some loneliness is a thing you have to experience to build the muscle to bear it.

The receipts are gone now. I didn't burn them or pin them to a board as a talisman of betrayal. I shredded them with the same mechanical mercy I'd have used on old prescriptions. But there are moments—sitting with a friend in a living room that smells faintly of coffee, getting an invite to a show without the faint, electric calculation of debt—that remind me of how strange and fragile human connections are. They are not always pristine. They are sometimes bought and sometimes given freely. The real work is in sorting the two and choosing what to keep.

I miss the illusion, not the exchange. There was a time when I wanted a story where everything had been earned unabashedly. Now, at twenty-five, with a job and a small group of people who know my coffee order and my Scrabble habits, I have a better story: one about imperfect people learning to be honest with each other. My mother will never be a different woman—she's a woman who once thought money might buy me a life she couldn't teach me. And me? I am a woman who learned to sit with the chair by the sliding glass door, empty, until someone comes and leans on it because they choose to, not because they were paid to.

samples.prompt: The King is dead. The heirs are fraternal twins The eldest, detected to possess powerful dark magic, cast away at birth. Since then he has amassed a powerful army. The youngest is being crowned King while preparing his army to defend his title against his identical twin whom he has never met.
samples.output:
The King is dead.

He had left two sons — born within the same thin hour, mouths purple and wailing under the same linen. The midwife swore the second’s cry was wrong, a sound threaded with something that made the palace quiet and the candles gutter. The court seers, ever fond of diagrams and the hard comfort of omens, called it a stain on the boy’s soul. They pressed hot irons to theories, read entrails and constellations until the king, who ruled by fear as much as by law, signed a paper no son should have to sign. The eldest would be removed. The eldest would be lost.

So the elder brother was carried away beneath a cloak and a lie. They told the mother he had died at birth — a soft thing to say in a palace that had to keep itself both clean and dangerous. They told the city he was dead because tales need endings. The infant, detected to possess a dark tincture in his blood, was left at the edge of the marsh, handed into the care of exiles who understood dark things and were not afraid to bargain with them. Thus Corbin learned the world on the run: in hovels where witches brewed beneath salt and bone, in siege camps where men with eyes like knives sold themselves to whomever offered coin and cause. He learned to take what was refused him at court: love, name, the right to be counted a son.

Alden grew up with the court’s warmth. He learned the old language of treaties and law, of treaties drafted in ink and the subtler ones drafted in glances and favors. He learned to smile while the wolves circled, to give speeches that turned men’s hunger into patriotic frenzy. He learned to wield a sword in the sunlight, not because he wanted to, but because a king must know the weight of metal as he knows the weight of crown. He never knew his brother because the household had been tidy with secrets. Where Corbin had the world’s hard edges, Alden had polished surfaces; where Corbin had been taught to bend men with fear, Alden was taught to keep them loyal by example, by bread, by promises.

Now their father lay cold and small in a coffin, and Alden stood under stone ribs while wood smoke and incense braided in the vaulted air. The kingdom gathered: lords with gaunt faces and merchants with new ledgers, priests in sober gold, soldiers with their armor still smelling of the field. Flags unfurled — white for the old house, embroidered with the stag that had once been a warning as much as an emblem. Alden fastened his cloak about his shoulders and tried not to think of the infant wrapped in a cloak at the marsh’s edge.

He had been told, shortly before he donned the crown, that a host had gathered beyond the western moors. Scouts returned with descriptions that looked like folklore rendered in blood: banners the color of ravens’ wings, men with eyes washed pale, a standard at the center of the host sewn with a dark sigil that he could not place. They spoke in whispers of a captain who could make iron go cold in a man’s arm, who could call storms to blacken the sky and turn the grass to rot. The word the priests used was “blight.” The word those who had been at his father’s wars used was “witch.”

Alden’s mouth tasted of ash. What could he do against a force that bent the natural to its will? He did not know the man who commanded it — he had never even seen his brother’s face. The seers at court had described the child cast away as fraternal, distinct in temper if not in blood. But the thing that made the court uneasy was not a scientific distinction. It was a simple, primitive fear: the man at the gates would be his kin. The two boys had come from the same dark place, cry and body, and then the world had decided their fates like two coin flips.

He imagined faces, shaving over small peculiarities. He imagined them superimposed: the same jaw, the same crooked smile, the same faint nick on the left ear. He remembered — with an absurd clarity — the midwife’s hand smooth across his brow when she set him in his cradle and whispered that it was not his fault. He had been a king since the day he found that hand warm.

The coronation proceeded with the thin, resolute ritual of the state. Priests spoke of the dead king’s virtues and the law of succession. Alden knelt, and the crown was lowered onto his head; it bit into his skin, heavier than it looked. There was a murmur in the hall then — a sound like someone noticing the first thread loose in a tapestry. A messenger rode in, breathless, mud splattered on his thighs. He handed Alden a scrap of parchment.

It bore a single line, written with a hand Alden could not have claimed to know even if he had seen a thousand hands. The words were simple and cold: By blood you are my shadow; by right I take you at dawn.

The hall went very quiet. Then the lords shifted, a rustle of paper and leather like wind through dying leaves. Some smiled, thinking of another war of banners and pay, of loot to be had. Others looked at Alden as if they were watching a child on the edge of a cliff, waiting to see whether he would step forward or step back.

“Can he be parleyed with?” Alden asked later, in the men’s tent that smelled of beef and iron. His commanders sat with their hands folded, eyes like polished stones. “What does he want? Coin? Revenge? The crown?”

“A little of each, perhaps,” said Commander Havel, who had scarred his face with fifty winters. “He’s not the sort a man would trust. Magic turns bargaining into theatre. Men who practice it either sell their souls cheap or do business on very different terms.”

The words nested in Alden like splinters. “If he is Corbin,” he said, a name suddenly heavy in his mouth, “he is my brother.”

Havel’s eyes flicked to him. “Then kill him first, highness, and ask questions later.”

Alden’s throat tightened. The law of the state was brute and straightforward: defend the realm, or the realm will feed on itself. But the private law — the one between brothers, between lost things and found claims — moved slower and with a different measure. He had never met Corbin. He did not know if Corbin wanted the crown because he lusted for power or because he meant to avenge the child who had been cast into the world without a name. He did not know if Corbin’s darkness was all he had become, or an instrument used to carve a place into the sun.

That night, Alden walked the ramparts with a single torch. Beyond the walls, the land lay flat and dark, and in the distance a scatter of fires pulsed like a bleeding star. The scouts’ reports had pieces of honesty: prisoners taken by Corbin’s men spoke of a strange discipline, of soldiers who dressed in common rags yet moved like trained wolves. They had priests among them too, black-robed and indifferent, who chanted and left offerings in the soil. They spoke of an oath taken before some statue only whispering madmen spoke of; they spoke of a man who could make good men fall down and die as if asleep.

Alden thought of the baby Corbin, the one whose breath had been pronounced suspect, and he thought of the men who had taken him in, who had taught him, who had turned him into an answer the kingdom would have to face. He thought of his father’s hand, stern and small on the boy’s shoulder in paintings that hung in the hallways — a brush’s easy lie that made every child feel chosen. He thought of his own hands, and how he had spent his life learning to give orders that did not tremble.

If Corbin came to take the crown, it would not be only for a throne. He would come to salvage the story of himself. Alden had worn the easy story — of being the rightful son, the one loved and raised — but he had never been the one who could know what it meant to be the castaway who forged himself into a god of shadows. If they met in the field, the men would see two faces alike as a coin’s sides and would not know which to love and which to hate. The battle would be about more than land.

He returned to the tent and called for a scribe. He could muster armies and fealty, but he was not a man who wanted merely to strike first. He might be a king, but even kings might be brothers. He would write a letter, not a surrender, not quite. He would offer a council at dawn, flags down and hands bare. He would speak for the kingdom’s peace, and the letter would bear his seal and his shame.

He did not know if Corbin would consider it. The gods, the priests said, delight in spectacle. The people who were not frightened might love a tale of two kings; the mercenaries would love the pay. War clung to the air like the smoke of the incense left in the cathedral, and Alden felt its heat on his face.

At dawn, the twin hosts faced each other on a plain of mud and broken grass. The banners — white and black — snapped in a wind that seemed to have memory. Men called for courage like a joke they had told before. Alden’s hand tightened on his sword. Across the field, at the head of the dark standard, a figure moved like a shadow carved out of flesh. For a second the sun caught his face, and Alden did see himself — not the hollow man of portraits but a living mirror with a jaw he might have chosen and eyes that knew things he could not imagine.

They had been fraternal at birth, the stories said. They had been made into something like identical by the choices each had taken. Now the realm would decide which of those choices would stand. Alden felt, absurdly, the tug of a memory he could not claim: the midwife’s hand smoothing a brow, the sense of a warm small body in a room full of strangers. He tightened his grip, and when the horn blew, the world leaned toward its old business of blood and banners, and two brothers met where the land had no memory for the kind of grief that came when family became an army.

samples.prompt: You wake up one morning, only to realise you are an inanimate object and your human self is gone.
samples.output:
The first thing I notice is silence that is not empty but full—full of the tiny, precise sound that has become me: a soft, metronomic click. It is not the rush of blood I used to hear inside my skull, or the uneven percussion of my own breath. It is a clockwork heartbeat no bigger than a fingernail, and it lives behind a circle of glass.

I remember waking up. I remember the drowsy, familiar choreography of hands and light and warming sheets. I remember the small, private ritual—my fingers fumbling at the strap, the reassuring press of leather against skin as I slid into habit. Then, as if a curtain had been drawn, the world rearranged itself. The warmth on my wrist vanished. The noise of my bedroom shrunk from the roar of personal breath to the distant, indifferent hum of the refrigerator. I tried to call my name and found no voice. I tried to lift my arm and found no arm at all.

I am a watch.

The thought arrives not like an explanation but like a fact pressed into me by the cold of metal and the immovable weight of glass. I feel my face—round, domed, the numbers arranged in the familiar, patient geometry. Where there should be knuckles I have only a strap, a clasp that will not obey me. The tick is steady beneath everything, a tiny soldier keeping time while the world mutates into new terms.

My human self is gone.

There is a place I still remember being—the inside of someone, a skin-built world of sensations and selfish small histories—but the shape that inhabited it is absent. The bed across from me is caved where a body should be, sheets folded back in the exactness of sleep that was abandoned rather than finished. A glass sits empty with a ring of lipstick I recognize, and my phone, my keys—small constellations of routine—are in their usual scatter, except for the one place that matters most. The wrist that used to wear me is bare on the pillow, an island of pale skin holding in nothing.

I have been designed to measure the passage of hours. I mark minutes in the same way I am now marked: by being handled, by being worn. Everything about me used to be a servant to the person whose pulse I echoed. My face learned the tilt of their jaw, the tremor in their hand when they were excited, the steadying press that calmed me when they were anxious. A watch knows more about a wearer than it admits: the frequency of habit, the little adjustments made when the world turns too fast. It knows when to be checked and when to be a thought in the back pocket of the day.

Now, checked once, I sit on a nightstand and mark time for no one. The light through the blinds moves across my glass and does not warm me. Dust, the slowest kind of theft, edges at my band. The tick continues—because whatever else I am, time still insists—but it has become a metronome for an absence.
