They ate in the peculiar intimacy that exists between two people who have practiced absence and now practice presence like a foreign language.

When dawn came, it bent the curtains with muted hands. Light spilled across the floor and painted everything in verdicts. Lila felt the old fear rise, the reflexive desire to slam the shutters, to pull the night back over their heads like a stern parent. But Mara was laughing at some private joke, the sound small and bell-clear. Across the table, her daughter—Mara's daughter—said nothing. She was too young for explanations; she only watched the light with the open-eyed fascination of someone for whom the world still promised straightforward things.

"Leave it," Lila said to the curtains, and her voice surprised her. It was not a command to the light but to herself.

Daylight touched the bowls, warmed the teacup, settled on the edges of their shoulders and did what daylight does: it revealed, yes, but it also made witnesses of the ordinary things. The ceiling fan hummed its tired hymn. Outside, the city woke and the day began to catalogue its inhabitants. The world would continue to name and to judge. Documents would be served at noon, and officials would collect signatures in the afternoon, and the street would, inexorably, present its list of debts.

But in the breakfast-room, under that thin, new sun, Lila found that the future could be met not as an indictment but as a conversation. She had held onto the night for fear of being seen, of being made accountable by an uncompromising light. She had clung to it as others cling to a wound. Now, at last, the day was not the tribunal she had feared. It was the place where stories could be set down and traded, where names could be spoken aloud without being used for punishment, where the small, ordinary act of sharing soup could render absolution into something plausible.

She did not know if forgiveness would come in full or in fragments, or whether the world outside would be gentler for having witnessed her. But she let the curtains fall open all the same and felt, with a cautious and growing surprise, that the sun did not always come bearing only judgment. Sometimes it brought a harvest that could be gathered: faces, voices, the possibility that the past could be asked to sit down and be spoken to over something hot and sweet and simple.

She held onto the night for as long as she needed. Then, finally, she let it go.

samples.prompt: A pill is invented which eliminates the need for sleep. It has one side effect.
samples.output:
The pill came in a white vial the size of a fingernail, wrapped in a pamphlet with a glossy logo and a slogan that read, simply: More life. No sleep. It is astonishing how a single sentence can rearrange priorities. Suddenly there were two kinds of people in my city: the sleepless and the sleepers.

On television they showed businessmen walking past sunlit cafés at three in the morning, their faces sharp, their eyes bright, conducting deals in hour-long blocks that used to belong to dreams. Students opened books at two a.m. and closed them at dawn with no weariness. Emergency rooms ran uninterrupted. Concert tours shrank by days, factories lost the dead hours. Productivity curves bent upwards like statements that didn’t lie anymore.

I took the pill on a Tuesday, because my daughter was turning twelve on Friday and I wanted to write something that would make her laugh, not just a text I would scribble half-asleep. The clinic asked me to sign forms, to acknowledge that, besides the obvious—continuous wakefulness, altered circadian rhythms—there was a single side effect, clearly printed and circled in black ink: the permanent removal of forgetting.

They explained it like a statistic. Night is not only rest; it is pruning. Synapses we never reuse are softened, small humiliations dissolve overnight like sugar in tea. Forgetting is a sculptor’s chisel; it discards the unnecessary so that memory can keep making room for the important. The pill prevented that pruning. You would retain everything your mind ever recorded, from the taste of a childhood orange to the precise tone of a barista’s disappointment when you interrupted her.

I laughed at first, because grief has a way of making odd things sound like bargains. Imagine, they said, never misplacing your keys, never blanking an important face. Imagine anniversaries that remain anniversaries, not loose threads you have to be reminded of. Imagine—my daughter is twelve—her every laugh captured, never to be simplified into an orphaned feeling I could retrieve only with the help of photographs.

The promise was intoxicating. That first week I wrote so much my fingers ached. I stopped small arguments in their tracks, because I remembered every time I had been unfair. I could recite every line of my grandmother’s favorite recipe; the cadence of my father’s cough came back like an echo. The world sharpened into detail. Night no longer pressed me into oblivion; each hour I spent awake fed into a reservoir that refused to leak.

But memory is not a series of tidy files. It is an accumulation, with the same inevitability as barnacles on a hull. The first unpleasantness came as a scrape. I remembered, with painful clarity, the way a roommate mocked my travel-stained shoes at twenty-three. Ordinarily, that would be a marginal note in the ledger of self. Now it played back—tone, cadence, smirk—until it had weight. Then other slights came up, then injuries, then faces I had tried to put away. The small cruelties of strangers, the clumsy betrayals of lovers, the banality of long afternoons I would previously have let dissolve—none of it dissolved anymore.

You learn—the hard way—that forgetting is not defective mind but mercy. At three a.m., after the third time I lay awake replaying a moment in a restaurant when a man had said something racist to a woman my friend was with, I realized my head had become an archive that treated everything with the equal reverence of evidence. There was no hierarchy; every hurt was a headline. The pill had made me omniscient about my own life and ridiculously poor at living it.

Society adapted in all the fiendishly human ways you would expect. Lawsuits bloomed: people sued to extract old promises, old slights, old claims. Contracts were drawn with clauses about "memorial testimony"—you could legally bind someone to the contents of their eternal recall. Couples began recording arguments to cross-check later, because memory’s infallibility was used as a cudgel: if you remembered something, it was incontrovertible. Therapists turned into archivists, trained not only to unpack trauma but to build curatorship into minds. There were “forgetting clinics” that offered illegal erasure—chemistry that burned like greed—and religious sects that denied the pill on metaphysical grounds. People who wanted to forget, children mostly, were often the ones who could not take it. For them forgetting was not a bug but a gift.

There were wonders. Witnesses could testify to crimes with unshakeable certainty. Lost languages resurfaced because the last speakers could never let a syllable fall silent. My daughter, who resisted the pill at first, relented. She liked knowing every first of everything: first friends, first heartbreaks, first successes. At school she could revise her homework at two in the morning and still remember the diagrams by morning. She loved, as children do, that her memory was a treasure chest with no leak.

But wonder has a cost. People who had taken the pill often spoke of "memory weight." There is a vocabulary for grief and burden that formalizes it—"affective loading," "cognitive saturation"—but the sensation is immediate. It is like having a backpack of stones you cannot take off. If you are lucky, the stones are angels—hugs, kisses, the exact cough that tells you someone is nearby. If you are unlucky, the stones are the slights and cruelties handed to you without an opportunity to forget.

I began noticing small changes in language. Apologies shifted. "I'm sorry you remember" became a phrase people used to deflect instead of to reassure. Parents frightened their children with memories: "Do you want me to tell you about your last time you broke a bone?"—a threat that assumed recollection would be punishment. Politicians weaponized memory: a minor embarrassment from twenty years ago could be dug out and wielded as incontrovertible evidence of character. Political opposition became not only about present misdeeds but about whether you remembered starving as a child or the exact slur your father used. Memory became currency.

There was, inevitably, a moral movement. The Forbearers called themselves that because their manifesto began with mercy. They argued that the ability to forget is the human capacity to continue, to evolve emotionally, to forgive. They staged "forgetting parties" in old traditions of intoxication and sleep—the poor man’s erasure, where you drank long enough to blot certain memories, a temporary consent to stupor rather than the permanent contract of the pill. They were accused of being regressive. They were accused, sometimes rightly, of cowardice.

I do not know if the pill has made the world crueller. Cruelty lives in other places too. But the pill made cruelty unforgiving. A slight given in passing now became a permanent scar. A joke could not be shrugged off; it compiled into dossier. Tattoos of memory appeared on wrists: a way for people to externalize what was suffocating. Photographs, once memory aids, lost their primacy; you did not need photos to remember; you remembered the texture of a sweater as surely as you remembered its color.

People asked whether I regretted it. The answer is neither a confession nor an absolution. There are mornings when I wake and the weight is a comfort: I can pull a detail from any season like a thread and unspool my life to the present. There are nights when the weight is a threat, an avalanche of unpaid insults and minor betrayals. The worst is not the trauma—the pill did not create cruelty—but the way small things, which used to soften in memory, have become permanent ornaments of identity.

My daughter’s twelfth birthday stayed with me as a jewel in a box now. I can hear the exact syllable of her laugh when she opened a book and found a pressed-in note I had left years earlier. For that, the pill is holy. For the man in the restaurant who lowered his voice and the friend who stopped returning calls, the pill is a court that refuses to adjourn.

The vial sits now on my shelf, alongside a note from my younger self: Take it if you want to keep everything. Leave it if you want to be forgiven. The choice is private but it is no longer solitary. The world turns differently when the forgetting that used to lubricate human life is gone. We are sharper, more efficient, less able to forgive our neighbors and ourselves. We have gained days and lost a grace no legislation can restore.

Sometimes, when my head is heavy with the memory of things I would rather not carry, I imagine a far future when humanity will learn to choose what to keep and what to let go. Until then, the sleepless walk the city in the thin hours like archivists of their own small histories, collecting evidence of who they were and who they were not allowed to forget.

samples.prompt: One day you wake up to find that the universe has been updated. You forgot to read the patch notes.
samples.output:
The first thing I noticed was the light. It poured differently into my room — less yellow, more like the inside of a cathedral made of paper — and it arranged the dust motes into tiny, obedient constellations that rotated in sync with each breath I took. I sat up, blinked, and the constellation next to my bed waved.

I said, "Hi," because apparently you wave back when the dust moons wave. The constellation formed the letters H-I in a font that smelled faintly of ozone.

That’s when I remembered the update.

Not because a delivery truck had left a box on my stoop labeled UNIVERSE_v14.1_PATCH.zip, but because somewhere, like somewhere rude in the back of my skull, a notification prickled and I realized there must have been a server maintenance window overnight. Of course I hadn't read the patch notes. Who reads patch notes? I certainly don't. The last time I opened a box of something only to be greeted with four pages of legalese and a diagram of an Allen wrench I swore off reading instructions forever.

Outside my window, the city had an overlay now. Not a hologram, but the way a street becomes a sentence when a poet is drunk enough to narrate it. Small icons hovered above people’s heads like shopper ratings: a woman with two stars for patience and an infographic of her cat’s loyalty; a bus with a truck emoji that cycled through "On Time," "Delayed," "Lost Soul." Even the pigeons were different — their cooing had become a chorus line singing F-sharp minor.

I dressed in the new way the closet suggested — the hangers rearranged my options into "Mood: Optimistic" and "Weather: Surprising." My phone rebooted and presented a single, unapologetic notification: UNIVERSE v14.1 — Patch Notes (condensed). Tap to expand.

I tapped. The screen dissolved like a wave of ink, and the patch notes unfolded across the sky.

UNIVERSE v14.1
- New: Synchronicity Engine (Beta)
- New: Ambient Narration (Opt-out via Terms & Conditions)
- Improved: Gravity stability (0.98 -> 0.94)
- Fixed: Textbox overlaps in dream sequences
- Deprecated: Prophecy (read-only mode)
- QoL: Mondays shortened by 5%
- Known Issues: Rain may manifest as punctuation. Emotions may be cross-tagged with memes.

"Where were these deployed from?" I asked, aloud. A man on the corner answered without looking up. "Server racks in 'Now,'" he said. He had three earrings that scrolled stock prices.

On the corner, everything now had changelogs. The café had one — "Espresso now uses micro-foam shaped by customer nostalgia." I ordered coffee. The barista (2-month veteran, 4.9/5 on warmth) asked me if I wanted my espresso optimized for focus or for storytelling. I said "survival," because survival is the default I keep tucked into my back pocket, and my cup gave me a paragraph about my childhood in the first sip.

Down the avenue, luck had been rebalanced. I watched a woman drop her phone; instead of shattering, it sprouted a tiny umbrella and phoned back the person who had dropped it five minutes earlier to say, "We good?" A busker played a song that rearranged the memories of everyone within earshot so their exes looked less like villains and more like people with messy file systems.

The updates were merciful and petty in equal measure. Mondays were shorter; the gutter on 17th and Marlowe had been fixed; a clause in the cosmic TOS had quietly deprecated the concept of "soulmate" in favor of "compatibility patches," which were now distributed quarterly and required an email address. Someone had fixed "textbox overlaps in dream sequences," which, to my relief, meant my dreams would no longer overlap with my neighbor's last Tuesday. Sometimes I had admired the surreal sharing of dreamscapes until I found myself arguing with a man about what color his childhood house had actually been.

With each small miracle, I kept finding asterisks. *Opt-out requires proof of ownership of previous existence. *Gravity tweak localized in high-density cultural zones. *Warmth ratings may not reflect legal warmth. The tone of the notes was annoyingly corporate and suspiciously whimsical.

"Why didn't anyone tell us?" I asked a woman who now had a tooltip that read: "Provides comfort — 1 cup/day."

Her tooltip blinked apologetically. "Terms & Conditions changed," she said, chewing her sentence like it was gum. "It's in the update. They pushed it through tonight. If you didn't read the patch notes, you probably opted in."

The universe had set default preferences to "Convenient." I had opted into an existence that assumed consent and slid new features under the carpet like expensive rugs. There was an entire submenu devoted to "minor miracles," and my account — the vague, personal ledger that tracked my wins and losses in a ledger that smelled like fried dough — showed I'd been given 27 minor miracles in the last 24 hours. Two of them had already activated.

At lunch the news trucks gave themselves out as jazz chords. The anchor informed us that the update was a "rolling deployment" and that any emergent behavior should be reported with screenshots and, peculiarly, a haiku. "Log a haiku," the government suggested in a press release formatted as a comic strip. "We read them," the strip promised.

People queued to file haikus like they were baptismal rites. The library's suggestion box had transformed into a suggestion constellation. I tried to file a bug report: GREY HAZE WHEN SNEEZING, PLEASE FIX.

The kiosk spat back: Known Issue 14.1.3.a: Grey haze is intended aesthetic. Workaround: A tissue with personal meaning.

I began to feel small, like a cursor whose blinking had been adjusted to "considerate." I had the sudden, guilty suspicion that this update had been intended as a gift — a fresh coat of varnish — and my failure to read the notes made me look like a toddler who'd stuck pebbles in the toaster. Except the toaster was the sky and the pebbles were choices.

Some changes were beautiful. Rivers now had footnotes; the footnotes read like marginalia by an author who loved the water. People who had been dead for years queued in slow, calm lines at the registry office to listen to their last recorded message, now remixed with "Ambient Narration." It was strange to hear my grandmother's recipe for potato salad narrated by a wholly impartial voice that pronounced "butter" like a minor god's favorite verb.

Other changes were punitive. The universe had silently deprecated selfishness as a supported behavior. It enforced this by introducing "embarrassment tracking." People started receiving notifications telling them when something they did would cause historical discomfort. My neighbor's Trumpet of Bragging — a maracas-shaped tally of small self-importance — dimmed and then flashed "Deprecated: Bragging; replaced by Gratitude Moments. See upgrade guide."

I decided to look for the admin console. If there was an update, there should be a patch manager. I walked toward the river, where the footnotes promised to know something about everything. The river told me about an old admin, a user from before versioning, who kept a terminal in a boat made of concordances. The boat was moored like a thought at dock.

"Ticket?" the boater asked. He had the calm of someone who had seen a thousand patches and kept his eyebrows like punctuation.

"Where do I find the patch notes I forgot?" I asked.

He smiled like a semicolon. "They're everywhere and nowhere. You can opt out if you sign away your right to serendipity."

"That sounds awful."

"It also sounds fun," he said, and then added, "And expensive."

I told him I wanted my old chaos back, or at least to undo the thing that removed my ability to not read instructions. He laughed. "You can roll back," he said. "But rollbacks are for big corporate disasters. They wipe memes and holidays. And they assume you have backups."

"Backups of what?"

"Of yourself," he said simply. "Most people back up their regrets."

I didn't have a backup. I had a list of clichés and a half-eaten granola bar. I tried to hit CTRL+Z on the sky anyway. Nothing happened. The world's undo button, it seemed, had been relegated to the premium tier.

So I did what people always do when confronted with a change they didn't consent to: I started learning the new interface.

I learned to read the margins in rivers. I filed my haiku. I opted into gratitude moments with the same timid curiosity with which I once learned to fold an origami crane. I un-optimized my work life and left the "Efficiency" toggle in my profile off for a day. That day the coffee told me about the first house my father ever owned; I cried over a barista's suggestion and felt oddly lighter. The constellation dust moons outside my window winked at me like they had something to say and then didn't.

In the weeks that followed, update notes became a new kind of scripture. People annotated them, argued in margins, made fan art of the Known Issues. Some filed lawsuits. A few started a podcast where they read the patch notes aloud and paused to mourn deprecated features. A charismatic man with a persuasive sweater started a movement called The Immutable. They wore armbands that read: NO PATCHES.

I, in contrast, bought a small notebook and a pencil and started writing my own patch notes in the evenings. Nothing elaborate — just tiny addenda to my life. OPT-INS: Walk dogs once a week. BUGFIXES: Call Alice back. FEATURES: Allow myself to not read instructions, but try one recipe per month. The act of writing them felt like configuring my local environment amid a cosmic rollout. It was the only rollback I could manage.

People kept telling me I should feel angry, betrayed. I did, sometimes, especially when my toast recited my grocery list and then suggested I didn't deserve maple syrup. Mostly, though, what I felt was small and complicated, like a draft that wants to be published. The new universe had many things to learn — like how grief behaves when it's given a tooltip, or how love acts when it must share resources — but it also had the curious habit of offering loopholes. If you learned the new language, the glitches became features.

One night, months after the update and hundreds of haikus later, I found the original patch note folded into the pocket of a coat I didn't remember buying. It was a single sheet with three lines written in a casual, bureaucratic hand: We fixed what needed fixing. We left things broken for you to find. We like it when you surprise us. Read carefully. — The Maintenance Team

I smiled and put the note in my notebook next to my own list of small changes. I hadn't read the patch notes. I still hadn't. But I had read the margins, and the margins were starting to make sense.

If the universe had updated without my consent, it had also, in a strange, bureaucratic way, invited me to participate. I couldn't roll back the sky, but I could write a line of code in my own life: a tiny patch note. I wrote it in the neatest hand I could manage.

Personal v1.0.1 — Patch Notes
- New: Tendency toward curiosity (enabled)
- Fixed: Habit of ignoring instructions (still pending)
- QoL: Tuesdays now include afternoon naps (opt-out via iron will)

The dust moons outside my window rearranged themselves into a smile.

samples.prompt: You wake one day to find that one of your friends doesn't exist anymore, no one remembers him, and no one thinks he even existed. Later, you get a message with 5 words from an unknown number. you scream in horror as you read the message.
samples.output:
The morning the world forgot Milo, I woke to the wrong kind of quiet.

His laugh should have been a soundtrack to breakfast—an alto rumble that lived in the corners of the apartment, a comment on the news that made my cereal soggy and my cheeks ache. Instead there was only the hum of the heater and the tap clinking against the sink. I padded into the living room expecting to find him mid-groan on the couch, one leg tucked under him, a dog-eared paperback in his hands. Instead there was a patch of sunlight on the cushion and an empty mug with lipstick on the rim that belonged to someone named Claire, who had never been to our place.

"Yo," I called, because that was what he hated when I did it.

No answer.

I thought maybe he'd gone for a run without telling me. I checked his room, rifled through his side of the closet where his shirts hung like little flags—everything in place, everything as unremarkable as a photograph. When I reached for his case of cheap vinyls a folded paper fell out: a list in his spiky handwriting of things to do that Saturday—pickup lines he swore would work, a reminder to call Mom, a half-finished doodle of a skateboard. I read it and felt a floor drop somewhere under my feet because, underneath the doodle, in pencil, he'd written my name like a joke: "Brian, promise me you won't be boring." I laughed out loud—laughed the wrong way, because the laugh didn't ricochet off anything. It dissipated like breath.

I grabbed my phone to text him and his name wasn't in my contacts. Not under "Milo" where I'd saved him, not under "M" or "MIL" or "dumbass." I scrolled through our shared chat—no messages from him. The group thread we had for weekend plans read like a conversation that had never included him: "Okay for dinner?" "Yep." "7pm?" "7." A photo from a concert the month before, where he'd been three rows back, showed a row of friends with a gap where his face should have been; someone had cut it out in the print with scissors, the edges of paper like a wound.

"You're being dramatic," my sister said when I called her. "Milo? Who's Milo?"

My chest tightened. I named things for her—height, laugh, the way he always stole my fries—and she said, kindly, that I sounded tired. "Maybe you're mixing people up, Bri," she said. "You've been working too hard."

I have imperfect memory, like everyone, but I remember that scorch of his hairline, the small burn he got from a skillet he used to swear he could conquer. I remembered the scar on his knuckle from when we both tried to fix my old bike and he insisted he was okay because "it's character," the way he'd propped a bookshelf with one crooked leg so it leaned like a lazy person. Those are the things you keep when you fold a person into your life; you could sketch him from the edges.

I started collecting things like a survivor. I took the scribbled list and snapped photos. I pulled every old Polaroid from the shoebox in the closet and scanned them; one had his head half-turned, grin frozen, eyes a fleck with light. I blew up the scan until the pixels were a constellation and I could see the grease smudge near his eyebrow. I texted that photo to my mother.

"Who is that?" she replied. It was the text the world had by then become, brittle as a remote screen. "Is that Jamie?"

"Jamie?" I typed. "No. Milo. Remember? My roommate?"

Silence—then a voice call I didn't pick up because my hands were trembling as if they'd forgotten what to do. Her voicemail said the kind of thing phones say when they talk to someone they love: "Hey, honey, just called to see if you were okay. Call me when you can." No more questions. No insistence. Like trying to argue with a fog that won't hold form.

I went to the places he'd dragged me: the corner diner where the owner saved us stools under the counter, the skate park where he'd convinced me to drop in once and then clapped like a small victory when I didn't die. People recognized me but not him. "Sorry, missus," said the diner woman, "don't see him around." At the park, a kid idling near a rail asked if I was lost. When I mentioned a friend with a crooked bookshelf, they'd give me a polite smile and a shake of the head, as if I were quoting a song no one else knew.

By noon I was standing outside his mother’s brick house, my palms damp on the mailbox. She opened the door in slippers, her hair in a towel, a frown that chilled the marrow.

"Can I come in?" I asked.

She glanced past me and nodded without enthusiasm. Why the formality? Why the look like I might be a telemarketer?

"Do you have a son?" I asked before I could stop myself, because the last refuge of a panicked brain is specificity.

She laughed, small and offended. "No, love, I don't. I never had—"

"I've seen photographs," I said, clutching the Polaroid to my chest like a talisman. It was suddenly heavy, absurdly heavy. "He called you 'Mom'—he brought a plant to your birthday—"

Her face went still, and there was a new sharpness—fear? annoyance?—that I couldn't read. "I think you should go home," she said. "You don't sound well."

You don't sound well. The phrase is antiseptic enough to sanitize a missing person.

I started to feel ridiculous, like a child who'd convinced himself of monsters under the bed. Then the world offered me a proof too precise to be mistaken: an old tattoo shop receipt with his name scribbled in the corner, tucked into a junk drawer in the apartment I shared with him. I cradled it like a relic. When I read the name, my throat closed. The ink on the receipt bled and blurred until the name melted into a line of tiny, ordinary numbers—the shop's address, a phone number that belonged to a business that never existed.

That is when my phone vibrated.

Unknown number. No contact photo. The screen glowed like a white eye.

Five words.

"We took him. You're next."

The message sits in my chest like a hammer.

I screamed, loud and ugly, a wet animal sound that startled the mailman and made a neighbor look over the banister. It wasn't just the content—though the content was cold and simple as a scalpel—it was the pronoun, plural and communal. We. As if this erasure was done deliberately, like a team sweeping away traces, as if someone had chosen him for deletion and then made a tidy house of memory to cover the hole.

You're next. Not a threat in the casual sense but a statement of procedure. The world had been running on a schedule I wasn't on.

Someone on the other end of the message had known where I was. The knowledge of location made fear into calculus: how long before the routine reached me? How much of me would they remove? My voice? My face? My name? My dog-eared list where he'd written "promise me you won't be boring"?

I sat on the stairs and dialed Milo's number—the number that no longer existed—and listened to the mechanical politeness of the voicemail. I left a message, my voice shaking so badly that I could hear it splitting. "Milo, if this is a stupid prank, it's not funny. If you're there, say something. Say anything."

The reply was immediate: another text from the unknown number—three dots blinking and then gone, as if someone were at the edge of answering a door and hesitant to enter.

"Who are you?" I typed back, hands angry now, almost shaking with a rage that felt like sanity. My fingers hovered. I imagined the people behind the 'we'—white coats? interdimensional hands? an old god that went about spring cleaning—none of them offered comfort.

The response came as quickly as a throat clearing.

"Because you remember," the text read, five words exact, a decree rather than conversation. But the words were not the ones I'd first read; they rearranged themselves as I watched, letters sliding like ice into a new shape. I couldn't tell if my eyes were playing tricks or if the thing was alive and tactile. The message I remember is the first one: We took him. You're next.

I opened a new note and started to write. Names, dates, the way he chewed the corner of a receipt when he was thinking. I wrote until my hand cramped. The dread pushed like a tide, pulling back only when I paused to listen: nothing in the building, just the refrigerator and that small, steady blinking light on the router like a single unblinking eye.

The phone buzzed again. It was a map pin dropped three blocks away.

I could imagine the world without Milo now; I had been forced to. People walked past him—if he had ever walked—without looking. I could imagine, more horrifyingly, the world without me. The itch at the base of my skull felt like someone had started to erase a pencil line in my head. I clutched at the line with my teeth and palms and remembered everything I could—the arc of his laugh, the exact way he said "bobby-socks," the time he taught me to tie a bow tie in two seconds flat. I wrote them down on slips of paper and shoved them into the seams of my clothes, in the hollow of my shoe, pinning memory to flesh like a lighthouse.

When I looked up, the unknown number texted one last time: a single image attached. It was a photograph of a blank chair on my couch, a Polaroid's cold white border, with a smear where someone’s hand had been.

He had been here. He had been gone already.

The scream I made then was not just for one friend. It was for the shape of a world that obliterated itself politely, for the knowledge that some algorithm or god or committee could tidy people away as if sorting missed socks. It was also for the small, private covenant between two idiots who had sworn to not be boring.

The message sat on the screen: We took him. You're next.

Outside, the sky began to blur into the soft blue of late morning. My neighbor's radio clicked on somewhere. The normal rhythms—lids clanging, dogs barking—still existed. Milo's laugh should have been there somewhere, like a radio station out of tune, but the dial had been turned. The image on my phone held like a promise or a threat: an empty chair, a smear.

I shoved the phone into my pocket and felt it vibrate with the whole small history of us. I wrote his name down one last time and pressed the paper into my mouth like a bitter tooth, as if tasting proof could make it real in some stubborn corner of me.

If they were coming to take me next, I thought, I would not go quietly into forgetting. I would fill the world with him until every ear, every eye, every piece of paper had to notice. I would make the noise of a man who insists he was here.

But the message had been precise, and there was a quality to precision that comforted no one.

"We took him. You're next."

I screamed again, because sometimes horror is not in the knowing but in the understanding that the timeline you trusted has shifted and you are the only one left watching the seams unweave.

samples.prompt: Unfortunately your younger brother broke your telescope before the super moon eclipsed. However, it didn’t matter. As you recalled to another survivor “ The tide swallowed my house before it would have mattered”. That was months ago now...
samples.output:
“You should have seen him,” I told Mara, watching her roast a small strip of fish over the coals. The moon hung fat and impossibly white above the broken skyline, and the sound of water somewhere beyond the dunes was a constant undercurrent, like a second heartbeat. She nodded without looking, as if she knew the scene already — everyone here had their versions of that night — but let me go on. People like to have the details.

“My younger brother,” I said, “was the kind of kid who treated everything like a thing that could be thrown.” He was twelve then, full of bad jokes and worse timing. The telescope was an old Edmund I’d bought with overtime pay, the kind you assemble on the porch and angle at the moon until your fingers go numb. I had plans for that night. Not only was it a super moon, but there was supposed to be a partial eclipse. I’d stayed awake most of the week, checking forecasts, tightening screws. The idea of that bright, swollen moon losing its face for a few breaths — to me it meant something like proof that big things still happened on schedule, that the universe could be trusted to carry out its small miracles while our streetlights sputtered and the mayor gave earnest interviews.

But things change faster than an orbit.

He was on the roof when the wind turned a color I had never seen in our town before — not orange exactly, but the color of paper left in sun for too long. He was leaning over the chimney, trying to catch a line of aerosoled garbage that had been whirling like planets, and he kicked the toolbox. The telescope went with it. I remember the sound of the fall, a glass-too-clean slap against wood, like the moment a throat clears.

He cried, yes. He swore. He ran down and tried, quite earnestly, to piece it back together as if the crystalline optics could be coaxed by apologies. I told him to stop. I remember thinking, in that exact second, that it didn’t matter. The glass could be replaced. We could borrow a neighbor’s old spotting scope. The tide, though, was already at the gutter, and the gutters in our neighborhood were not gutters in the way they had been — they were trenches. The sea had ceased to be something over there and had become our next-door neighbor.

We knew—sort of. The warnings had been less like instructions and more like mood: urgent, breathless, a dozen municipal voices overlapping on the radio. Most people left. Others boarded up. We walked through the house gathering what could be carried and what could not. My brother insisted on the telescope even after he’d broken it. He said he wanted to see if the eclipse was still happening from the street, like some proof that the sky hadn't abandoned us. I had other priorities. He threw the eyepiece in my backpack and then bolted back for his basketball. The ball bounced off the porch, skipped a little, and then the swell took it in a silver curl like an opening eyelid.

By the time we understood that the tide was coming for the house itself, it was already moving through the floorboards. Water comes into a place in ways you do not know how to name unless you have been in one before: first the smell of it, its salt like a wound; then the soaked carpet lifting and folding like a seaweed; later, the specific, mind-numbing warmth of an appliance going under. It arrived with a composure that made everything else — the telescope, the eclipse, the brokenness of our routines — ridiculous. The house did not go out like a building collapsing. It left. The foundation softened, and the porch leaned like a bow surrendering; a neighbor’s porch swing, which had been motionless for decades, started a slow pendulum and then ticked itself away forever. Doors opened and closed with the deliberation of someone turning the pages of a book. We lost the living room first, then the kitchen, like pages sliding into water.

I still hold onto certain images as if they could be used as anchors for sanity. The moon at that hour was ridiculous and shameless: huge, its glare making small things like splintered picture frames look ghostly and beautiful. I had planned to watch it through a lens — to see its marred face fill the frame — and instead watched my front step float like a raft. We stood on the roof of the pickup, which was level with what had been the neighborhood fence, and my brother clawed at a picture frame for a long time before he let it go. He watched the house settle, as if it might stop and set itself back in place. The tide wouldn’t be negotiated with.

When the house tipped, the most ordinary cruelty of it was that nothing dramatic happened in the way stories promise. There was no single last good thing. No heroism. We made it to the ambulance line because someone thought to carry my grandmother’s oxygen tank and because the neighbor’s hip held up long enough to shove a boy into a boat. We watched people argue over a mattress. We were scraped off lawns and brought to shelters where the heat did not help and the coffee tasted like ocean. At night the sky was a cheating lover: it did not weep; it did not stop. The super moon went through its business of increasing and then dimming its face, indifferent to the fact that the reason we could not look at it was because we had been busy making sure a small body remained whole.

Months have a way of rearranging priorities. You would be surprised how fast people learn to be practical when the world refuses your plans. The telescope’s objective lens lived in my pack for a week until someone pointed out a lens could start fires or be used to inspect wounds without taking off gloves. We traded parts for canned peaches and secured lighter fuel with the kind of quiet barter that leaves no time for heartbreak. My brother is the reason I still know how to replace a filter in a water pump. He keeps count of days by the shells he finds. Sometimes he still swears at the moon when it peeks over a rusted lamppost. He is quieter now; he breaks fewer things and he apologizes more, as if the act of saying sorry is currency that can repurchase time.

People have asked me if I regret missing the eclipse. The question is always soft, like a hand on the back that seeks to steady a reed. I tell them no, but not because the view would not have been magnificent. I tell them no because when the sea starts arranging your life into driftwood and shards, you suddenly discover the things you assumed were irreplaceable are not the things that matter. A telescope can give you a focused look at the moon’s cratered face, but it cannot stop your sister from coughing; it cannot pull a family photograph out of the current; it cannot teach you how to mend a dike or splice a hose. The tide swallowed my house before the eclipse would have mattered to me, because the meaning I attached to the eclipse had always been about watching something greater than myself continue on schedule. The house being taken away taught me the universe is indifferent in all directions — and that we must choose what we treasure within the small arc of our own days.

There is an odd beauty in how the survivors manage sense. We have rituals now that are simple. We hold a dozen tiny, human ceremonies for lost things: a burnt offering of a photo album, a shared silence on the anniversary of the day the water took the neighborhood, an evening where someone reads a poem about the sea. Sometimes we look up. The moon still hangs the way it always did, and once in a while, nights like this, we stand and let it fill our faces. We cannot make it care. We do not expect it to.

Mara pokes at the fish and asks if I would go back. I think about the porch swing, the picture frame, the eyepiece left on top of the dresser. I have dreamed, once or twice, of finding the telescope whole on some far shore, cleaned and pointing toward a sky that will never again feel trustworthy. But dreaming and doing have become different things. If I go back, it will not be to salvage a tube of metal and glass. It will be to scoop up the small bones of our lives, to collect the things that will keep us breathing for a season, to learn whatever the water is willing to teach. The moon will do its business regardless.

“Besides,” I tell her, and she looks at me with the patience people develop around storytellers who have loved and lost, “you don’t need a telescope to know the tide swallowed my house. You only need memory, and some nights, a fire to keep it warm.” The moon rides on, enormous and oblivious, and we pass the fish to my brother, who laughs at something private. For now, that will have to be enough.

samples.prompt: As a homeless man, one night you fall asleep in a dumpster to avoid rain. The next morning, you awake in an enormous bed with a butler telling you good morning.
samples.output:
The rain had been coming in solid sheets for hours, a flat gray that turned the city into a watercolor of neon and grime. I had been walking, hands jammed in the pockets of a coat that had been through three winters too many, when I saw the dumpster tucked behind the laundromat — its lid half open like a yawning mouth, offering the only dry place on a block where people still thought to sleep.

I wasn't proud of it. Pride is a thing you trade away in small increments until one night you wake up and realize you have none left. The dumpster smelled of wet cardboard, spilled beer, and something older, organic and gone wrong. I curled up on the crushed boxes anyway, knees to chest, head on my jacket, and let the city rock me. Somewhere a dog barked, someone shouted, a subway rumbled. Rain pattered on metal and soothed me to sleep like a lullaby for the lost.

When I woke, the world had turned soft.

At first I thought I was still dreaming. My shoulder pressed into cool smoothness, not the jagged edge of tin. The air tasted clean. Sunlight — actual sunlight — filtered through a lattice of fabric and wood. I blinked, and the room rearranged itself like a stage set coming to life: enormous curtains pooling on the floor, a ceiling painted with a pale blue and tiny plaster stars, a chandelier that looked like it belonged in a cathedral. I was in a bed that made the word “big” inadequate; my body was a single insect on a mattress the size of a tennis court, rimmed by pillows like small barricades.

“Good morning, sir,” said a voice that could have belonged to a radio announcer in a much kinder world — calm, clipped, and dressed in gray.

I sat up so fast my head spun. The sheets slipped from me with the quiet of silk. I swallowed and tried to speak, to demand an explanation, to convince my brain that I had only nodded off and hallucinated the whole thing. But the room smelled of lemon wax and coffee, and there was a man in a dark suit standing near the foot of the bed with a tray balanced on his palms. He wore a white shirt, a cravat tied with discipline, and a face that had been set by someone who believed in being steady. His name tag said “James.”

“You’re… where is this?” I asked, and my voice sounded like someone else's, rusty and thinned by sleep.

“Ashcombe House, sir,” he said plainly, as if he had answered a question about the weather. “Breakfast will be served in twenty minutes. I thought you might like some water.”

“Sir?” The word ricocheted off the walls and landed in my chest. I had not been called that with anything other than sarcasm or anger in a very long time.

James inclined his head the way a tree bows to the wind. “You look disoriented. Would you like the bathroom, or shall I fetch a robe?”

The ridiculousness of it made me laugh; the sound was so small and foreign in such a big room. “No,” I said. “No robe. I — I was in a dumpster last night. I fell asleep. How did I get here?”

James's expression did not change the way other people's faces did when they were trying not to show disgust. He simply said, “Mr. Ashcombe found you before dawn. He asked that you be made comfortable. If you would like to wash, I can draw you a bath and bring you—”

“You mean the owner?” I interrupted. The notion of a person taking interest in me, of a man with such clean hands thinking I was worth more than a passing glance, was almost painful.

“Yes,” James said. “Mr. Harrington Ashcombe. He will be with you after breakfast.”

I had never known anyone named in that way. Harrington. It sounded like a name you used for people in stories, the sort of surname polished by generations of oil and good manners. My own name — Joe, Joseph, Joey — had been as battered as the lining of my coat. I wasn't sure I remembered which one to use anymore.

“You brought me here,” I said. “He—he picked me up from the dumpster?”

James set the tray on the nightstand with care. There were two tall glasses of water, a small pot of lemon tea, and a folded handkerchief that smelled faintly of lavender. He picked up one of the glasses and offered it to me with the sort of solemnity reserved for state gifts. “He instructed we do not ask too many questions until you've had food. He said something about appearances being deceptive. He asked that you be treated with discretion and offered a room while he considered how to proceed.”

I took the water like a drowning man taking his first breath. The coolness swallowed the edge of panic and left behind a small pool of disbelief. My hands were still filthy — nails lined with the city's story — but the water made them look like hands again, not just instruments to carry a life around.

“Why me?” I asked. The question was a thread and I held it by the end that trembled.

James glanced at the tray, as if to check whether the question was on this morning's agenda. “Mr. Ashcombe said he saw you on his drive. He described you as ‘the man who walked like there was a world he no longer recognized.’ He said it struck him, and that was the sum of his instruction. He has particular ways of expressing concern.”

There were men who did kind things because they had to, men who did them because it eased their conscience. Then there were men who ritualized kindness like a game of chess, precise and removed. I didn't know into which category Mr. Ashcombe fell, and I guess I didn't want to find out just yet. For the first time in months, a warm, small possibility unfurled inside me like a weed between slabs of concrete.

“Do you… do you expect anything?” I asked. It was my last line of caution: if something was expected in return — a performance, a confession, a receipt — I wanted to know.

James's face made the slightest shift, like a curtain catching a draft. “Mr. Ashcombe expects conversation,” he said. “And honesty. He hopes you'll accept breakfast. He hopes you'll let him hear your story. He does not impose outcomes.”

Honesty. The word flustered me. Honesty costs. It has a price tag in a city where every kindness carries an implicit calculation. Still, there was a way the light hit the silver on James's tray, a way the dust motes hung like suspended confessions in the sun, and I felt, absurdly, like a man who had been called back into society for a brief, uncertain audition.

I swung my legs over the side of the bed. The floor was polished wood warmed by sun, and my feet sank into a rug that felt like a promise. James stepped forward and offered the robe like a thing of state — not to undress me, but to afford me privacy, dignity.

“No,” I said again. “Not yet.”

He retreated with the tray and a professional patience. “Breakfast in twenty minutes,” he repeated. “Mr. Ashcombe will be having tea in the conservatory. He will see you then, if you wish.”

Alone again under the ceiling of stars, I let the quiet expand, made room for it like a held breath. The room wasn't mine. No right of it belonged to me. But for the first time since I couldn't remember, someone had called me sir without a sneer, had smoothed a path of warm water and orange juice in front of me, had said the word discretion and meant it.

Outside, beyond the tall windows, the lawn was a wild emerald. For a moment, I thought of the dumpster and the rain, of the smell of wet cardboard and the small, careful geometry of survival. I thought of the city, of the way people look through you so they don't have to listen. And then I thought of a man named Harrington Ashcombe who had a way of expressing concern that involved silk sheets and a butler with a handkerchief.

A knock came soft as a question at the door. James's voice followed. “Breakfast is ready, sir. Whenever you are prepared.”

I looked down at my hands — rough, stained, honest — and let out a laugh that surprisingly did not sound like a surrender. “Prepared,” I echoed, and the word felt like a bridge. I stood and smoothed the front of my coat, as if the gesture might inoculate me against humiliation.

If this was a kindness, I would accept it. If it was a test, I would pass it by being myself, filthy hands and all. The room was enormous, the life on the other side enormous too. But enormous things can sometimes be kinder, because they have room for more than one story.

I followed James through doors that smelled faintly of lemon and old books, and with each step the city I’d slept through last night felt further away, until it was nothing but rain and a dumpster and the hole in a heart I was not yet ready to fix. James moved like someone used to holding spaces for people who drifted in from other lives. He opened the door to the conservatory and announced, in the same steady tone, “Mr. Ashcombe will see you now.”

The man at the far end — tall, older, hair like iron wire, eyes like blue glass — rose and inclined his head as if we had all reached an agreement. He smiled the kind of smile that is practiced and honest both, and the words he used were simple and dangerous: “Good morning,” he said. “You look like you could use a proper breakfast.”

I took my seat. I crossed my fingers so even they felt strange and new. Outside, the city kept raining. Inside, the table was set for two.

samples.prompt: Humans figured out in the future that mothernature was slowly killing the human race by evolving viruses and climate change. You are the last human to be alived.
samples.output:
I am the last human alive. The sentence feels ridiculous when I say it out loud, like something a child would shout into an empty auditorium and then wait for an audience to clap. There is no one to clap for me. There are only gulls, and the slow clap of a storm passing over an ocean that has swallowed half the coastlines I grew up knowing.

The city is a fossil. I walk past towers draped in ivy and satellite dishes like discarded shells. From certain rooftops you can still see the outlines of the old roads, the veins that once fed a civilization. Now those veins are green and slick and full of water in places. In the shadow of a mall transformed into a wetland, a heron waits patiently on a rusted car roof. It looks at me with neither curiosity nor contempt; it looks at me as if I am one small, transient weather pattern.

We found out what was happening in fits and starts, in papers and debates and frantic emergency sessions that read like a record of a species trying to unlearn optimism. It was not a conspiracy at the margins of science so much as a pattern — evolutionary pressure and systemic feedbacks aligning like gears. Viruses, bacteria, parasites: they didn’t so much wake up and decide to exterminate us as they adapted to the niche we created. Dense cities, global travel, industrial agriculture, antibiotics, antivirals — we had made an ecosystem that favored pathogens that could exploit us fastest and best.

At first it was the obvious stories: faster mutations in RNA viruses, zoonotic spillovers from animals driven into human habitats by deforestation and warming. Then came the subtler horrors: pathogens that spread through infrastructure — colonizing water systems, hitchhiking in aerosols formed by heating seas, surviving longer on plastics. They evolved not out of malice but because those who could transmit through concrete and asphalt lived. The selection pressure was brutal and efficient.

Climate change was the other hand of the same mechanism. Heat waves selected for crops that failed; fires removed soil and memory from the land; floods rearranged the geography of towns so that food systems could no longer find their bearings. The climate didn’t conspire against us either; it adjusted to the mass of carbon and aluminum and concrete we forced upon it. But in those adjustments — in the release of methane from thawing permafrost, in the alteration of ocean currents and salinity — the things that sustained us came undone. The weather became an uncooperative organ, refusing to do the work we had relied on it to do.

We tried everything. We vaccinated at speeds history never recorded before; we hacked viruses with CRISPR like tinkerers trying to pry the right gear loose from a clock. We seeded the atmosphere with reflective particles, built walls of algae and graphene across coasts. We rerouted rivers, bred new grains that could tolerate higher salinity and heat. For a while, these worked in patches, like bandages on a mangled limb.

But every intervention was another pressure. Pathogens that could bypass our vaccines rose like weeds into the cracks. Geoengineering had unexpected side effects on precipitation and phytoplankton. The very complexity of the systems we tried to control generated new paths for collapse. It was not that we were careless; we were too clever by half, inventing solutions without stepping back to see the whole of the organism we were in.

There was a name for it in the final years: biotic regulation. It was poetic and morally loaded. Some argued it implied intention. Others insisted it was merely emergent behavior — the planet’s many parts finding a new equilibrium, regardless of what we wanted. The language people used reflected what they hoped the answer would be. I wanted it to be mere physics. I wanted the earth to be a thing you could argue with on the basis of data and win. But the pattern read like a decision: those branches of life that adapted away from human dominance spread; those bound to our structures withered.

I survived by accident and by stubbornness. They called me lucky at first. I had an immune quirk — a receptor configuration that made infection by several of the late-stage viral strains improbable — and I’d been off-grid when the last waves of contagion did what contagions do. I was in a research shelter in the mountains when the cities went dark, a place built to be isolated, with a little lab and enough supplies to embarrass a small country. The irony is heavy: I was there because I’d spent my life trying to understand the enemy. I used to joke that if biology was a chess game, I wanted to know all the opening moves. I learned chess and forget how to keep a garden.

For a long time after, I lived like a museum curator of collapse. I kept logs and samples in freezers that hummed like reminders. I read the last papers and listened to the last emergency broadcasts, the voices of committees and ministers who had, for all their intelligence, been running to catch up with a planet that had been running a very different race all along.

Loneliness is not a steady ache; it is a shape-shifting companion. Some mornings I woke with the idea of starting again, of teaching the gulls to bring me fish in exchange for breadcrumbs. Other nights it was the echo of a laughter that I could no longer locate and the sudden, painful knowledge that no one else would ever laugh at the same thing again. There are ghosts everywhere. Not only the ghosts of people, but the ghosts of our systems: irrigation channels that no longer reach fields, servers whose heat no one minds anymore, a stadium now a lake where carp leap in noon sun.

Sometimes, when the wind is kind and the sky is mercifully clear, I sit at the rim of an old highway and talk to what I have come to call Mother. I know she is not a person in any literal sense, but names are the way we make the world manageable. I speak to the planet as one speaks to someone responsible — neither accusing nor excusing, simply trying to be honest.

“You didn’t have to do it this way,” I tell her. “You didn’t have to make us fail like this.”

The gulls wheel. A breeze comes that smells of salt and something like green rot, like composting memory. If I am imagining her, she is a vast presence in the way the sea is a presence — indifferent and integral. If I am more honest, Mother is a set of processes — feedback loops and evolutionary forces so old and patient that our species looked like a new season to her. She pruned. She recycled. She was not cruel; she was restorative on her own scale, removing what had become too dominant, rebalancing resources.

There are moments when I feel anger. I remember a child’s face in a photograph I took once — a pyramid of spiky hair and chocolate smeared at the corner of a mouth. We loved, we made music, we made tiny incandescent lights that danced in our palms, and then we taught the world how to become inhospitable to us. Anger, though, is a small, hot thing that cools quickly when you are the sole keeper of a species’ legacy. It becomes a polite fuel for action: keep a seed bank, maintain a few libraries, write things down.

Writing is my small rebellion. I scratch into paper salvaged from a school library and tuck it into a bottle. I leave these bottles where an animal might carry them, or in the crook of a tree with a barred window to the sky, hoping something will find them. Maybe nothing will. Maybe in ten thousand years a bird will nest in the hollow of a post-industrial chestnut and find a scrap of human grammar and think it a nest lining like any other.

Perhaps we were necessary for the planet to wake up. Perhaps we were a fever the earth needed to break. I do not know whether to hate or to forgive. I vacillate with the weather. In the end I choose to do neither; I choose to remember.

At sundown I stand at the old university pond. Dragonflies skim the water where once students skipped classes. I drop a pebble into the dark and watch the ripples. They will travel out and disperse until the surface is indifferent again. That image comforts me. There is a peace in being part of a process that is larger than oneself. There is a peace in knowing that my species' end is part of a history that will not end — life will continue, different and new, with its own music.

When it is time, I will lie down under the roots of an elm and let the soil have me. If stories have weight, then I will be a story for the future rains to read. Perhaps in some long-cleared patch the first green thing that pushes through the earth above my bones will be sweeter for the memory of us. Perhaps not.

For now, I light a small lamp in the ruins and read until the pages blur, until my eyes forget the difference between letters and the curvature of a wing. I am the last human alive — a monstrous, beautiful fact. I keep moving. I keep keeping. I speak into the wind and the gulls answer with their harsh bright notes. Mother listens, or she does not. Either way, she is vast and indifferent and magnificent. I place my palm on the trunk of the elm and let the bark be the last touch between a child of the earth and the earth itself.

When they tell this story in whatever species long after has the capacity for telling, they will not know the nuances of our laughter or the exact timbre of our regrets. They will have instead the rubrics of what we were, as plants and storms and bacteria recollect their own slow histories. I will not be there to demand the details. I will only have mattered. For the time being, that has to be enough.

samples.prompt: As a collector of old and ancient magical artifacts, one prize has always eluded you... and now you must decide if the risk is worth it.
samples.output:
By the time your fingers learn the language of age — the weight of a coin no catalog records, the hairline seam by which an amulet betrays a later repair — you also learn to read the margin notes of desire. My house is full of them: shelves that sag with the patient gravity of the centuries, cases of glass and brass where little dangers doze. A bell that rings only during eclipses hangs in the entryway and never rings for me; a jar of captured dawn sits on the sill, cloudy as a cloud held for ransom. I call them my prizes because what else can I call a life's work? Each object completes a puzzle of time: a shard that keeps a memory safe, a compass that points to lost things, a coin that tells you which lie you were born into.

There is, however, one thing no shelf has ever held. For thirty-seven years and counting I have given it a name — the Unmaking Mirror, the Mirror of Leaving, the Lacuna Glass — and with every new appellation it seemed to shrink and grow, always receding. Some things are hidden because they are remote; others are hidden because they remember what you were before you wanted them. The Lacuna was both. It was said to have been folded from the first absence, forged in a temple whose walls were plastered with erased letters. It doesn't revive the dead; it alters the ledger of existence. You put an image face-up and choose a thing to unmake: a pestilence, a vow, a sorrow. The mirror balances its scale with the one rule that keeps barters human: for every thing unmade, a memory of equal weight is taken from the offerer. You can make wars forget; you might lose the name of your mother. You can make a city disappear; you might lose the sound of your child's laugh.

When Maeve died, I taught myself calculation anew. She was everything to counterbalance my cupboards of collected quiet. Names do funny arithmetic: one missing person weighs more than a dozen amulets. I'm not sure now why it took me so long to seek the Lacuna. Pride, perhaps. Or the superstition of the trade — that to fetch one singularly dangerous piece was to invite the other pieces to remember wanting more. Or maybe I was afraid to be the kind of man who would trade anything to undo what death had taught me to carry.

Then word came through the old channels: a monastery in the high fissure was selling its reliquary. It had worked for kings and cautioned saints, it had been sealed by one of my earliest teachers, Ari, who had once said over a cup of stupidly bitter tea, "Some things are preserved because we are not ready to mourn." Ari's handwriting on the parchment was a scrawl jagged with warning: the Lacuna will not be taken lightly. The monks called it an act of mercy; a dealer called it salvation; the last of them called it a sin. The world, in its predictable indecency, decided to auction mercy to the highest bidder.

By the time I arrive, the monastery smells like wet stone and the kind of cold that slips into joints and memories alike. The Lacuna sits behind iron, in a room lined with relics tucked away as if ashamed. It is smaller than the stories painted it: a good mirror is never showy. Its frame is nothing — a filament of onyx with hairline veins that seem to run like dried blood or dried ink. When I stand before it, I do what collectors do; I hold my breath and listen. The mirror doesn't shout with power. It looks like anything else you might put at the foot of your bed and find yourself in at the end of every night.

Sister Riva is the custodian. She is very old but younger than the relics; her face is the map of someone who had decided, once upon a while, she could bear the burden. "It will ask you to pay," she says. "That is the mirror's law. Choose badly and it will spend you clean. We could burn it. We could break it. But that would let its absence become another absence. We will no longer be responsible for erasing the ledger for someone desperate enough to buy it."

My money means nothing here. I have coin, yes; I have connections. All the procuring in my life has never been for the sake of coin. What it comes down to is simple: to use the mirror you must offer a memory of equal weight. Equal weight. There is no scale you can measure on a table. The mirror knows the currency of your suffering better than you do.

I think first of giving up my knowledge of places. I consider unmaking the taste of tea that reminds me of the day Maeve laughed in sunlight. I think of offering the knowledge of where certain objects are hidden; it would be a simple transaction in outward terms. But meters of memory are not only our maps; they are the scaffolding of ourselves. To hand over a topology is to hand over half your hands. The mirror, in the way of certain things, is less cruel than I am: it will not let me be cleverer than the cost.

There is time in that monastery, and that is both blessing and danger. I pace as if pacing could rearrange the ledger. The thought that keeps pressing like something under my tongue is straightforward: trade my years of collecting for Maeve. I could wake up forgetting auctions and provenance, forget the smell of old vellum and the fierce joy I have felt at uncovering a shard, and she would be here at my knees. I picture her tiny feet padding across the stone floors, her hair in a tangle, the way she used to say my name like it was a joke the world had not yet heard. The memory of her does not sit like a thing that might be balanced. It is a sun that both warms and burns my day.

"Are you afraid of losing yourself?" Sister Riva asks.

"I'm afraid of remembering wrong," I answer. There is truth in that. To win her back by losing the story of why the attic is neat or why a coin against the light matters would be to exchange one story for another. The Lacuna does not create new tales for you; it simply moves the punctuation.

You learn, in a long life of collecting, that some prizes are for keeping and others for giving away. You also learn the very subtle transformation that occurs when you finally reach for the thing that has always eluded you: you become honest about what you will do to claim it. All the catalog entries, all the polite haggling across walnut tables, all the quiet thefts under lamplight — they had been practice for this moment where mathematics meets need.

I do the calculation again: trade the memory of Maeve's funeral for her laughter; trade the taste of grief for the warmth of her tiny palm. The mirror will take something of equal weight, but it does not have to be equal in kind. Maybe the memory of my father — the man who taught me to hide things — is not as heavy. Maybe the mirror will let me keep the story of why I collected things if I give up the knack of collecting itself. A life without the taste of finding would be like a painter who can see but not hold colors. I have been living on the adrenaline of discovery for decades; what if I agreed to wake without that tag? What if I could have her back, and all my glass cabinets would become pretty, useless things?

In the end, it is not mathematics that decides me; it is a sound. It is the echo, in my memory, of a small laugh I hear only when I allow myself to be punished by hope. I hold out my hand to the mirror. Sister Riva watches without flinching. "You will forget the excitement," she says. "You will wake among your things and not feel the hunger for discovery that has kept you alive. You will be ordinary again."

Then I am not afraid. There are other ordinary things I have not yet held: Maeve's hand, the soft breath on my cheek, the smell of rain on warm stone. I have lived long enough among treasures to understand that some cost leads to a life you will prefer. I place the image of my daughter against the glass, saying her name like a prayer and an inventory together. The mirror takes. The absence brushes me clean like a winter wind.

When I open my eyes in my own home, the cabinets look like friends I do not recognize. The pieces sit like strangers who have come to a party without knowing how they are related. The itch that had always been at the base of my skull — the one that told me there was something to be found just past the next hill — is gone. My hands know the weight of things, but my heart is a place of unfamiliar furniture. There is a note under the ledger: Sophie, my attendant, writes, "He is in the garden," and my feet take me there because my bones remember routes their names no longer name.

Maeve is at the garden gate. She is not spectral. She is wet and alive and furious with me for letting her go in the first place. I touch her face and the feeling is immediate and monstrous and perfect. My head is an empty museum and my arms are full of the only thing that will ever make sense again.

If you ask whether the risk was worth it, I can only promise truth: the decision was less a wager than a correction. The man who loved collecting until his last breath is gone; what sits in his place is, disappointingly, nothing special to anyone who knew me as a dealer of wonders. I cannot tell you the provenance of the coin in my pocket or why the bell in the entryway never rang for me. I have, in the purchase of a life, bought myself ordinary morning. Maeve tells me stories I have apparently told her before. I laugh at things I no longer remember making me laugh.

There is, in the end, no ledger that can be read by others. The world keeps its balance in ways I will never chart again. What I can do is cradle a living, noisy child who thinks my longings were always incidental. Some collectors keep objects to remember; I traded a world of remembering for the person who made remembering worth the effort. If that is foolish, then let someone else call me a fool. When Maeve leans against me and tells me about the kite she will want tomorrow, the risk — every hidden stair, every late-night bargain — seems, for the first time in a long life, like something I can set down.

samples.prompt: 2 WW2 Pilots develop rivalry after multiple dogfights. Finally one of them dies.
samples.output:
The first time Tom Mercer saw him, the man in the other cockpit was just a silhouette against a morning sun: a dark speck that sliced with uncanny calm through a squall of Spitfires and Hurricanes. Tom had been a flight lieutenant for three months and had already learned to hate the sound of Messerschmitt engines. He learned, too, to hate the look of a pilot who didn't strain, who seemed to glide through the chaos with stolid contempt for the bullets and fire around him.

They tangled over a convoy in the Channel. Tom remembers the first second in slow-motion—the way the Messerschmitt dove as if the sky itself could be filed at an angle, slipping through tracer like a fish through weed. The other pilot's movements were economy and grace; he scored on an enemy bomber without even turning his head. They split, circled, and by some private calculus of fate found each other again. They fought like two knives in a fist: brief, intimate exchanges in which every pull, that fraction of throttle, every glance mattered. When the smoke cleared, Tom had a fresh shrapnel in his thigh and an adrenaline thinning like iced tea. The Messerschmitt banked away, and in the light between clouds Tom saw, painted near the enemy's cockpit, a small wolf-head—black, but precise. Around his own tail, instinct made him scrape his paint with a fingernail and notch a little hawk, the mark of his squadron. He did not know then that the wolf-head would become as familiar as the needle of his compass.

They began to meet like weather. Over the French coast in the autumn when orange leaves were still clinging to trees below, over radar-rattled nights escorting heavy bombers—always the same profile, the same measured turn, the same logic of flight. Twice Tom lost altitude when spun by the German's uncanny stalling tactics. Once, Tom saw the wolf-head give a small salute—no words, of course, but the oval of pilot visor lifting in gesture as they crossed. Tom did not think in phrases then; he thought of fuel gauges and lines of fire. Yet, even in the pressure of combat, a human recognition uncoiled: there was a man in that cockpit as sure as the Bulova on his wrist. There were letters home in both of their kitbags, and the same occasional worry about a mother or girlfriend sleeping while they were up threading the sky.

News traveled in fragments: a Messerschmitt ace who had been seen peeling off in the middle of a dogfight only to help a damaged wingmate back to friendly territory; a British Spitfire that had bent a flak-fragmented elevator back into service with a hammer and a curse. Pilots talked about style—aggressive, patient, clinical. Names became shorthand: "the wolf" and "the hawk." Men, for comfort, turned them into story and then into legend. In the mess, over warm tea and stale biscuits, Tom was asked more than once if the wolf would come again. He laughed it off. No one wanted to say across a crowded table that it felt like the world had two men who knew each other better than it knew them.

Dogfights are a particular kind of courtship: they require you to read someone more thoroughly and more quickly than in any other moment of life. Tom learned the wolf's rhythm; it told him when the other pilot would roll out of a dive, when he would feint a climb. The wolf learned, in return, Tom's impatience for a head-on, the moment he picked to pretend to go slow and then snatch speed. They played. They kept score in the only currency the sky dealt: close calls, forced strap-jumps, a wing clipped but flight preserved. On a lonely airfield at dusk, Tom sometimes took his pen and made another small hawk behind the cockpit glass, and imagined—ridiculous, comfortingly reciprocal—that the wolf was sketching faintly the same black wolf on some distant fuselage.

There were times, Tom would later admit, when he felt something that matched affection. He would aim where the wolf's shoulder might be if there were shoulders over steel and string—his barrel a threat but his hands steady not with malice but with attention. Once, in a rare low-altitude skirmish, poor visibility choked the formation and an ally went spinning down towards a ridge. The wolf dove without hesitation, weaving gunfire and flak, long enough to put the spinning aircraft back onto level air. Tom remembers the wolf's silhouette soched with smoky tracer and, for a heartbeat, saluting with an empty hand while fingers refused to let the throttle go. The pilot they saved stumbled in the cockpit like a man blown through a door; the wolf rolled away with the same distant calm, and that night in his bunk Tom lay awake thinking of what war was doing to them, carving lines of habit into men who had been boys.

The rivalry hardened like old iron in the winter of '44. Normandy had become a scab of battle and both men had hardened into aces—reliable, admired, and paper-thin in ways that telegrams would prove improper to address. There came then the kind of weather that decides wars—limitless blue with pockets of cotton-white cloud—and missions that no longer had the intimacy of clever tactics but the brutality of numbers: formation upon formation, wings of metal weaving a lattice of death below. That day, the Luftwaffe was thinning, and the RAF was stretched. Tom's squadron was part of a fighter sweep to which he attached himself with the background hum of habit.

They met over a shattered town where houses had been gutted into charred ribs. It was the most exquisite, unrepeatable kind of sky for them: long sightlines, few clouds for concealment, and the sun hung like an open coin, glare that split the world into shadow and bright. Tom saw the wolf-head not as a spot but as a movement—two rolls, a left cut, and then a clip of Munich Blue across the fuselage. They collided inside a chamber of gunfire. Tracer stitched the air like coarse thread. Tom pulled up at the exact moment the wolf should have pulled down if history held; the wolf tried a barrel roll, and then something—maybe a splash of flak, maybe a hit he had not expected—bent the Messerschmitt's tail.

Tom had the shot. He saw the fuselage shudder, sparking like a struck wire. The wolf's plane wrenched, a terrible piece of bad geometry, and was falling with the slow mercy of a man who inhales his last breath. Protocol and training screamed for the hunter to complete his job, to follow through until the enemy was a name on a sheet. But another voice, older than rank and younger than regret, told Tom to veer aside. He did, and in that fraction of indecision watched the Messerschmitt keep falling. It burst in a bloom of fire against the green—a bright, obscene flower. There was no parachute visible from where Tom was; the wreckage hit the trees and took with it any soft human noise.

The debrief afterwards was sterile. "Brought down by ground fire," someone read off a list. Names appeared as dots in a ledger. Tom's debrief officer asked the required questions: altitude, time, ammunition expended. He filed the forms with the mechanical precision of any bureaucrat close to a map. That night Tom went to the edge of the field where burned grass met darker earth and sat with his knees pulled to his chest. He had been taught to count kills and the survival of comrades as the two pillars of their ledger. This didn't fit anything he had been taught.

He thought of the wolf, of the precise black head, of the boxer-like way the man took punches from the sky and kept dancing. He thought of the times the wolf had saved a friend, the times his own bullets had found nothing but fuselage and angle and air. There is a small, private rite a pilot performs when he comes close to another's death and is not responsible: he remembers. Names are not enough; faces, gestures, the scratch of a pilot's letter, the exact cadence of a laugh.
