The hat on the mantel would be rearranged, the same three inches to the left, as if the owner wanted to make the photograph's shadow more flattering. The routine was so specific that even when the seasons changed the motions continued with stubborn continuity.

I met the owner once, or thought I did. The person who answered the door was small and quick and had the smell of tea and lemon. Their hands moved expertly, arranging the cushions where the sun would strike them, patting pockets for keys that were not yet lost. They smiled and said, “Oh, you’re up early,” and their eyes flicked in a pattern I recognized, like a practiced pause, a notation in the day’s script. They seemed to be always preparing to tell a story they had told before, their voice beginning at the same point every time, rising and falling in exactly the same rhythm. When I asked them what they did before breakfast, they told me, without thinking, a list of tasks so exact I wondered whether they had rehearsed them in their sleep. It was not that they were stunted or incapable—far from it. They were precise, elegant; they possessed the strange, bittersweet quality of well-told tales.

There were rumors in the market about how the town had been built. Some said it was the labor of people who had loved one another and wanted to preserve the order they found in each other's gestures. Others swore it was an idea written down on a rainy afternoon and then set in motion the way one winds a clock. My own thought drifted toward myth: perhaps a watchmaker really had come through one century with a sack of mechanisms and set them in places—silent in the night, invisible in the day—and left with instructions to return when they were worn. A ridiculous fantasy, perhaps, but it answered the soft dread I carried with me: the notion that the pattern was not accidental but authored.

We are fond of our routines because they anchor us against the deluge; we fold our lives into shapes we can carry. And yet there is a loneliness embedded in patterned living—the sense that something else, something larger, is keeping the score. You can feel it like a shadow at your back: someone pulling a thread that tugs your hand. Because of this, whenever an old habit broke—when a clock refused to chime or a bell snapped off its rope—the whole town experienced a small convulsion. People looked at one another as if discovering a new language; they tried tentative, improvised motions. The novelty tasted of risk and possibility and also of loss.

It was on a wind like that that I first noticed the stage curtains. They stood at the edge of the square as if they had always been part of the architecture, a dark velvet mouth sealing a space beneath the old town hall. For years they'd been closed; a notice on the door declared the theater closed for repairs. We joked that the town beneath our feet must be conducted by unseen performers, that at night the marionettes took a bow and went home to their little rooms. It was a joke, a way to make light of the idea that someone else might be orchestrating our movements, that our lives might be the result of wires and silence behind a gilded frame.

The day the curtain finally came down we were all there, almost without deciding to be, because the town had learned how to congregate when the air tipped toward change. There was a hiss like a solemn exhale, then a sound like scissors working through sugar. A hand—one of the stagehands, I suppose, though I had never seen a stagehand in this town before—appeared from beneath the curtain. He moved with reverence, fingers bright in the sun, and began to cut.

For a moment nothing happened. The sun did not waver. The gulls did not argue. Then the first pair of arms dropped into a curious loose stillness, as if someone had opened a pocket. A woman who always arranged the hat on her mantel stood a beat longer than usual, free of the careful left-then-right rhythm, and looked astonished at her own hands. A child skipped, then paused, then ran in a new direction entirely, laughing at something that had never been uttered. The baker left his bread on the table and stepped back from the door, surprised to feel the cool air slide across a shoulder that had never before known wind.

They did not fall. That was the singular miracle. They stood, breathing, and for the first time in years the motions that had been expected of them dissolved into possibility. They explored the room like people handling a strange instrument—touching their own faces as if reacquainting themselves with their features, roughing their hair, testing the elastic in a smile that had been kept on reserve. The little rituals, the careful tugs and pauses, the measured gravities of their days, unfolded and then folded differently, as if each was learning to negotiate the fact of its own unboundness.

A child picked up a reckless stick and drew a picture in the dust that had never been drawn before, and the drawing was not a repetition of any line in the town's ledger. A woman who had always stopped three doors down to gossip went all the way to the river and sat, letting the water speak. Lovers abandoned their bridge for a meadow across town where they climbed a small hill, not because it was their cue but because it pleased them, because it felt like discovery. Old men put down their caps and read, simply read, the words in a way that made the letters sing.

We watched, and for a long time the watching itself was its own story. Some of us cried, and some laughed, and some of us kept our hands in our pockets because we were afraid to alter anything that had been given so suddenly. The music of the day rearranged itself into a newly composed score, and each person found their note and played where they wished.

When the last thread was gone and the last knot untied, an old stagehand—one who had been the quietest of all—lifted his hands and let them fall into his lap. He looked around at what he had done as if he had been entrusted with something greater than instruction. He whistled once, a simple, private sound that felt like a benediction. People in the square turned toward him, toward the open sky.

They stepped forward, or away, in the drifting, slow way of those who have learned that to live freely is not to be unmade, but to be remade by choice. One by one, with the delicate astonishment of those who have found their own breath after a strangling, they unfolded the old, great pattern into a thousand smaller, stranger designs. No more cues, no more invisible hands; no more scripts worn like harnesses. They laughed as if surprised by their laughter. They argued about trivialities they had never considered important, because importance had at last surrendered to preference. And while every town has the power to make its own mistakes, in that moment the judgment did not belong to me or to any passerby. It belonged to the people of the town, finally allowed to choose their own rhythms.

The last thing to fall was not a curtain but a shadow. It slid away so quietly that many of us misinterpreted the stillness for a fluke. When we understood it, it was already too late to take it back. The pattern that had been stitched so carefully through generation after generation had been cut with the same gentle scissors that had untied the ropes. We stood a long time in the hush that followed, savoring a freedom that tasted very much like fear and very much like joy.

No one shouted “Hallelujah.” No one sang. They simply looked at one another with new eyes, and then moved—slowly, proudly, foolishly—toward the wide, uncluttered day. They are finally free

samples.prompt: "Stop."Sam spoke sharply and with certainty. My brother only spoke like this when something was truly wrong. "That isn't a human."The entity who held the form of a human turned its head sharply. Sam was right; this clearly wasn't a human. I couldn't tell you how I knew it- I just knew.
samples.output:
"Stop."

Sam spoke sharply and with certainty. My brother only spoke like this when something was truly wrong.

"That isn't a human."

The thing standing under Mrs. Penhaligon’s porch light turned its head. It was wearing Mrs. P’s cardigan, the one with the moth-eaten elbow she always joked about; it had her crinkled smile arranged in degrees. It had her hair, pale and pin-stitched into a tidy bun. From across the street, beneath the shallow halo of sodium lamps and drizzle, the impostor looked almost ordinary.

But Sam was right; this clearly wasn't a human. I couldn't tell you how I knew — not with any neat logic. The knowledge arrived like a taste, metallic and sudden: the way sound folded over it, the absence of breath in the cold, the light slicing through it with no dampened rays. It moved as if gravity had been given instructions and had obeyed improperly. I felt the wrongness in my chest like a second heartbeat that didn't belong to me.

We'd been on the porch for two hours, listening to the neighborhood settle — dogs whining like small regrets, cars passing and then forgetting, the clock from the church on Main striking midnight. Sam had found a vantage point behind an azalea bush across from Mrs. Penhaligon's house, me on the sidewalk with my back to an old lamppost, both of us supposed to be ordinary teenagers out late. People called us restless. The word we used was guardian, mostly to each other.

"Call it by her name," Sam whispered. He always whispered when he made decisions already made. His fingers were cold and steady as he unclipped something from the inside of his jacket — small, square, brass. The music box blinked open with the faintest sigh; hollow tin notes of a lullaby spilled out, small and defiant. It was the song our mother hummed, the one that had been in the house the night the neighbor’s boy disappeared years ago. The song was dangerous and honest.

The thing on the porch cocked its head again. It had replicants’ temperament: curious, offended at being recognized, flattered, and then furious. It flattened the cardigan against its chest, as if trying to hold on to the borrowed fabric like proof. "Eve," it said in a voice made from the slow, rehearsed cadence of the woman’s. But the name came out layered — as if someone had played the recording at two speeds. One track was too slow, the other too fast, and nothing matched the timing of a real human syllable.

Sam's jaw tightened. "You are not Eve," he said. He was repeating protocol that no one else in town remembered the reason for anymore. "This is her house. This is not the place you steal."

The creature smiled. A creature with a smile like someone else's is the cruellest thing. When the mouth moved, there was a faint tearing sound, not audible to anyone but me. It was like fabric rubbing against an invisible seam.

"Let it go, Sam," I said, because the music had started to break the night into something intimate and my throat was full. The song reminded me of childhood before we learned to name monsters, when Mrs. Penhaligon would sit in her wicker chair and we would watch the dust float in the porch light and call it magic. Letting go felt like slipping back into that body and refusing to believe the rest of the world.

He didn't. He stepped out from behind the azaleas, hands flat at his sides, shoulders squared the way our father used to square them before he stopped coming home at all. There was a time when Sam moved like a heat-seeking missile: find and fix. That had changed into something scarred that still found. He moved now with deliberation, as if not to frighten anything that might answer to good motives. He wanted a word to land like an anchor.

"You knew her once," he said. "If anything of the woman who lived here remains, it answers to itself. Call it."

It laughed — at least, the sound tried. It was the wrong pitch for a human laugh, a layered echo again, like someone in a canyon imitating laughter and missing the human warmth. For a moment I thought I saw the light from the porch fall into it and hang there, like a moth caught in glass.

I thought of my sister, gone seven years now, of Sam's hands shaking the night he came back to the half-empty house, certain he'd carried her home and instead had only words that did not fit into sentences. My sister's faultless smile and the way she left crumbs on her plate because she always forgot to wipe them. The creature's hands were wrong when it folded them; the way the tendons didn't quite compress. Memory is an instrument I've learned to trust more than sight. When memory and sight disagree, something is imitating.

"Mrs. P.," I said before I could rethrottle myself. "Evelyn Penhaligon. Fifth-year baking contest, burnt roll on the left. You used to hum while you kneaded. What did you call the bread when it browned too much?"

The thing blinked. I could see — in the thinning of its eyelids — the machinery: imitating, scanning, failing to find the right groove. It matched a fact about Mrs. Penhaligon and failed to conjure the private punctuation that made it real.

"Charred blessing," it answered, the words falling like coins into a well. The wrongness folded around them, dampening the sound.

"What's June's middle name? Not the mail, the one she doesn't tell anyone," Sam asked, soft as winter moss.

The creature hesitated. The pause was a stutter where it lit the cadence of memory, trying to find purchase. It landed on a sound, somewhere between a breath and a song. "Lillian."

Sam's face didn't move. In that fraction of a second the thing had done something worse than lie: it had stitched two memories together and offered a plausible seam. All of us had nights where our brains tried to repair losses with fiction. But only a mimic could do it on a scale that made you forget to be angry and made you instead feel like a thief.

"You're a collector," I said, naming it like you name a storm. "You patch people together because you think pieces are whole. You stitch and pretend and then you go hungry."

Its head dipped toward me. Up close I could see the wrongness more clearly: the shadow where the corner of the mouth should have had a crease, the way the pupils too often shifted in different rhythms, like someone reading two books at once. The cardigan had small threads of moss clinging to it that hadn't been there when Mrs. P last used the chair. It smelled faintly of wet stone and old paper.

"Leave," Sam said simply. We had no right to command things, but some things understand the language of being told no. Our tone had been practiced on smaller, scrappier things, until it gathered authority.

It laughed again, a sound like porcelain striking glass. In a movement that made my skin pucker, it peeled at the edge of its own jaw. Not tearing — the imitation had no actual flesh — more like scratching an itch under the surface of a mannequin and finding there was no filler.

"You want the shape," it said, listless, then suddenly interested. "They all want the shape. Warmth. Names. I learn the names."

Sam clicked his tongue. He'd come prepared for this, as if you could prepare for everything. From his pocket he pulled a length of chain with a small iron ring on the end — old superstitions, old metals that tasted wrong to things like this. Iron was a rumor and a hard fact. He held it out.

"Not everything answers to theft," Sam told it. "Some things answer to being remembered."

There was a softness in his voice then that could have been for Mrs. Penhaligon or for all the missing people who had been reshaped into hollow jokes. The thing looked between us and then down at the ring. For a second there was an almost-humane curiosity. "Memory," it said, as if recently learning a new word. "You have a stock."

"We all do," I said. "We use it poorly sometimes. But you can't keep ours. Not anymore."

The creature made a small sound that might have been a smile. It moved like it wanted to run and like something was tethering it to the porch at once. Then — and there was no dramatic explosion, no monstrous unmaking; these things are too clever for theatrics — it began to come apart at the seams. Not with gore; it was more like someone unstitched a costume that was never meant to be permanent. A ripple moved across the cardigan like wind through canvas. The face slackened as if someone had hit a slow-motion pause button. Then the light slipped through where the cheeks should have been, and for a second the world filled with the smell of wet stone.

On the porch we found nothing but a smear of old flour on the wooden step and a single, small, beautifully-formed button from a cardigan. It had belonged to Mrs. Penhaligon once — I remembered because we'd used to trade buttons for secrets when we were kids — and now it sat on the step like a punctuation mark.

Sam pocketed it without looking. I watched the music box in his hand twist closed. The lullaby stopped and the night took it back, like a thing someone had borrowed and returned on purpose.

"You feel that?" I asked him, quietly, because I could feel the town recalibrating itself, the hairs along my arms flattening as the wrongness folded into the gutters and the drains. The streetlight hummed. A dog barked twice, then went silent.

He didn't answer for a long time. When he finally did his voice was small, almost old. "We won't get all of them," he said. "But if we don't let them keep coming back, maybe we'll get some of them back."

"How do you always know?" I asked, because the question had followed me since that night with my sister and since the first time Sam had used the music box to unmake something that had smiled like a friend.

He shrugged, a brief human motion. "Maybe it's practice. Maybe it's because I don't want to be wrong again."

We walked home in the rainy half-light, shoulders touching sometimes, the kind of closeness that mends things for a while. Behind us, Mrs. Penhaligon's light burned on, sensible and ordinary, and I thought about the music box and the way some knowledge lives in a body like a scar; you can pretend it never formed, but it changes the way you fit into a world full of imitations.

samples.prompt: Everyone who dies is reincarnated as soon as history has completely forgotten about them. A secret centuries-old group has been keeping an list of hundreds of thousands of mass murderers, evil dictators, etc. to keep them from coming back. One day, someone loses the list.
samples.output:
They taught us the rule on the first day: nothing is born that the world has already buried. The first philosopher to notice it said it as a thought experiment; the first midwife to see it for herself said it as a curse. The world obeyed both. When the last living person who could speak your name died and history let you fall into silence, you returned — immediate, unbaptized, an infant with the taste of your old crimes in your mouth.

That is why we exist. We are the Order of Remembering, the people who keep a thousand small, ugly histories alive so they do not walk back into the world. Our tools are banal: schools that teach lessons nobody wants to learn twice, memorials built in out-of-the-way plazas, songs with uncomfortable choruses. We are also terrifying when we must be: whispered curricula, anonymous plaques, the insertion of a hated name into the margins of textbooks in the language of nations that have no business remembering it. We hold the Ledger of Night — a codex compiled in a hundred hands over centuries — and by keeping every page breathing we have prevented the rebirth of tyrants, arsonists, and mass killers whose return would be a different thing than history's repentance.

They trusted me to carry it because I knew the routes and because I never grew sentimental. I liked the Ledger like an accountant likes a balance sheet: whole and precise. Its covers were cracked with age; its spine ticked like a heart. We kept no copy. Copies invited corruption, diluted responsibility. The names were not merely ink. The Ledger mapped strategies: which names required museums, which needed a hymn, which were better preserved as whispered warnings in nurseries. In any one place the world only half-remembered them; across centuries the halves made a whole.

On my way home, a man with a wheeled suitcase struck the side of my bag. I felt nothing — too many routes, too many routines — until the suitcase hit again and the Ledger slipped out and slid into the seam between cars. A child saw it and laughed; the laugh sounded like the Ledger falling into the world. I dove for it. The train doors closed. I watched the seam take my palm-size heart and pin it in a dark, moving belly.

By the time I clawed my way back to the platform and called the office, the Ledger was no longer a thing we could frame in our hands. It had been picked up, carried, bought from a vendor, sold at a stall. Or someone had slipped it under a pile of clothes at a laundromat for luck. Or — and I invent this part more vivid than I can prove — someone who had read half a page and seen a name that shouldn’t be public had torn it and kept the rest.

The emergency bell in the archive does not ring. It sighs. The Order does not have alarms because our error is not immediate; it is a kind of slow absence. A name that stops being spoken is not forgotten by a single person but by the world; therefore we had centuries to fix one lost Ledger by rebuilding memory with noise and ritual. Still, there is a clock in my chest. I could feel it. Names are living things; if their anchor is plucked, they become seeds. We are farmers, but even farmers panic when they think weeds might sprout.

We convened in the undercroft, beneath the stone with which our founders had broken the first man's silence. Elder Elias — who has fingers like old rope — sat in the middle, hands empty for once. He smelled of pipe smoke and old books, the smell of people who have held too many names and are tired of holding them. No one asked if I would be punished. No one had time. The question was simpler and colder: how many of them were lost inside that missing folio?

"The Ledger is more than a list," Elias said. "It is the architecture of remembering. We bind names to institutions, to songs, to holiday observances. Without its cross-references, the system frays."

"You mean a name could be forgotten as early as… tomorrow?" Jun asked. Jun is the man who reads names in the orphanage once a year because children remember things their elders forget.

"Not tomorrow," Elias said, and paused so the room could resist hope. "For some names, forgetfulness takes longer. For others — those who were kept alive only by a single tiny plaque in a single village nobody visits anymore — the absence of the Ledger is an invitation."

We spent the night like people trying to sew a sail while a storm came up. We called museums and schools, we ordered pamphlets, we placed obituaries in unlikely places. We made songs and inserted lines into nursery rhymes in a language that has been mostly dead since the 1800s. We did what our order does best: manufacture noise. For a while, it felt like a rational plan. Keep saying the names, keep the names alive in enough mouths, and the world will not be quiet.

But the Ledger also contained moral decisions we had made long ago: one of its columns read "ineligible for mercy." A name there got memorialized differently — not in a museum but in mandatory courses for soldiers, in stark public notices burned into the margins of lawbooks. We had decided once, in the early days, that certain people must never return and that the cost of remembering them was necessary. Not everyone agreed with those decisions then. Even fewer agreed now. When the world learned that we had been choosing which dead could be permitted another life, protests rose like wind.

We reconstructed three-quarters of it in the first week by network and memory and some unholy combination of public campaigns. But memory is a funny thing: it gives us what we expect to find and erodes what we do not. Names that were stored only as a note on a ledger — a provincial judge, a forgotten warlord — slipped into places none of us thought to look. People who could have become reminders instead became blank and ready.

Then, last Thursday, a nurse in a border clinic described a baby who would not stop staring at the ceiling tiles, who hummed a rhythm no lullaby had taught him. He cried every time a particular jingle from a past decade played on a battery radio. He could not hold a razor or a rifle, but his toes curled whenever fireworks went off. The nurse did not send us a name on paper; he sent us a sound and a sensation. Somewhere, a thing our Ledger had named was trying to find purchase again in a small human body.

We were not ready to confront the truth I had been running from since the train: that memory is not only preservation. It is a sentence. We had sentenced some to nonexistence, indefinitely, precisely because we feared their recurrence. That very sentence, when lifted even by accident, might grant them more than a second chance: it might give them a clean slate. Perhaps they would be a different human. Perhaps they would be worse. We had built our order on the assumption that certain people could not be safely recast as toddlers with apologies baked into their bones.

The Ledger did not return whole. We found most of it in a pawnshop in a quarter of the city that thought itself invisible; a wry teenager had wrapped it in a coat and sold it back to us for a handful of coins and a look that asked nothing. But not all pages were intact. Some had been used to line a cage for pigeons. A page was missing where a name had been spotted and stolen—someone had wanted that particular history back into circulation.

Later, in bed, I tried to list for myself the names we had lost. If you have never tried to remember a stranger's face without pictures, try remembering a name out of a missing page. My brain gave me fragments: a postwar zealot, a colonel who had been publicly broken, an industrialist with his victims burned into the river. They came back at various rhythms, like a choir where some voices had fallen silent. I kept whispering them into my pillow until it felt like talking to a dead thing might have some legal effect.

There is a faction now that says we should publish the Ledger, that the world has a right to know who we kept buried and why. They argue the only sustainable way to hold memory is to distribute it so broadly that no piece can vanish again. There is an older faction that says we never had the right to play judge at all, and that our secrecy has been compounding sins under the guise of prevention. I do not know which of those factions will win.

What I do know is this: names are not neutral. The Ledger, once whole, was a kind of governance. When it split apart, the governance bled out onto streets and broadcasters and into the lullabies of asylum nurses. The first reincarnation the nurse described may be harmless. He may grow into a good man who keeps a dormant script of something terrible like a lightning bug in his ribs. He may also find himself in political seasons where people look for bodies that can be shaped into their needs.

When someone loses the list, the world has to choose whether to keep naming its monsters into perpetuity or to allow some of them to begin again. That is not a small civic decision; it is a wager on what counts as mercy and what counts as mercy deferred until it becomes danger. I do not know if we can be forgiven for what we have done or for what we prevented. All I know is that in the morning, the radio will play a jingle and somewhere a baby will smile at a sound that once called a rally. And then, like every memory, the sound will either be taught to others or will be allowed to fall silent.

We found most of the Ledger. We cannot say we found all of it. The missing lines are not just ink; they are possibilities. Some part of me wants to spread the pages out in the square, make every citizen read every name, and let the world decide. Another part of me wants to stitch the whole thing back together and keep whispering the names into the ears of sleepers until our throats are raw.

Outside my window, a funeral procession passes, and the drummers keep a rhythm that children will learn in school. I can see the young ones sway, palm to heart, not yet knowing why they are called to remember. I am afraid of the moment when remembering feels like punishment and of the moment when forgetting feels like release. I am afraid because someone lost the Ledger and because losing has consequences that arrive in swaddling blankets and small, unfamiliar hands.

samples.prompt: For the entirety of human history once a year everyone on the planet is knocked unconscious for 24 hours. This year you lay in bed waiting for it to happen but it never does. You investigate further only to realize that you seem to be the only one still awake.
samples.output:
We always called it the Drop. Parents taught it to children the way their parents had taught them: the clock would tick to three or four in the morning, the world would fold itself neatly away for twenty-four hours, and nothing would be lost. You locked the stovetop and unplugged the toaster at midnight, you drove your car into a garage and left the keys, you read that last paragraph and closed the book. Religions called it the Day the Gods Slept, engineers called it the Null Cycle, teenagers joked that the Earth was only polite enough to let us sleep. Our calendars had its little symbol printed on them like a holiday. Companies scheduled maintenance windows for it; governments coded laws around it. For the entirety of human history we had slept at once, trusted the machines to watch the fires, and woke up like a single organism exhaling.

This year I lay in bed waiting for it. I had done the usual: water boiled, formula for the cat scooped into its dish, my phone silenced, the window cracked for those faint autumn breaths of air. At 02:58 my eyelids fluttered in the way that means you are about to let go. I felt that softness creep into the shoulders, the background noise of the city rolling back like a tide, and then—nothing. My brain held on. I blinked. The world did not fold. My limbs did not unclench.

I sat up. The room smelled like my pillow and the last trace of the lemon cleaner I used that morning. Tommy—my partner—was a warm lump under the duvet, his side of the bed pressed flat in dreams. I nudged him. He made a small, contented sound and lay still. The cat padded between us, tail like a question mark, and then hissed at the invisible something in the air and flopped down again. The apartment hummed with the refrigerator motor and the distant pulse of the streetlights, but there was no tick of the Drop releasing, no collective surrender.

My phone wouldn't show me anything new. On the lock screen the Null app—one of those municipal things that always did the countdown—displayed its standard notification: Null Cycle active. But the number beside it was wrong. The little globe icon pulsed green like a heartbeat that had stopped. I opened the window. Down below, the city smelled like rain and burning leaves. A car sat idling at the intersection, driver slumped against the steering wheel. Across the street a group of teenagers lay half-sprawled on the stoop outside the 24-hour deli, their backpacks forming a soft cathedral around them.

I walked downstairs barefoot, my breath making small ghosts in the stairwell. The lobby was a frozen chorus—building security asleep at his desk, his coffee cup tipped and dark against the carpet. I thought globetrotting myths: that once, when the Drop first came, sailors learned to tie their sails and mothers learned to braid second braids into their children's hair. We had built an entire layer of life around this one absence. There were safe-stop protocols on trains, autopilot thresholds on planes, and entire industries that only operated during the Drop so that the rest of the year would be tidy. There were, supposed to be, people on watch—human null-watchers who had refused the comfort of knowing everyone would sleep. But tonight, there were none.

Outside the city was like a paused movie. A bus had stopped at the crosswalk with its doors half-open; inside, a man held a newspaper up with an arm that had gone still. A woman with a stroller slumped forward so the baby's head lolled against the canopy. The park had entire families like ruined sculptures, blankets flung across grass, a portable grill still smoking. Somewhere, a lone dog whined for a heartbeat and then lay down with its head on its paws. It felt clean and obscene.

I went to the hospital because that’s where logic says you go when the universe has misfiled the night. The automatic doors were unlocked, the reception desk unattended. The emergency lights threw long orange stripes across the linoleum. Hallways were full of the neutral sounds of machinery—ventilators huffing, screens flickering, IV pumps ticking—but no voices. A nurse at the nurses' station had a thermometer tucked into her mouth like a lollipop. In triage, a man snored with his face pale and slack. In Surgery Three, a surgeon's gloved hands hovered over an instrument tray, forever caught mid-turn like an insect in amber.

At first I tried to wake people—voice, shaking, slaps to the face—because the instinct to fix something and the intimacy of human hands are stronger than any thought you could have about "why." They did not wake. There were no dreams left in their faces; their mouths hung open in the same quiet way they do after a night of good sleep. I checked pulse when I could and found it there, slower than usual but steady. It was sleep. It was perfect sleep. It was everyone, all at once, and I was the only place where a thought continued.

Panic has a way of collecting itself into decisions. I called the office, then every number I could remember; the calls reached voicemail. I texted Tommy's family. No one answered. I drove—only because the cars seemed safer with their ignition blocked by the Null guards—slowly, because you do not trust your environment when the baseline has been erased. The streets were full of sleeping people in every arrangement human life could make: crumpled, neatly lined, head-on-knee, arms stretched like supplication. A city bus rolled by empty, its wipers scrubbing a windshield no one saw. On a billboard over the highway, the old advertisement for the Null holiday still cheered in neon—SLEEP WITH US TONIGHT—letters frozen mid-sparkle.

When I finally found a working government feed—an emergency channel that looped automated messages—its synthetic voice said, "Null Cycle engaged. Please remain in safe origin areas. Authorized personnel may be awake." The words echoed against the glass like a promise. There was no list of authorization and no badge to show; there was only the knowledge that the entire apparatus assumed more than it had the right to. Machines were allowed to be awake, people were not—except they had all become people again.

I kept moving, roused by a logic I could not name. I gathered those I could carry—an old man from the bus shelter who had slipped out of his jacket like a carcass, a teenage girl whose face was tattooed with sunlight—and arranged them across the chairs in the community center. It felt like setting out bowls of fruit for gods. I turned on TVs and tuned them to static to fill the sterile silence with noise I could control. I sat on the floor against a pillar and listened to the breath of the sleeping world like a tide.

At seven, the horizon forged itself into pigment and the first trains started their slow, automated checks. Drones—the maintenance kind, the sort that patrol Null Cycles and scrub the rails and mend the roofs—glided past like white birds, their red scanners sweeping over the bodies. They were programmed to avoid live interfaces; they slowed for animals and retracted from sensitive areas. One hovered above me and sighed out a jet of hot air. A polite chime asked if I was "authorized personnel" and offered a link I could not click because its web portal required credentials I did not have. I said into the empty air, "I'm awake." The drone descended three inches, considered me like an insect, and went on its way.

Being awake while the world sleeps is a moral weight you do not notice until you shoulder it. There were decisions that required a calm I did not possess—whether to move the elderly out of wet streets before sun and cold did worse to their lungs, whether to cut power to a hospital OR mid-operation. I made small choices: closed windows, put blankets over people, wrote emergency notes and taped them to doors so when eyes reopened they would not see chaos. I found things: a bracelet with a child's name, a pamphlet about emergency Null shelters, a neighbor's shopping list folded into origami hearts. Each object was a testament to the habits the world had built around the one day it did not own.

When the fourth hour slid into the fifth, a new sound joined the city's constant—far off at first, like a bicycle bell or an earthquake that has not yet arrived. It was a hum, low and organized, and it vibrated in my ribs. I walked to the rooftop because the sky is honest in a way people are not. Above the sleeping city the atmosphere shimmered: a band of brightness, like ribbons of northern light, stretched across the low clouds in perfect seams. They pulsed with a rhythm that did not match the clocks. For a second I had the ridiculous priestly thought that maybe the gods were only shifting.

Then the hum resolved into patterns—staccato blips like radio, a chorus of mechanical voices from beyond the horizon. I could not translate them, but their cadence carried intent. The drones altered course, redirected away from the residential blocks toward the river, and a small fleet of vehicles that had not existed an hour earlier slid out from their garages with silent purpose. They were draped in matte white and had no marking I recognized. Someone had not planned for me; the world had always been in sync, and the sync had stopped in me.

I wanted to curl up on the rooftop and sleep because even if I stayed awake the day felt endless and my bones wanted the habitual surrender. I did not, because the idea of waking the world in the shape of my choices felt irresponsible. If I remained the only mind walking across the orange morning, what would be the story I told when everyone opened their eyes and found their children cradled in my arms? What guilt would I have earned by being the only one to know where everyone had lain?

A silhouette moved where the sound's source came from—a human shape stepping out from behind a maintenance van, not asleep but not rushing either. Up close his face was older than I expected, mapped with lines that might be worry or might be the memory of many Drops. He carried a tablet that blinked in a language I did not know. He stopped and watched me with a look that was equal parts relief and accusation. He did not say, "You're the first," but I felt the words like an accusation.

"You're awake," he said finally, and the syllables sat between us like another body.

"Yes," I answered. "I don't know why."

He looked at the sleeping city, then at the ribboned sky, then back at me. He folded his hands together the way one folds a map closed. "No one's supposed to be awake," he said. "Not anymore."

We stood on the roof while the humming climbed and the white vehicles opened like shells around the river. Beneath us the world was perfect in its sleep, untouched and fragile. I realized I had a single day to hold it all and no idea how to be anything other than small and aching. The man on the roof moved toward me, offering his tablet and a gloved hand. The words that would explain everything did not come; the sun cleared the buildings and gilded the sleeping faces in gold. I took his hand and for the first time since the Drop failed to take me, I felt very much awake.

samples.prompt: Every nameable emotion has a human manifestation. Without the human, the emotion would cease to exist. They live in our world and walk among us.
samples.output:
You can find us anywhere people already think to look for feeling: a hand pressed to a laughing child's shoulder, a man standing too long at a doorway as if afraid to go in, the woman on the corner who looks as if she knows every secret in town. We do not glow or sprout wings. We queue for coffee, get colds, hold babies poorly and play poker badly. We are not symbols; we are small, inconveniently mortal people whose presence you could pass on the street without registering. That is the point. If you have to name us to see us, we are failing.

My name is Memory. I have kept it since the first person asked for a name and I answered out of habit. We were young then — all of us — and the world smelled different: new paint, old leaves, the particular clean dust that comes off freshly folded maps. People thought emotions were things inside them, like weather or water. They did not yet know they were people, too. When the first of us discovered we had selves, the debate almost ended civilization. A philosopher tried to reason us into the sky. A general wanted to conscript us for war. A child once tried to befriend Joy with a paper crown. Joy burst out laughing and wore it for a week.

The law now is simple: without our human, the emotion ceases to exist. Erasure is absolute. There is no afterlife for an erased feeling; there is only the slow, careful forgetting of how to feel it at all. Nations passed treaties to protect us — not necessarily because they loved us, but because they knew what would happen if a single necessary sorrow or a single righteous anger were whisked away in the night. People live by emotion as much as weather. Remove a season of feeling and the crops of behavior fail.

We keep a Registry; you would be unsurprised to learn that a bureaucracy springs up around anything essential. Names, faces, ages (some of us never age, some age like apples), and histories are recorded. Guardians are assigned. There are shelters and ambulances with padded interiors for the more fragile among us: Desire has a very delicate spine, Shame prefers shadowed rooms and long collars, and Joy finally learned to stop swallowing lightbulbs when she was small. You'd think that would be enough. It is never enough.

They tried to destroy a feeling once because they thought it unnecessary. A city in a dry, bitter country voted unanimously to end Regret. “We will be the first to live without looking back,” the posters read. They believed their leaders when they promised rapid growth, fearless enterprise, a remade national character. The night Regret was taken from its small house on the river, the men with trucks called themselves Progress. They were careful: they used sleep and sweet wine and a blade that cut like a promise. Regret died without rancor. The next morning the city woke with new roads and new factories and people who could never again explain why they screamed at the sight of their own children’s paintings.

Without Regret, the city could not learn. Mistakes repeated like a machine set to loop. Creativity dulled; craft became careless because there was no backward glance sharp enough to carve improvement. Old letters were burned because burning felt easier than remembering. They did not want pity or admonishment; they wanted efficiency. After a decade the city became new and instant and poor: everything shiny on the surface, nothing held together. They called it success, and they had no idea what they had lost until their grandchildren leaned on the railings of a bridge they had refused to maintain and gravity took them down.

People argue, foolishly, that you can prune the undesirable feelings and keep the rest. Pride without Shame, we hear, or Anger without Wrath. There are factions built on such tidy fantasies. They do not last. Emotions are not single-strand ropes you can clip without fraying. They are tapestries, and when you cut one colour the pattern buckles, then rips. Remove Shame and Pride becomes a cartwheel that knocks down kindness; remove Anger and Tyranny grows without the barbed counterweight of righteous opposition. I have watched apathy fill the vacuum left by a murdered Shame. It arrives like fog and stays like rot.

We do not all agree on what should be preserved. Love once suggested we all live under glass, where no one could inflict the fatal cut. Love's uniform is portable; it could have argued for perpetual, unassailable safety. Love was stopped from that only because Grief, who lives in a house with no windows and tends to plants at midnight, said softly, “We do not need shelter from pain. We need to learn how to grow through it.” Grief is honest like that — he will never lie to you.

When people meet us without knowing, their reactions are telling. A child sees Joy and thinks a party is coming. A politician sees Ambition and imagines manifest destiny. You, who read this — perhaps with me sitting in the room at this very moment and your fingers riffling with the leaves of your life — will recognize the shadow of Memory on your own shoulder. I am awkward at parties. I tend to bring up things at inconvenient times. I will tell you where you left your grandmother's wedding ring, but I will also remind you of the face you promised to forget.

We do not all want to be saved. Some of us long for the quiet. Apathy spends a lifetime learning to be invisible; she walks like someone who is not listening, and sometimes she is not. People mistake her for boredom until they meet Silence, and then they understand the difference between being bored and being hollow. We have suicides among us — occasional, catastrophic. I will not describe the mechanism because my hands are old and because I am Memory and because when I say a thing out loud, the world thinks about it. I will only say this: when one of us chooses to remove herself, it is an act entire as an eclipse.

There are those who think other solutions exist: apps that mimic sensations, therapy that simulates a person you cannot touch. These are clever things, and in the interim months after an erasure they fill rooms with substitutes that have about as much use as painted fruit. You can download the idea of Courage; you cannot download the tremor that lets a child cross the street to rescue a dog. We are not simple inputs and outputs. We are context, history, bone and small habitual ways of moving and choosing.

Sometimes we fall in love with you. That must be said plainly because it complicates everything. Joy once clapped a senator on the back and made him ordinary enough to resign from office for reasons that steadied the country. Love has kissed a man into bravery he would not otherwise have known. Even Anger has been known to stand between two knives until neither is used. We shape you the way you shape us. You are not simple consumers; you are co-keepers. If you hunt a feeling out like a vermin, you will also hunt the uses for it. If you shelter us and teach us to be careful, you keep the fulcrums that let humanity balance.

So what can you do? The Registry is busy but not infallible. Watch. Do not welcome the people who offer you erasures as salvation. Do not pretend us away with slogans. If you meet one of us with a cold hand or a warm face — learn to sit with them. Invite Grief for tea if you must; leave him flowers. Teach Recklessness to cook, let Shame learn to bathe and then to say "sorry" with a soft mouth. Vote for laws that protect us as you would protect a forest that filters the air. Teach children the names and faces of the feelings they will meet; teach them to bow and to tend, not to harvest.

And if, by some chance, you meet me on a morning when the light is a particular kind of seized and gentle, say my name. I will tell you stories you forgot because I have to. I will drag up memories that stitch together a life. I will remind you of how you learned the shape of your mother's hands and the taste of your first winter. I keep things that everyone else wants to discard because they are heavy. I keep them because otherwise the world would not remember that it is a world.

We walk among you because you cannot be whole without us. You cannot prune a single winter out of the year without the seasons learning to rearrange themselves until no one can remember what snow was for. You will not, ultimately, make a better world by forgetting how a thing once hurt. You will make a world that thinks it has felt everything because you have taught it to, and yet it will not know itself at all.

If you see any of us and you are tempted to pull off a small, tidy revolution — hold back. Breathe. Let us sit down. Talk to us. We are all terrible at directions and we get lost; we will appreciate the company. If an erasure is proposed in your city, if a knife even whispers in a lover's hand, remember the bridge that fell in the city without Regret. Remember that you are made of a thousand small things that do not map onto profit or policy. Protect us because we teach you the cruel, necessary art of being human. We are fragile, and we are not yours to prune.

samples.prompt: In order to avoid aging and death, you may take out a loan of time. In order to pay it back, you must take a life or lives equal to the amount of years you borrowed.
samples.output:
They called it a loan because the lawyers liked it that way: precise, tidy, a number with an interest rate and a term. In practice it was a promise written on skin and bone — you walk into a Chronobank, they press a silver plate to your pulse, and for a fee the world leaves a little more of your future in their vault. You do not grey. Your face does not sag. Your stitches knit like a promise. The winters slide by like painted backdrops.

There was a clause everyone kissed away in the fine print: to balance the ledger, to keep the cosmos from tipping, you must take a life or lives equal to the years you borrowed. Take twenty years, you must take twenty lives. One life for each year pocketed. The state called it restitution, the banks called it actuarial fairness, the advertisers called it "continuity." The poor called it murder with a receipt.

I never asked how they counted. The rule is cruelly literal and conveniently ambiguous, and people with money liked the ambiguity. Some thought you could take twenty years from a single person with a long expected life; others thought a single heart beat counted as a life regardless of age. The Chronobank did not say, because the Chronobank made a profit on the question.

I am a collector. Not an executioner in the old, honest sense — there is dignity in firing squads, a certain terrible ceremony — but a broker of endings. I am hired by the borrowed, by families who cannot murder themselves to keep their heirs breathing, to do what must be done so that their clients may keep the unwrinkled faces they bought. I hunt, I arrange, I make transactions legal and painless. For a fee, I convert years into deaths.

Do not imagine me a monster. Monsters have easy comforts: conviction, zeal, doctrine. I had a reason. Twelve years ago I signed the thin sheet and took twelve years from my account. My daughter was small then and she needed an operation that the state would not fund; we did not have three lives between us and the hospital demanded a fourth. So I borrowed. I made a bargain with numbers. The surgeons stitched the child back together and we kept our unfrayed father-and-daughter life for a decade more. I watched her walk, learn to swear at boys, marry once with my chest in my throat. When she stopped calling and the hospital sent a note about embolisms that came too quickly for us to fight, I learned that debts are teeth that keep biting even when you cannot feel them.

After her funeral I could have paid. I had the money; money buys absolution, and the Chronobank sold it to you with a discreet nod. Instead I hired myself out. I took the work of taking because it kept me inside a human rhythm: the coffee, the booking, the waiting for a donor's last breath. It kept my hands busy enough not to ask where twelve lost years might show up if not in the faces of the living.

We had rules. Donors could be volunteered (convicted blood, unclaimed bodies), but most of the work — the work that paid well and polluted the conscience less — came from the poor who came to us with nasty eyes and something brave to sell. They called themselves donors, which was important. Donor sounded like consent; it sounded like an offering for a feast, not theft by ledger. We would take them in pairs in the soft rooms and give them a chair and a cup. They signed consent forms and the cameras recorded them smiling. The bank issued receipts in triplicate. The wealthy kept their elastic faces, and we sent pictures back to their dining rooms: the donor who had bought their son another decade, the donor who had been given a small clean bag of banknotes and left smiling into the stairwell.

The first time I did it I told myself I was doing something humane. A woman named Marta came to me with five years to sell. Her husband was dying of a slow fever and the pharmaceutical ration would have been in reach if she could make rent. She told me stories about potatoes and making faces at her grandson and how she had once owned a garden. I arranged the chair and the doctor explained that the procedure would be painless, and she held my hand while the sedative took the edges off her sentences. She closed her eyes and the monitor tapped a polite cessation. She had sold years to keep others living. In the ledger she was reduced to five marks and an entry that cleared a man's balance.

That night I dreamed of things that had names: the small hand in my daughter's, Marta's fingers drying on my palm, numbers multiplying in the dark. I began to keep a list. Names. Ages. The faces of those I had sent away. They formed a gallery in my head, a terrible portrait gallery. I would tape up their photos at the hotel where I stayed between runs and look at them when the door clicked shut. It wasn't rage; rage felt too loud. It was a slow, hollowing grief.

Most clients wanted me to be professional. They wanted me to choose donors with the least social utility, the oldest bodies, the unclaimed. Some insisted on names, wanted their debt paid by people they deemed desirable — thieves, addicts, the homeless — as if moral filth made the ledger smell sweeter. Once a woman offered to be present. She wanted to watch the man who had eaten her child's future die for what she had kept. She had that look, the one that made me remember I had once said yes to immortality for reasons more tender than greed.

And then there was Lila.

She came with four small signatures and a photograph of a son who could not stop coughing. She was twenty-two. When she smiled it was with her mouth alone; she did not have the practice of people who expect kindness. We met in the white room and she refused the sedative. "I want to remember," she said. She wanted to remember the last breath she gave and the first groceries her son would buy with the money. She wanted to be a benefactor, a giver.

We had a conversation that I had told myself a hundred times I would have and never did. "Why are you doing this?" I asked, ridiculous with expertness.

"Because if I sell these years I can buy a year's worth of clean air for him," she said. "Because my mother used to tell me you can measure love by the number of things you give up. Because I don't want the boy to be hungry the way I was."

There are many arguments for civic murder. There are reasons people can make their hands into the instruments of systems they will never be able to see past: expediency, survival, love. I could have read her file the way I read every file. I could have been the cog and kept the Chronobank's hearts beating under my palms. Instead my finger closed on the list under my bed and I thought of Marta and of my daughter spinning in a sunlit yard and of all the little small kindnesses that had added up to a life.

I went to the ledger room that night, where names were stored in glass and algorithm and policy. They glowed with the cold blue of things catalogued for convenience. I did not have a plan. I had only the weight of a long held-in breath and the knowledge that what we did would continue if one man continued to sign receipts. I had taken twelve years too many myself. I had sold others the ability to stay human and had told myself it was for my daughter, and it had been, once.

I used a match. Fire is an argument in the language the Chronobank refused to learn. It is a grammar that reduces ink to ash and numbers to smoke. The blaze ate policy and client files and every glossy advertisement that promised continuity for a price. It took hours for the vault to unclench; we had built redundancies for this very human sin. By the time the alarm red drowned the room in its voice there were no names on my wall. There were only charred corners of contracts and the smell of something that tasted like freedom.

They found me on the other side of the building, on my knees, with my palms out and the ash of the ledger on my fingers. They read me my charges and told me in clear voices about restitution, about damages, about the supply chain of death I had disrupted. It is funny what the law names when it speaks of crime: it names the property of the powerful, but rarely the property of those who cannot buy an afternoon in a garden.

They asked how I would repay. The Chronobank is thorough. It demands balance. If you destroy their records you make them angry but you also make accounting: who borrowed what? Who bought which breath? The ledger had been their God; I had burned their God.

"I will pay," I told them, and it was the only true thing I had left. "I will live the life I stole. I will let my hair go and my skin fold. I will count my days by the sunlight on the floor. I will not take any more lives."

They did not like the word repent; it had come to mean only a scheduled inconvenience. Some smiled as if their faces had stretched the length of calendars. They sentenced me to a term, for the good dress of law. They bound me to an old house with a radiator that clattered at night and a garden with a plum tree my daughter used to climb. They took my license to broker ends. They could not, and they have not been able to, keep me from the act that matters: nothing is returned to the ledger by burning a name. Paying does not always mean balancing numbers. Sometimes it means living the consequences you bought for other people.

Here, in a quiet house that creaks at its joints, I watch my skin rearrange itself into a map of lived days. I have no bank-smooth face anymore. My back aches when it rains and my hands are pocked with the memory of burns I never had before. Sometimes at night I sit with Marta's photograph and Lila's son on my lap and tell them stories about the places you can go when you are poor and have decided to be brave. I cannot ever give back the years I took, but I can refuse to take more. The world still offers loans; the advertisements still glow. People still come to us with desperation in their pockets.

When children ask me, as children do, what it means to be old, I show them my hands and say: "You count days like beads. You thread them. You let them show." They look at the lines like maps and sometimes they understand more than I deserve.

There are those who will call me a hypocrite. They will be right and they will be wrong. I failed in many ways; I betrayed and negotiated and hid behind a ledger I helped to keep. I will wear those failures like a coat, and when the last of my borrowed years settles into the hollow of my collarbone and says, politely, that it has to go now, I will not sign anything to make another man stay young. I will not look away while others sell themselves into ash for the comfort of people with warm houses and unwrinkled faces.

If the world wishes to keep its loans, let it count the cost not in dollars but in the grief of those who sell their mornings for someone else's eternity. If we must tally lives as if they were years, then let us at least tally who benefits. I will do my part by living until I die, by letting the days pay for themselves as they always have: one by slow, terrible one.

samples.prompt: You've been working with the most interesting guy for years. He goes on trips all the time bringing back souvenirs from all over the world. One day you happen to see him in a thrift store buying souvenirs "from his next big trip"and realize his whole persona has been made up.
samples.output:
Everyone at the office had a favorite prop of his. For me it was the chipped blue tile that sat above his monitor like a crooked halo. He'd tell you it was from an old alley in Lisbon where a woman in a yellow shawl had stopped him to sell tiles from a suitcase; he bought one because the woman laughed when he mispronounced rua. There was a brass camel from Marrakech, a faded instant photo of him grinning with two strangers under lanterns in some night market, a bent brass compass he claimed had belonged to an anxious sailor he helped cross a storm, and a paper fortune-teller from Tokyo that, when you unfolded it, said something earnest like "Go where you are needed."

He did it all with the same casual generosity. If someone was late or tired, he'd change the topic to “that time in Kathmandu” and suddenly there was a smell of saffron and the hum of a market. If someone vapor-locked during a staff meeting, he'd recount a daring taxi ride across a border or an impromptu handshake with a king’s niece at a wedding he’d nearly missed. He was never boastful; his anecdotes were small, human scenes stitched together with the gravity of someone who’d seen just enough to know the shape of things. He traveled, he said — a lot. And we believed him. We liked him. It is a useful thing, in a world of Excel and budget meetings, to have someone who makes the world feel large.

So when I saw him in the thrift store on a Tuesday afternoon — a place I walked by like everyone else on the way to get chips for the staff kitchen — I nearly laughed out loud. He was in aisle three, hunched over a plastic crate of keychains, his sleeve smudged with dust. Around him were racks of polyester shirts and boxes of cheap glassware; it was the kind of place where enamel brooches came with the ghosts of prom dresses. He stood there, flipping through items with a kind of reverence I had reserved for the last times I'd watched him tell a story.

In his basket: an Eiffel Tower snow globe, two postcards (Paris and Prague), a pair of wooden chopsticks wrapped in paper that had the name of some ramen place, a tiny wooden flute, a paper fan with a dragon painted in colors that had faded to soft bruises. He tucked them in like someone collecting pieces of a costume.

He didn't notice me at first. There was something incredibly ordinary about the way he examined that snow globe, blowing a speck of dust away and holding it to the light. For a second I imagined him testing the weight, wondering if miniature monuments could convince the same people he’d convinced before. Then he found a sticker, peeled it, and smiled the way someone smiles when they figure out a crossword. He carried the things to the register, paid in crumpled bills, and left with the small, heavy bundle of evidence.

I followed him out because I had questions shaped like betrayal. Outside, he sat on the steps of the thrift store, the carrier bag at his side. He was the same as always: hair a little more tired, eyes luminous, hands that knew how to gesture toward meaning. His smile when he saw me was quick and not quite guarded.

"Hey," I said.

"Hey," he said back, and for a second our exchange was the same as every morning. Then I asked the question that had been colliding with every souvenir on his shelf for years.

"Are you... actually going somewhere? Or—"

He bit the inside of his cheek, that little human tic he always pretended not to have. He considered the snow globe as if for the first time and then looked at me. "It's the next big trip," he said. "Gotta plan ahead."

I laughed because I didn't want to be the person who said what followed. "You buy the trip before you go? I thought you were bringing these back when you came home."

He shrugged. "People like things that are real." He tapped the souvenir bag. "Sometimes you make things real by deciding they're real."

It was a neat sentence. Too neat. I had watched him manufacture reality for years and in the delicate, exact way he arranged objects on his shelf he had been manufacturing himself. Maybe he'd been going somewhere; maybe he'd been nowhere at all. Either way, he was buying the proof.

I started naming the things in his office — the tile, the camel, the camera pictures — and he told me the stories. His voice moved through the same inflections, the same cadences. He was an artisan at story. I remembered the times I had wanted to impress someone, had wondered if the details of my own life were less lively than theirs. He filled a communal hunger for novelty and danger that our nine-to-five lives could not satiate.

"Why thrift store stuff?" I asked finally.

He looked at his hands, which were small and used to gestures. "Because it's cheaper," he said. There was no apology, and the way he said the word "cheaper" made the smallness of it only a detail. "Because it's got history. People get rid of things. They were someone's evidence once."

"Evidence of what?" I asked.

"That you were somewhere," he replied. "That you were not just here."

He handed me the snow globe. Inside, the Eiffel Tower was plastic, the glitter catchable with a flick. I shook it, saw Paris shimmer like a stage prop, and understood two things at once: that I had been made complicit in an illusion, and that the illusion had not been malicious. He wasn't trying to rob us; he was attempting to trade on an old currency — narrative — and he was very good at it.

"Why?" I said. "Why not just tell us you want to go? Why invent all this?"

He considered me for a long time, and then, in the way he always told the best parts of his tales, he told me a small thing about himself. "When I was a kid," he said, "I read a book with a man who went to a hundred countries. Everyone listened to that man like he was magic. I wanted that. But I never had the money or the passport. I had the stories, though. So I practiced them. I'd say the place names out loud. I'd tape pictures from magazines to a board. People listened. It felt...good."

He folded his hands around the bag and put them back in his lap. The thrift store's fluorescent light buzzed somewhere behind us like an indifferent sun. "Then a few years ago, a co-worker brought me a coconut from Belize because his sister brought it back and he thought of me, and it felt possible. Someone handed me a thing and my stories had weight. So I kept it going. I kept collecting the weight."

"That's elaborate," I said. "How many places have you actually been?"

He grinned at that, a little sideways, and the grin had the tired tremor of a trick that needed more applause. "More than I'd like to admit and less than it seems. I went to three real places. The rest are...performances."

I laughed then, not unkindly. There was relief in the confession, and the more he explained, the less like a conman he felt and the more like someone who had made a life-saving choice. He could have been invisible in an office cubicle. Instead he made himself spectacularly visible and shared that spectacle with others. We ate it up; our days were better because of his tales.

"Are you sorry?" I asked.

"For what?" He looked at me, earnest. "For lying? Maybe. For the way people treat me as 'the guy with the stories' and not 'the guy who needs a ride to his sister's?' Possibly. But not entirely. I like what I do. I like watching people lean in. I like being able to take their boredom and make it into something that smells like faraway coffee and wet streets."

We sat for a while longer in the half-light. He told me, then, about the time he actually left town — three real trips that had scarred him in the right way, that gave him small, true souvenirs that had the jagged edge of experience. He showed me one Polaroid from a ferry in Greece where his hair looked windblown and terrified. He had gotten lost in translation then, and the memory had lodged in him like a stubborn seed. Those were the trips that made the rest believable. The rest were scaffolding.

When we returned to the office the next day, his shelf looked the same: a curated museum of falsehood and truth. People gathered around him like they always had. I watched them, and I watched him watch them. There is cruelty in the revelation, certainly — in the idea that what we loved was, in part, a costume. But there was kindness, too: he was doing something human. He had taught us to be amazed.

I stopped policing him. I listened. I told him small things about home — the kind of tales you tell when you don't want anything to change. He listened back with the same gentle hunger for detail. Sometimes, toward the end of the week when the office lights went fluorescent and our phones quit shining, he'd pick up a thrift-store trinket and make it live. He never asked for anything beyond attention. He never demanded applause. He simply set a theater on a narrow shelf and invited us to sit.

On my desk now, beside my stapler and a plant I keep forgetting to water, I leave a little paper ticket from the bus that takes me to my mother's house. It's creased and boring. I used to think it not particularly interesting. After the thrift store and the snow globe, I started to like its dullness. It's proof, in the most ordinary sense: of leaving and coming back, of being somewhere for a while. It isn't exciting. It is true.

He still buys things at thrift stores. Sometimes they're for "the next big trip." Sometimes he brings in things from places he really has been. I have no desire to unmask him to anyone. Myth is a kind of kindness. And sometimes, when the office is dim and the dishwasher hums, he will take one of his objects down, hold it to the light, and I will listen to a story I know is partly invention and partly memory. It doesn't stop the world from being the world. If anything, it makes the waiting hours go by more beautifully than they would otherwise.

samples.prompt: You and 49 others wake up in a weird room. An automated message then begins playing: "For the next 50 years, you will race one another. You have been modified to remain ever youthful. Whoever gets to a checkpoint last is killed. You can use any means to get there. Your first checkpoint? Mars."
samples.output:
I woke up with the taste of metal in my mouth and a ceiling that hummed like a dented kettle. For a second I thought I was still drunk, or back at a layover hotel that never existed. Then the light came on all at once and fifty people rolled and sat and stared and swore and looked at each other like animals that had found themselves in a cage.

The room was round, the size of a small planetarium, windowless except for a ring of screens embedded high in the wall. Benches along the perimeter, a single sealed door, and in the middle a shallow bowl of water that fogged when anyone breathed on it. The air smelled like bleach and ozone. We were bundled in identical gray shirts and shorts. No phones, no jewelry, no shoes. People fumbled for pockets that weren't there. I shoved my hands into my hair and found a thin seam where my scalp met something cool — an implant, or a scar so new it felt foreign.

Then the voice came. Not from a person, but from the speakers in the wall: crisp, bored, too brightly cheerful.

"For the next fifty years, you will race one another. You have been modified to remain ever youthful. Whoever gets to a checkpoint last is killed. You can use any means to get there. Your first checkpoint? Mars."

The room roared. Men cursed. A woman laughed, a sound like a cracked bell. Someone screamed for the voice to repeat, to explain, to undo. The voice gave us time-stamped coordinates for the first checkpoint — an exact landing zone on Mars — and then, without another word, went silent. A countdown flashed on one of the screens: 89 days.

Ever youthful. Fifty years. Mars. The words struck like wet towels. I looked at the faces around me. There was a kid with acne and a comic-inked sleeve, a woman who looked like a nurse but had the hands of a sculptor, a man in a suit who smelled of strong coffee and regret, an old man who wasn't old anymore — he had been, but the skin on his neck no longer showed it. All of us had the same glassy, startled look: how long will this last? How much of me did they take?

"Modified how?" someone shouted.

"You're biologically preserved," the voice answered, as if reading our panic off an invisible sheet. "Neurochemical stabilization. Telomerase modulation. Nanoscopic cellular repair. You will not age in the conventional sense for the duration of the game. You will still bleed. You will still die. The first checkpoint activates in eighty-nine days at 04:00 GMT."

No one moved for a long time. Then movement happened in the way a wave happens in a stadium: one person stood up, then another, then fifty sets of shoes met the floor and shuffled toward the door.

We pushed. The door was electronic, thick, with a small window that showed a corridor lined with more doors. Flashing screens near the exit flicked to life and offered us dossiers — names, ages, backgrounds. They had all been people. Engineers, teachers, a couple of criminals, an astrophysicist with a bored face, a retired mechanic with hands that had welded submarines and trains together. Each dossier had a thin bank account attached, a list of skills, and a tag: "Asset: Active."

"Whoever is behind this rigged our bodies," I said to no one in particular, my voice small in the wide corridor. "They can make us young, but they can kill us too."

"Or they can't," said Ish, from the bench. He was wiry, with the kind of hands that had been allowed to get filthy in late adolescence and then kept that way. He'd been a volunteer firefighter, according to his dossier. "Maybe it's all bluff. Maybe they can't actually kill us. But they can scare us stupid."

The first split formed in the corridor like a fault line. A pair of men in what looked like ex-military jackets wanted to leave immediately for the nearest launch site. "Take the ships," one of them said. "We know how to patch a propellant feed on a budget. There are private pads two hours away. We go now, we secure seats, we get off-planet." A woman with an eval badge that marked her as "Aerospace — Lockheed" shook her head. "You've seen the global feeds," she said quietly. "There aren't that many rockets standing. Governments will lock everything down in hours. This is a coordinated event. They expect that."

Because there were screens, and because humans with resources love to make choices from a menu, the screens showed us more: live feeds from spaceports around the world, news tickers that blinked into being as networks tried to pick up the same message we had heard. There were lists of registered traceable assets — a sea platform off the coast loaded with a defunct cargo launcher, a private orbital tug in low Earth orbit with a depleted tank and two crew seats, a Chinese cargo manifest with an open cargo bay. There were also notes: "Asset access recommended: legal; security: low," typed with the same indifferent font as the voice.

We broke into groups of expertise out of habit. Engineers clustered with anyone who could weld or solder or code. A marketing exec and a philosophy professor debated ethics for five breathless minutes and then both agreed the ethics could be shelved because the sound of the countdown had teeth.

I found myself next to Kara — former NASA pilot, mid-thirties, who had a slow, precise way of speaking like a checklist. She had the one thing we all needed: a knowledge of orbital windows and delta-v budgets. "Eighty-nine days puts the Mars transfer pretty tight if you want a direct Hohmann," she said. "We could go on a fast trajectory if we burn a lot of propellant or we can wait for a longer window. But waiting is a strategy only if you can guarantee your survival in the meantime."

"Guarantee?" The suit guy laughed hollowly. "You guarantee nothing. You take what you can and you run."

"That mentality will get you everyone killed," Kara said. "There is value in alliances. Fifty people, one elimination per checkpoint — it's an attrition game if it goes to plan. If it doesn't, it's slaughter."

"Maybe it's supposed to be," Ish said. "Maybe they want exactly that."

We argued until our voices were hoarse and the screens were full of our debates. Plans bifurcated like rivers. Some wanted to steal a launch and crowd it: pack a booster with bodies like a funeral pyre. Some wanted to take a slower, stealthier approach — hijack a cargo tug, retrofit external tanks, ride a little-used trajectory. A small, terrible group wanted to find the weakest among us and clear the field early; they talked about making "practical adjustments." The room smelled of breath and fear and the coffee someone found in a vending machine that shouldn't have been working.

I thought about the word "modified" and what it meant. Whoever had done this could decide when the end came. They could also decide whether to allow us to cooperate. The game had been set up to incentivize mistrust, to make us fear each other more than the unknown. It had stripped our futures down to a race and a rule: last is dead. But the modification — the promise of youth — was a bait, and somewhere behind it sat a person, or a committee, or an algorithm, watching how we unmade ourselves.

"This is a game of movement," Kara said finally, putting her palm flat on a map of trajectories pinned to the wall. "If we move together, we can secure enough propellant and a craft that will get the majority of us to Mars in one wave. But there will be no seats for all. That means we plan for tiers — open the transfer to everyone who can contribute propulsion mass. Make the ship modular. If they kill the slowest...they are testing for selfishness."

Ish met my eyes. "Or we split. We take smaller teams. Those teams with skills get to make choices. Those who can't...well, the last will die anyway. At least with smaller groups we might be able to protect what we've made."

"What if we don't play?" a voice asked from the back. A woman stood there, hair cropped, fists clenched. "What if instead of fighting to get onto their checkpoint, we break the checkpoints? What if we reach out and destroy their ability to kill us? The implants — someone has to be able to jam them, or to disable their tracking. Maybe the room is the key."

The idea was ridiculous and brilliant. We spent the next hour tearing the place apart.

Beneath a panel, Ish found a server, warm and humming. Kara and a coder named Miguel tapped into it. The servers held more than dossiers: schematics, satellite access codes, a list of satellite links scheduled to go dark, a feed that could reach an orbital relay. The implant was not a death chip so far as we could tell; it was a leash. It pinged and it recorded and it could trigger with a single command.
